column2: MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Tass announced today invention of a new noiseless transport operating on a high frequency current without a trolley, rails or storage batteries.
A communique, as broadcast in English to North America yesterday from Chungking and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

It appears that the war is washing away the last barrier that has stood between two ways of existence in America -- that of the urbanite and that of the dweller of the tank town and the open prairie. Nowhere is this fusing process more at work than in New York.

PACIFIC FLEET HEADQUARTERS, Dec. 21 -- The arrival here of Admiral Sir Bruce A. Fraser, recently named Commander in Chief of British Naval Forces in the Pacific, to confer with Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, has spurred speculation as to just what part the strong British fleet will play in future chapters of the Pacific war.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- Maj. Gen. Robert B. McClure, United States Army Chief of Staff in the China Theatre, today served notice on the Japanese that the concentrated bombing of Hankow on Dec. 18 was only the beginning of such heavy air strikes against their installations in China.
Yesterday's Mediterranean communique, as transmitted in Italian by the Allied Press Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

In the "Children's Christmas Story," which received its first presentation yesterday afternoon at the City Center, the story of the birth of Christ was enacted in pantomime by a group of pupils from the schools of Greater New York and parts of New Jersey.

One million dollars' worth of purchased war bonds was represented by the presence of ninety-eight debutantes last night at the second Allied Flag Ball and Debutante Cotillion given in patriotically decorated surroundings in the grand ballroom and adjoining foyers at the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, declared today that "greatly increased" demands on war production would result from the German offensive.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 21 (AP) -- We didn't come out here just for the ride," Coach John Barnhill told his Tennessee football players today as he sent them through two long workouts, broken only by light lunch and heavy blackboard drill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The President and the Vice President had a long talk yesterday which, the latter informed some of his fellow "liberals," was very satisfactory. They have assumed from this statement that their wing of the Democratic party, the dominant one, will be recognized as such in the making of policies and appointments in the next administration.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Business in today's stock markets continued to be restricted, but the tone was firm and there were one or two good spots.

After holding within a 5-point range all day, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with net gains of 1 to 7 points. It had opened unchanged to 2 points up. Price fixing just about offset liquidation.

Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, American secretary of the World Council of Churches, maintained last night that "international agreements and treaties are not enough" for lasting peace, adding, "there must be behind them the force of public opinion, and that can be an abiding force only when tied to the deepest moral convictions such as those aroused and maintained by religion."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The outlook for a "White Christmas" in the North Country appeared promising yesterday, much to the delight of skiing enthusiasts, who plan to spend the holiday period etching tracks on snow-capped mountainsides. The Weather Bureau's special skiing forecast also indicated that a fall of from two to five inches of swirling flakes is anticipated from the Pennsylvania Poconos to New Hampshire's Mount Washington this week-end, to be followed by a cold siege.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Although the King of Greece is in London, there is no more news here than in Athens of his attitude toward the proposed appointment of a regency to exercise royal prerogatives until the future of the Greek Monarchy shall have been permanently decided.

The Brandt interests, operating a large chain of motion-picture houses, have expanded their realty holdings in the Times Square section through the acquisition of the Liberty and Eltinge Theatres on West Forty-second Street, it was learned last night.

Seventy per cent of the total of 32,000 ranch mink in the United Mink Producers Association was sold yesterday by the New York Auction Company. Top price on the skins, all Yukons, was $32. No comparison was available owing to the higher quality of the furs. All branches of the industry were represented at the sale.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Allied setback in Europe made it impossible to predict an end of the civilian production freeze, Samuel W. Anderson, WPB vice chairman, said today.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- During the week ended on Dec. 16, the Bureau of Labor Statistics comprehensive index of commodity prices in primary markets advanced to the highest level since the war began. The increase of 0.2 per cent for the week was caused by seasonally higher prices for eggs and apples and upward adjustments in prices for wheat and hogs.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Friday, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A communique:
Wednesday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Bucharest and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Plans for the manufacture of 150,000 coal stokers for installation in 1945 have been modified as a result of the recent order of the War Production Board subjecting authorizations to more critical review, the Stoker Manufacturers Association declared today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A letter has been sent by the National Education Association of the United States to representative educational organizations in each of the United Nations and associated countries inviting delegates for a world education conference.

Any suggestion that the United States enter into an agreement with Great Britain "on the percentage of controls to be lifted in specific industries must be opposed on the ground that it would constitute the most gigantic cartel in the world," Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, declared yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 -- Paramount has named Sonny Tufts for a starring lead with Ray Milland and Olivia De Havilland in "The Well-Groomed Bride," a comedy scheduled to go into production on Jan. 15 with Sidney Lanfield directing. Tufts, who was teamed with Miss De Havilland in RKO-Radio's "Government Girl," replaces Dennis O'Keefe.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- During the week ended Dec. 20, member bank reserve balances decreased $134,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

Harold (Red) Green, Brownsville welterweight, and Rocky Graziano of the East Side are paired in the top bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although neither fighter has especial renown outside the confines of Greater New York, their meeting has aroused considerable interest and Promoter Mike Jacobs is confident the contest will attract more than 12,000 spectators.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Christmas in France this year will be shivery and lacking in most of the good things to eat but the average family is struggling to make it happy for the children. Christmas here is children's day. In peacetime grown people danced, gave presents and visited friends on New Year's Day.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Within a few days the Lublin Committee of National Liberation, which came into being with Moscow's blessing as one of the pawns in the Soviet Union's game to by-pass the Polish exiled Government in London and give an atmosphere of legitimacy to Russia's unilateral decision to absorb former territory of the Czars east of the Curzon Line, will declare itself the provisional government of liberated Poland.

An over-all plan for corporate simplification and physical integration under the terms of the Public Utility Holding Company Act was filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, one of the last major utility holding companies to be affected by the "death sentence" provisions of the act.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Dec. 21 -- The battle in the Malmedy-Stavelot area continued with great violence, determination and resourcefulness through its fourth day today, with the advantage, perhaps, swinging slightly our way, but with the issue still undecided.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Celebration of Christmas began at the White House today.

Harry Fleischman, national secretary of the Socialist party, in his debate with Prof. Irving Fisher on socialism in your columns says: "But of course neither Dr. Fisher nor any other spokesman for free enterprise believes that the system can provide peace and plenty."

Large-scale public works have been given a prominent role in most post-war programs. A program costing about $1,200,000,000 has been approved by the Board of Estimate for New York City and is now being considered by the City Council. The principle of advance planning for capital expenditures is a sound one.

The butcher shop shutdown that New York meat retailers have been threatening to begin on Christmas Day seemed yesterday to have been averted by a conference in Washington, but immediately this city was faced by a new threat of a business strike -- this time by the owners of 2,000 delicatessen stores.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 425 East Fifty-first Street has been sold by the Empire Trust Company, trustee for holders of certificates of the Prudence Bonds Corporation, to the Gemcar Company through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. Assessed at $500,000, the property is 100 by 100 feet and contains sixty-six apartments.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Communique 257:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- President Roosevelt issued today a special executive order which in effect froze civil service permanent appointments at present levels in order to hold open the maximum number of jobs for competition by future veterans.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- Army Liberators of the Pacific Strategic Air Force bombed airstrip installations on Iwo Island in the Volcano group on Tuesday, in the thirteenth consecutive day of a neutralization offensive against enemy bases south of the Japanese homeland.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- Red Army forces, driving to within eleven miles of the Czechoslovak rail city of Lucenec after a three-day twenty-mile advance, yesterday threatened to entrap the last German army in northeast Hungary, while Berlin said that more than 100,000 Soviet troops had launched a great offensive southwest of Budapest.

By capturing team-field honors with a percentage that sets a new major league record and gaining four individual top rankings, the champion Cardinals established themselves by far and away the outstanding defensive club in the National League last summer, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A possible "issue of life or death" to employers in New York City's fur trade is presented by the action of the National War Labor Board in requiring arbitration of employe discharges throughout the entire year, industry members of the National War Labor Board asserted today.
Republican leaders in Congress, at a conference with Governor Dewey and Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, made plans yesterday for a vigoroous opposition party.

Duck shooters who have been complaining that the birds are staying too far out of range for meal-making purposes may find this interesting if not necessarily important. It's a report from F.C. Lincoln of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service that ducks are being "herded" by airplanes in the West, just as sheep are sent scampering in the desired direction by dogs.
LONDON, Friday, Dec. 22 (UP) -- The Russian Thursday midnight supplementary communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

William C. Wallace, 49 years old, of 533 West Forty-ninth Street, a member of Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union and of the City Patrol Corps, although having a previous felony conviction against him, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to seven and one-half to eight years in Sing Sing on his guilty plea to second-degree manslaughter.
The battle of Leyte in the Philippines appeared to be drawing to its close yesterday after a hard-fought two-month campaign, which has required more strength and more time than originally expected.

The war news from Europe again imposed yesterday a restraining hand on prices on the stock market. Cross currents ran through the entire session, but speculative influences proved sufficiently strong to allow a mixed closing.

The gray birch is a humble, unpretentious sort of tree -- a poor but worthy cousin of the glamorous white and aldermanic yellow. And like most of the humble service-giving forms of life in nature it is found over an extensive area. Betula populifolia doesn't grow very tall.

Pullman, Inc., concluded yesterday negotiations for the acquisition of the entire outstanding stock of the M.W. Kellogg Company, petroleum and chemical engineers, in a move to broaden the activities of the company in the face of the pending severance of the car-manufacturing and sleeping-car businesses.

A large exhibition of war art has opened at the National Arts Club, arranged by junior members of the organization. The show includes work by men and women in the armed forces and war services and several well-known artists. There was no jury.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, supported today one of his aides who had protested against a news blackout on Germany's counter-offensive.

Holiday travel increased slowly last night but Grand Central Terminal. Pennsylvania Station and midtown bus depots were not nearly so packed as had been anticipated. All through the afternoon traffic seemed somewhat lighter than on ordinary Thursday

ARMONK, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Not since two bank robbers were found hiding in an automobile trunk here eight years ago has there been such excitement on Main Street as today when a Santa Claus suddenly began giving away packages of cigarettes. Motorists skidded to a stop, icemen dropped their tongs and housewives hurried to the street to share in the bonanza.
HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Two jockeys suffered severe injuries and a third escaped unscathed in a spectacular three-horse spill during the first race at Gulfstream Park today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Complying with the Dec. 11 recommendations of the Westchester County Board of Acquisition and Contract, the budget and appropriations committee of the Board of Supervisors moved today to have the Supervisors lease the $4,000,000 county airport in Purchase to the North American Airport Corporation, affiliate of the Gulf Oil Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- Superfortresses of the Twentieth Air Force, in their fourth straight day of operations against Japan and occupied territories on the Asiatic mainland, attacked an airplane factory at Mukden, Manchuria, in force today and shot down or damaged thirty-three Japanese fighter planes that challenged them in combat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Paul A. Porter, who was director of publicity for the Democratic National Committee during the recent campaign, was appointed chairman of the Federal Communications Commission by President Roosevelt today.

Painting walls, cleaning upholstery, rearranging furniture and eliminating clutter are all things that the home decorator can do today without getting snarled up in material and labor shortages, suggested Emma Hopkins, president of the Decorator's Clinic, 4 East Fifty-third Street, in an interview yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The War Production Board warned today that restrictions over the use and distribution of lumber, already one of the most rigidly controlled materials, may have to be tightened further to offset reduced production.

There can be little satisfaction for the average Japanese in the initial success of the current German counter-attack in Europe. A man whose sleep has been trampled out by the 8,000 horses of a Superfortress probably reads the communiques from Berlin with a somewhat bleary eye.

Vito W. Rizzi, 34 years old, a medically discharged veteran of the New Guinea fighting, was found guilty yesterday in General Sessions of murder in the first degree, the jurors recommending to Judge George L. Donnellan that he be imprisoned for life.

Lauritz Melchior, Metropolitan Opera singer, exchanged the mantle of Lohengrin for the familiar red coat and britches of St. Nicholas yesterday morning when he played a cheerful and boisterous Santa Claus to forty children at the Jones Memorial Center of the Children's Aid Society.

Marilyn Hansen, a 17-year-old Hollywood High School student has been signed to a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer term contract. She was brought to the attention of the studio through her performance in the leading singing role in an Army camp production of "New Moon." . . . Also at Metro, Selena Royle has been assigned to the cast of the "The Harvey Girls" and "Hold High the Torch" has acquired Bruce Kellogg.
I should like to add a few footnotes to the informed and urbane discussion of liberals and the Liberal party contained in Topics of The Times of Dec. 20.

"Things are really tough these days so I am doubling my usual contribution to a most worthy cause," wrote an overseas veteran, "a battle casualty," who recently was returned and discharged. He sent $10 "In Memory of My Mother, Minnie Hahn," to the Neediest Cases Fund.

The news of the great battle now raging in Belgium and Luxembourg, which may turn out to be the decisive battle of the war, indicates that General Eisenhower has thrown large reserves into counter-attacks against both sides of the wide and deep wedge which the Germans have driven into our lines.

With the 1944 allocation and priority procedure of the War Production Board and the Office of Civilian Requirements credited in the trade with functioning quite successfully on children's coat and legging sets and snow suits, producers are looking forward to the Government's program for the new year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Twentieth Air Force communique 36:

LONDON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The chance that Britain may ask American-Russian aid in settling Greek political woes arose today along with a demand in the House of Commons that the British Government "invite" King George of Greece to remain here until his erstwhile subjects decide whether or not to take him back into the fold.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- President Roosevelt signed today the bill authorizing a $10,000,000 Public Works program in the Virgin Islands to provide slum clearance, fire protection, water supply, highways, sanitation and medical facilities.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Philippines, Friday, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- Far Eastern Air Force fighter planes began using an airfield constructed on Mindoro Island, 150 miles south of Manila, just five days after American landing parties went ashore there.

The action of the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday in refusing to approve the competitive sale of $12,500,000 of 4 per cent bonds of the Capital Transit Company to a group of investment bankers headed by Alex Brown Sons of Baltimore because it was not satisfied that "competitive conditions were maintained or that the price to the company and the underwriters' spread are proper," caused considerable uneasiness in underwriting circles.
LONDON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A joint Air and Home Security Ministries communique:
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Unless space for nurseries is provided in public school buildings in five neighborhoods of the city, the working mothers in the communities, the majority of whom are employed in war industries, will not have any facilities for caring for their children during the working day, according to surveys made by the Information and Counseling Service of the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children, Helen M. Harris, executive director, said yesterday.

Ninety hospitals and health agencies on Long Island have accepted definite quotas of nurses who can be released to meet the Army's urgent need for nurses, and some of them have already met their quota, the Nursing Council for War Service in the area announced yesterday.

Where shall we look for the garden spots of the nation? If it is war gardens we have in mind, then most of them will be found in urban territory. To be exact, there were this year two urban families with a home garden for every farm family.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, named today eight members of a fifteen-member medical panel which will advise on the treatment of veterans suffering from rare types of diseases encountered in far-away battle areas, as well as improvement of general medical practices in the treatment of veterans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A list of thirty-four fighter pilots who have shot down fifteen or more enemy planes up to Dec. 15 was issued tonight by the Army Air Forces. Maj. Richard Bong of Poplar, Wis., tops the group with thirty-eight planes destroyed. Although dispatches from the Pacific since have put his score at forty.

Directors of the General Foods Corporation approved yesterday contracts for the borrowing of $25,000,000 on unsecured notes on Feb. 1 to provide funds for the retirement of the preferred stock and to pave the way for expansion after the war.

Van Wyck Brooks, Louis Adamic, Franklin P. Adams, William Rose Benet, Thomas Craven, Henry Seidel Canby, Edna Ferber, Marcia Davenport, Thomas Mann, Langston Hughes and M. Lincoln Schuster have joined the new Independent Citizens Committee of the Arts, Sciences and Professions as initiating sponsors.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- New York State will receive $100,000,000 under the $1,500,000,000 Federal Highway Aid Bill signed yesterday by President Roosevelt, but this is only a small part of what the State plans to spend on a highway construction program during the five years after the war.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Red Wings equaled the season's high score for a National Hockey League club by whipping the New York Rangers, 11 to 3, tonight before 7,253 fans. Bill (Flash) Hollett got three goals for Detroit.

WITH UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Dec. 21 -- Valiant doughboys of the First Army, fighting the Germans at every turn since the enemy offensive started, have provided invaluable time in which to marshal necessary forces against the deepest penetration of the American lines, a staff officer said today.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Governor Dewey, acting to transfer for trial in New York County the cases of five persons indicted by the special grand jury investigating alleged crime in Albany County, directed today that an extraordinary term of the Supreme Court be convened in the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Center Street, on Jan. 29, and designated Justice Charles B. McLaughlin, of the Bronx, to preside.

To stretch generally short footwear supplies and to offset inflationary trends in shoe prices, the National Association of Popular Price Shoe Retailers, Inc., yesterday called for an immediate temporary holiday from rationing for 15,000,000 pairs of leather shoes.

BUENOS AIRES Dec. 21 -- The first measure taken specifically against a German firm in Argentina suspected of having contributed money for espionage or other activities on this continent was taken today when the Government by decree appointed a "manager-delegate" to act as co-administrator of the blacklisted company Thyssen Lametal, Sociedad Anonima.

Abdur Rahman Siddiqi, editor of The Calcutta Morning News and former Mayor of that Indian city, paid a courtesy call yesterday to Mayor La Guardia at City Hall and confided to reporters that the American cigarette shortage bothered him a bit.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 21 -- Berliners will have Christmas, after all, but only those who can afford to buy in the black market the traditional trappings of the German Weinacht, from children's toys to liquor. The "angels" of this "secret Christmas," as Berliners made it, are racketeers, many of whom deserted, foreign workers and war prisoners who got their start in the business by burglarizing party stores or railroad warehouses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Veterans Administration issued today the regulations for guaranteeing loans to veterans for buying or taking over the operation of small independent businesses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Outright dismissal of the Government's anti-trust suit against The Associated Press was asked by the news cooperative today on the ground that the case was based "on a theory not yet embraced in our law."
LONDON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended Dec. 20 reported an increase of 16,337,000 in note circulation to the record total of 1,242,037,000.

Net sales of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, totaling $651,410,411 for the fiscal year ended with October, were the largest on record for the company and 19 per cent greater than the volume of $545,389,601 for the previous year, John W. Thomas, chairman, informed stockholders in the annual report to be released today.

The Supreme Court has ruled that under the war powers it was constitutional to remove American citizens of Japanese descent from their homes on the Pacific Coast after Pearl Harbor. Whether it was right and necessary to do so is another story. Of about 100,000 men, women and children ordered out, about two-thirds were citizens.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, expressing the official War Department view, suggested today that the Germans were so fearful of the consequences of our advance into the Cologne Plain and Saar Basin that they had accepted the risk involved in their all-out counter-attack on the Western Front.

MADRID, Dec. 21 -- The Spanish press is striking out in earnest against what it considers the planned concentration of a foreign press propaganda offensive against the Franco regime. The attacks are leveled almost exclusively against the British press, especially the recent Spectator article of Savador de Madariaga entitled "Generalissimo, Go!" and the recent series by Vernon Bartlett, correspondent of The News Chronicle.

It is encouraging to learn that views of specialists in political science and authorities on business management, in addition to those of members of Congress, will be sought by the new House-Senate twelve-man joint committee on "modernization of Congressional procedure" when the committee begins hearings on the subject next month.
LONDON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Add post-war plans:

OUTSIDE STAVELOT, Belgium, 2:30 P.M., Dec. 21 (AP) -- American tank destroyers today smashed attempts by German armor to break through and rescue remnants of a German force of sixty tanks trapped near this embattled village.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Army and Navy revealed today that they were outfitting fighter pilots with "G-suits" (the "G" being for gravity) to keep fliers from "blacking out" in steep dives and other maneuvers.

A check of local markets yesterday revealed that over-all stocks of poultry for the Christmas dinner are about as low as they could be at this season, one chain store estimating that turkey supplies are only 25 per cent of normal. Meat, fortunately, though limited in variety, is comparatively plentiful, with mutton, veal and beef of lower grades readily available.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- The first post-liberation congress of the Radical-Socialists, who consider themselves in France the "grass roots" party, ended near midnight tonight with mild resolutions and a noisy row after the delegates voted down a proposal to replace the present provisionally appointed incumbents with permanent "dynamic new officers."

PROVINCE OF ZEELAND, the Netherlands, Dec. 18 (Delayed) -- Except for two corners and some higher reaches on the dunes, the entire island of Walcheren, reclaimed from the sea in the twelfth century, is now under water again as a result of bombing by British planes that breached the island's sea walls nearly two months ago as part of the campaign to liberate the port of Antwerp.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 21 -- Striking back with desperate fury American tanks and infantry have smashed into the northern flank of Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt's offensive, recapturing Stavelot, in Belgium, and engaging the enemy in a bitter battle for Malmedy, another road center behind enemy spearheads that have now reached Habiemont, thirty miles from the German frontier and eighteen miles south of Liege.

Melodies such as "East Side, West Side" and "Jingle Bells" rang out in Beekman Hospital yesterday as 200 children, once patients at the institution, gathered in its halls for their annual Christmas party.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- The wording of leases, many of them of informal nature, by which evacuated Japanese-Americans turned over their West Coast farms and businesses when they went to relocation centers in 1942, was regarded today as a deterrent to the evacuees' early resettlement on some of their own properties.

Red Cross girls, driving their two-and-one-half-ton clubmobiles up close to the battle lines, wherever the Army calls, are doing a "good, hard job," Mrs. S. Sloan Colt reported yesterday, after a return flight in a cargo plane from England.

Dr. Gabriel Turbay, Colombian Ambassador to the United States, has notified holders of the Republic of Colombia's 6 per cent bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1961, and 6 per cent bonds of 1928, due on Oct. 1, 1961, of an extension of time from Dec. 31, 1944, to Dec. 31, 1945, within which to exchange the bonds and appurtenance coupons for 3 per cent bonds, due on Oct. 1, 1970, of the republic.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The British Government announced in the House of Commons today a decision taken by the War Cabinet at a midnight session last night to draft women of the Auxiliary Territorial Service compulsorily for service overseas but deferred this proposal until the House had a chance to debate it after the Christmas recess.

ATHENS, Dec. 21 (AP) -- British tanks and rocket-firing fighter planes shelled and strafed Elas troop concentrations north of Athens today upon expiration of the 9 A.M. ultimatum in which Lieut. Gen. Ronald M. Scobie warned the Greek leftists that he would use every available weapon in an effort to restore order.

KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- Today's communique reported that British Fourteenth Army troops had occupied Wuntho and Nankan, on the Myitkyina-Mandalay railway, forty and twenty-five miles, respectively, southwest of Indaw, which the British Thirty-sixth Division captured eleven days ago.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- December rye advanced today 5 cents a bushel, the limit for one day, on the Board of Trade on general short covering. The close was at the top. Uncompleted contracts for 2,807,000 bushels were outstanding when trading started, and brokers said a large part of the open interest was eliminated before the close.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 21 -- Twelve hundred wives, fiancees and children of United States Army and Navy personnel are awaiting transportation to the United States from Australia. All have visas and the other required papers, but estimates of the time likely to elapse before they get berths vary from one to twelve months.

ULITHI ATOLL, Caroline Islands, Nov. 20 (Delayed) -- Ulithi Atoll, a cluster of tiny islands that looks from the air like a green necklace carelessly flung on the sea, has become one of the Pacific Fleet's bases west of Pearl Harbor in the two months since its capture.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Unofficial financial quarters estimate that the French Liberation Loan that closed last night had brought in 130, 000,000,000 francs. In a broadcast scheduled for tomorrow evening, the Minister of Finance, Rene Pleven, will announce the official figure.

The city's restaurants have enough turkey and chicken on hand to meet a record-breaking Christmas demand, but many diners-out will have to eat their bird without cranberries or cranberry sauce, Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Secretary Stettinius asked the utmost cooperation from employes of the State Department, assembled in Constitution Hall where the Under-Secretary of State, Joseph C. Grew, the Assistant Secretaries of State and Mr. Stettinius' special assistants were presented to them.

Jack Schoer, 48 years old, a proprietor of the Jackmor Hat Company, was killed late yesterday afternoon when a fire that swept his company's manufacturing plant at 21 West Thirteenth Street trapped him and forced him to leap from a third-floor window.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- President Roosevelt, Attorney General Francis Biddle, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the nine Supreme Court justices, former Justice James F. Byrnes, and three members of the Federal Parole Board, have been sued for a total of $75,000,000.

The eight-month-old mystery surrounding the purchase of the old Union Club building and adjoining properties at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street as the site for a new department store was cleared up yesterday with the announcement by Best Co. that this would be the company's new post-war home.

The Greater New York Fund has sent $2,702,806 in checks to the 408 local hospitals and health and welfare agencies for which it appeals, bringing the total distribution to date from the $4,620,275 subscribed as of Dec. 6 in the 1944 drive, to $3,664,885, it was announced yesterday by Arthur A. Ballantine, fund president.

The National Institute of Arts and Letters, honorary organization in the field of the arts, elected three new members at its annual meeting, according to announcement yesterday by Arthur Train, president. Membership in the institute, which is limited to 250 life members, is bestowed in recognition of distinguished creative accomplishment in the arts.

Acting at the request of the Army, the Office of Price Administration revoked yesterday the temporary change it had made on Dec. 12 in its price regulations to increase the shipment of dressed turkeys from the West to New York and other Eastern cities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Senators from livestock States have arranged a conference for tomorrow with representatives of Federal agencies on proposals for live animal ceilings.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- The Regional War Labor Board issued a decision today upholding a finding of its panel in the case of striking musicians of station KSTP in Minneapolis.

ONE noble experiment which has been abandoned without regret was the wartime measure some professional football magnates adopted of consolidating two teams into one. Thus the Eagles and the Steelers blossomed forth as the Steagles a year ago while the Cardinals and Pittsburgh joined forces to become the Car-Pitts this season. And a well-trod carpet the Car-Pitts were.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Remnants of three Japanese divisions fell back down the Myitkyina-Mandalay railway in Burma today, offering only slight opposition to pursuing British troops who occupied the rail town of Wuntho, 135 miles north of Mandalay.

A UNITED STATES NAVY BASE, in England, Dec. 21 -- Each one of a hundred American LST's [landing ship tanks] in this harbor was brightened tonight by a Christmas tree, complete with all the trimmings, donated by a grateful Englishwoman.

I have recently returned from France, where I had opportunities to speak to French people of all classes. I found them to be totally unaware of the extent of the American war effort and the sacrifices being made on the home front.

Lumber production decreased 10.8 per cent last week, compared with the like week a year ago. Shipments were down 18.4 per cent and orders 27.4 per cent, according to reports received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

" The tragedies of this war must not let us forget the tragedies we have right close to us," wrote Rosalie Gould Clark in sending $10 to the Neediest Cases of New York. Her gift was among 688 that came yesterday from the fighting fronts, from Florida, California, Utah, from those ill and dependent, from physicians, lawyers, business men, from mothers, school groups, children, and from many who mourn the passing of loved ones.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 22 -- Stanford University received in the first sixteen weeks of this academic year gifts aggregating more than $1,700,000, which exceeds the total for any previous full year in its history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 16 were 749,883 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 43,671 cars or 5.5 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 8,998 cars or 1.2 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 6,822 cars or 0.9 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Remo Cerulli, 2 1/2 years old, who had been missing since 5 P.M. Thursday when he was taken for a walk by a woman patron at his father's grill, 546 State Street, Brooklyn, was found at 9:30 o'clock last night with the woman in the New Adelphi Hotel at 470 West Twenty-third Street.

M.J. Abner has sold the four-story store and apartment building at 311-15 Queen Anne Road, Teaneck, N.J., to the Farimount-Newman Corporation for cash over a mortgage of $63,000. The building contains two stores and twenty-four apartments and occupies a plot 51 by 130 feet. The C.B. Snyder Realty Company was the broker.

WITH THE UNITED STATES SEVENTH ARMY, Dec. 22 -- The Germans are apparently capitalizing on the propaganda value of their offensive on the First Army front by giving the Wehrmacht on other fronts, such as this one, shots in the arm in the form of exaggerated accounts of German successes.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22 -- The Russian Army's newspaper, Red Star, reiterated today the warning that a departure from the unanimity rule among the permanent members of the proposed international security organization on questions affecting one permanent council member would endanger the stability of the entire world order and stimulate the formation of various blocs inside the council.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 22 -- The strategic objective of the present German offensive is Antwerp, neutral military circles in Berlin report. To prolong the war, the Germans desperately need Antwerp, which is a major gap in the chain of Atlantic coast ports held or controlled by them.

Servel, Inc., of Evansville, Ind., filed yesterday a registration statement in Philadelphia with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the proposed offering of 60,000 shares of $4.50 cumulative preferred stock of no par value. The offering price to the public will be supplied by an amendment.

Mayor La Guardia's inclusion of a $3,500,000 lump sum appropriation in his executive budget for 1944-45 was criticized yesterday by the Appellate Division in a unanimous decision reversing the action of Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber in dismissing a taxpayer's suit sponsored by the Citizens Budget Commission.

HEADQUARTERS OF TWENTIETH BOMBER COMMAND, China, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- The crew of "Superstitious Aloysious," a superfort of the Twentieth Bomber Command, today dropped bombs on Mukden, Manchuria, and returned to base to complete three missions and more than thirty-four hours of combat flying in the last three and a half days.

ATHENS, Dec. 22 -- Current reports to the effect that a new communication from the Elas group setting forth proposed settlement terms has been received at Lieut. Gen. Ronald M. Scobie's headquarters were authoritatively denied here tonight. It is known, however, that such a communication has been drafted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Women labor officials of Mexico, Puerto Rico, Brazil and Chile who have been studying for three months the labor laws of this country and their enforcement said today at a farewell press conference that they thought their countries could profit by some of our enforcement methods but that they considered their labor laws as good or better than ours.

Mrs. Israel Sieff of London, who was a British delegate to the recent war emergency conference of the World Jewish Congress in Atlantic City, was guest of honor at a tea held yesterday by eleven national Jewish women's organizations at Congress Hall, 7 Central Park West.

Distilleries will produce about 20,000,000 gallons of bourbon whisky in January if they are permitted to use corn, according to estimates of representatives of the industry yesterday. Reports from Washington indicated that corn would be allotted for manufacture of bourbon, the first to be made by American distilleries in more than two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- Between 70,000 and 80,000 soldiers are returned from overseas each month and more than 750,000 have come home on leave since Pearl Harbor, Secretary Stimson disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Labor members of the War Labor Board, seeking a declaration that all wages below 72 cents an hour shall be considered substandard, a rise of 22 cents over present policy, said today that the board for almost three years had refused to attack this problem in "forthright fashion."

The first heartening tinge to the European war news since the German counter-offensive was started was seized upon eagerly yesterday by followers of the stock market, and prices recovered as much as a point. Although the main force of the rebound was in the railway shares, sufficient optimism filtered into other sections to give the list a generally brighter appearance.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
The major leagues face their fourth wartime baseball season with more manpower than at any time since the start of World War No. 2.

ROME, Dec. 22 -- Two trials ended this afternoon and as a result two generals charged with failing to defend Naples against the Germans and one of Benito Mussolini's former mistresses received aggregate sentences of seventy years in prison.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 21 (AP) -- James M. Kurn, 74 years old, former president and co-trustee of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad, has resigned because of ill health, it was learned tonight.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Dec 23 -- Troops of the Seventy-seventh Division drove three miles west of the Ormoc corridor toward Palompon, Japanese escape port on north-western Leyte, and the port itself was placed under American artillery fire.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, 148 1/2, of New York, used his advantages in height and reach in effective fashion tonight while gaining a seven-round technical knockout over Georgie Martin, 153, of Boston, in their scheduled ten-round feature bout at the Boston Garden.
PARIS, Dec. 22 -- Although little news trickles out of Spain, it is evident today that there has been much wishful thinking on the part of exiles in this country, regardless of party.

Confronted with an acute and progressive shortage of labor, Germany mobilized her last reserves of labor in 1943. Gotthard Friedrich was then appointed Reich Manpower Engineer and given thirty-four regional assistants to direct 5,000 plant engineers whose appointment by individual managements had to be approved officially.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Production of tires for civilian passenger cars will be slashed to 5,000,000 in the first quarter of the coming year.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 23 -- Berlin said last night that the Red Army had opened its winter offensive, hurling about 270,000 men into battle in Latvia, while Moscow announced Soviet advances in Czechoslovakia to within nine miles of the menaced rail city of Lucenec.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Roosevelt appealed to the people on the home front today to back up the fighting forces with a sustained concentration on efforts which will help win the war as quickly as possible.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Jimmy Nelson, former Alabama backfield star, will not be in the South's line-up for the Blue-Gray football game here Dec. 30, it was disclosed today.

Richard De Wolfe Brixey, president and treasurer of the Kerite Insulated Wire and Cable Company and formerly president of the Art Centre, who died March 14, 1943, left a net estate of $2,894,352, according to an appraisal filed yesterday.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 22 (AP) -- As United States Tenth Air Force pilots wrecked further enemy bridges, front-line dispatches indicated today that the Japanese had decided to give up northwest Burma and fall back to a defense line around Mandalay.

An average collection of 13,000 ranch mink of general shippers brought a top of $27 on a turnover of 58 per cent at the New York Auction Company sale yesterday. Ninety per cent of an offering of 1,000 wild mink was sold, the high being $25.75.

SOMEWHERE IN BELGIUM, Dec. 22 (AP) -- American doughboys fighting a powerful German armored column at close range with bazookas and hand grenades today sealed off the western exit to the Ambleve River pocket after a slambang forty-eight-hour battle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Preliminary soundings on the tariff, which some observers think will be one of the controversial issues in the new Congress, have been started by the executive and legislative branches of the Government, it was learned here today.

The fourth wartime Christmas will be celebrated in the churches beginning at noon today when the annual Yuletide service of carols for business men and women will take place in Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway, at the head of Wall Street.

LONDON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Royal Air Force Lancasters and Halifaxes tonight blasted the Rhine railhead cities of Coblenz and Bingen, supply distribution centers for Field Marshal Rundstedt's attacking armies.

The local basketball program tonight shows only three games: the double-header at Madison Square Garden, where Long Island University opposes De Paul and St. John's faces the University of Puerto Rico, and the contest at City College, where the Beavers tackle the Trinity College aggregation.
Yesterday's Communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Japanese remnants fleeing from the Ormoc corridor are trying to cut their way through to Palompon.

Because of his heroic action in saving the lives of fellow-members of an anti-aircraft gun crew in the South Pacific, Henry Schimensky, 19 years old, Navy boatswain's mate, 2/C, got off with a suspended sentence yesterday in General Sessions, where he was tried on a hold-up charge.

Announcement that in just six days an airfield has been put in operation on Mindoro has implications for the Japanese as important as the whole campaign in the Philippines. From Leyte and Mindoro the enemy-held islands of the 1,200-mile archipelago can be brought under air siege by land-based planes.

Marcel Hubert, French 'cellist, gave his postponed recital last night in Town Hall. As always, the artist's performances were musical, refined and imaginative. The pure, resonant tone he drew from the strings invariably retained its singing quality, and was capable of a wide range of color and dynamics, as well as exceedingly subtle nuances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Two important banking groups were said today to have agreed upon their position with regard to the Bretton Woods monetary proposals, which will be a major subject of Congressional attentiion in the next few months.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 22 -- The great German winter offensive smashed westward through Belgium unchecked today for the seventh consecutive day.

As we think of loved ones absent in the service of our country at this season we will be comforted by the assurance "that nothing can separate them from the love of God that is in Christ Jesus," Presiding Bishop Henry St. George Tucker of the Protestant Episcopal Church declared in a Christmas message issued yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 22 -- The nightmare of the Nazis' return to Brussels, haunting the Belgians this past week, has driven some to inquire what plans are being made for the Government's evacuation of the capital. The answer given, with the utmost firmness, is that nothing of the kind is contemplated.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 22 -- A novel method for making lace on sheets of polyvinyl alcohol, an improved process for obtaining gramicidin and an instrument for sewing up wounds are among the 512 inventions listed in the current issue of the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

Irving L. Levey, who was elected last November to a fourteen-year term as Justice of the Supreme Court, was sworn in yesterday in a brief ceremony by Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division Court. The oath was administered in the library of the Court House, at Madison Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, and Justice Levey will assume his duties officially in Manhattan Supreme Court on Jan. 2.
ALBANY, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Six prisoners received their freedom tonight and the terms of two others were shortened in Yuletide commutations of sentences by Governor Dewey.

Investment bankers, after a month devoted almost exclusively to the Sixth War Loan campaign, resumed public offerings of new securities here this week, marketing eight new bond issues amounting to $69,953,000, the largest weekly figure since mid-November.

ATHENS, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Continued British attacks with tanks and rocket-firing Beaufighters appeared to be liquidating Elas opposition in southern Athens and the near-by port of Piraeus. Following up his declared intention of swiftly cleaning up Elas resistance, General Scobie sent landing forces across the main harbor in western Piraeus in assault boats today.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The German Transocean news agency interrupted an Eastern Front broadcast tonight to flash a statement that Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt's offensive in the west had been halted by "increasingly furious counter-attacks by several divisions of the United States Third Army," to the south of the First Army front.

MALMEDY SECTOR, Belgium, Dec. 22 (AP) -- It was estimated today that 500 parachutists who dropped behind the lines at the start of the German offensive had been virtually liquidated. The end came this morning when some parachutists sent word that they needed medical attention and were ready to surrender.

Trains, buses and planes moved in and out of New York City yesterday burdened to the doors with Christmas riders, 50 per cent or more of them service men and service women on holiday leave. Every bit of available rolling stock and every available plane was used to carry the load, which included thousands of standees.

ROME, Dec. 22 -- On the anniversary of the battle for Ortona which they won last year, Canadians of the Eighth Army have further unhinged German defenses west of Ravenna, captured Bagnacavallo and advanced the front to the Senio River.

Although the provision which would have included the particular type of aircraft facility known as "flight strips" was deleted from the Federal Aid Highway Bill this is one of the matters which merits further consideration. The flight strip should not be a subject of controversy. It is corollary to and not competitive with the over-all airport program.

Fifteen soldiers, eight of them possessors of the Purple Heart Medal, are working in the shops at the Morey Machinery Company, Inc., at 4-57 Twenty-seventh Avenue, Astoria, Queens. The plant manufactures equipment for plants that make heavy ammunition for the Army.
Many year-end changes in firms having membership in the New York Stock Exchange were made known yesterday.

M. L. Hess, Inc., were the brokers in the sale of the six-story store and loft building at 860 Broadway by the Sperry Hutchinson Company to an investor. The building was occupied for many years as the New York headquarters of Butler Brothers, who recently have transferred some of their activities to Baltimore, Md., and is now being used as the fashion pool center for the Butler Brothers stores throughout the country.

Several recently developed shortages and some which have been intensified within the last month indicate that the plastics industry faces "the most severe material and machinery drought of the entire war," molders of plastics products stated yesterday.
MOSCOW, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Pravda attacked Argentina today as an "asylum of Hitlerites," declaring its rulers continued to air Germany against the United Nations.
WITH AMERICAN TROOPS IN BELGIUM, Dec. 22 -- Eleven American soldiers had to strangle their pet dog to keep him from giving away their hiding place to the Germans.

" THE RAZOR'S EDGE," by Somerset Maugham, did not make a great hit with many critics, and yet the American public, or more correctly one of its publics, has given it a strong and sustained response. Why? As a storyteller Mr. Maugham is as adroit as they make them, but while his story and the setting must have engaged his readers, "The Razor's Edge" was not solely compelling on that account.

Brooklyn College's dream of some day beating New York University at basketball remained a dream after their meeting last night before an overflow crowd of 1,200 at the Kingsmen's gym. For Howard Cann's boys defeated Tubby Raskin's crew, 57 -- 48, the setback marking the ninth with never a victory for Brooklyn since the series started in 1933.
With one shopping day to go, Christmas trade is maintaining the record high sales totals noted earlier this month, merchants here reported yesterday.

HEADQUARTERS OF 21ST BOMBER COMMAND, Saipan, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The first planes over Nagoya today met heavy ack-ack but few enemy fighter planes. As in previous raids, the later "Superfort" formation fought off hordes of Japanese fighters but little ack-ack.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Lottie Wolf of Detroit, who arrived yesterday to see her horses round out a remarkably successful campaign at the Gulfstream Park meeting which ends tomorrow, was represented by another winner when Good Going, 19-10 favorite, ran off with the Kentucky Purse by three lengths today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- After an hour-long conference with President Roosevelt today, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson reaffirmed the stand he took at his news conference yesterday that he was not getting panicky over the German offensive on the First Army front.

A cold wave held the upper half of the nation from the East Coast to the Rockies in its grip yesterday as the first full day of winter sent seasonal records tumbling in New York and many other communities.

Joe DiMaggio, who was baseball's topliner when he elected to cast his lot with the Array Air Force at the close of the 1942 campaign, called at the Yankee offices yesterday to extend holiday greetings to President Ed Barrow and for a few seconds gave his former employer the shock of his life.
Harold Green and Rocky Graziano came back to Madison Square Garden last night and put on another exciting struggle that ended with the identical result that followed their initial meeting on Nov. 3.

Stan Musial, fleet Cardinal outfielder, who has been no bargain for any opposing pitcher since going to St. Louis, surprised no one by finishing last season as the National League's leading slugger. As revealed by the official miscellaneous averages just released Musial, for the second straight year, topped the league with a percentage of .549.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Department store sales for the week ended Dec. 16 were 17 per cent above sales in the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists changes from like periods of last year:
ROME, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A communique:

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday transferred $223,292,833 in fine gold from the account of the Bank of France to the account of the National Bank of Belgium, thus terminating litigation begun in New York courts in February, 1941, arising out of the delivery of that amount of gold by the Vichy Government of France to Nazi occupation authorities in that year.

In addition to the reports of the recent four-day convention of the Socialist party in France printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES, the French Information Service here has furnished the text of the following resolutions, the passing of which ended the convention:

Wholesalers who sent applications to the War Production Board for priority assistance on staple cotton piece goods indicated yesterday that they "went through the motions" without any real hope of relief.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- In a precedent-setting procedure, the anti-trust prosecution of the Aluminum Company of America by the Federal Government will be argued Jan. 2 in New York City before a court especially empowered to make a final settlement of the long-drawn-out issue, it was stated at the Department of Justice today.

General Eisenhower's Order of the Day to "all units of the AEF" was typically his. It also was typically American. It does not rank in eloquence with some of the defiances Winston Churchill threw at the Nazis in England's dark hours of 1940 and early 1941.
BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- The Southerland, another of the Navy's new type 2,200-ton destroyers was commissioned today at ceremonies in the navy yard.

DENVER, Dec. 22 -- Forty-one thousand persons who are receiving old-age pensions from the State will share in a $2,000,000 jackpot Jan. 20 as the result of a recent court decision which released accumulated funds. This amount will be paid in addition to $1,600,000 to be distributed as the normal January pension.

A SMALL ALSATIAN VILLAGE, on the Seventh Army Front, Dec. 22 -- There will be no Christmas party in this village Monday morning. The uncertainty of war cast a shadow over the doughboys' plans and made it necessary to hold, the party at noon today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The U.S.S. Ward, a destroyer-transport which sank a midget Japanese Submarine one hour before the attack on Pearl Harbor, and the U.S.S. Mahan, a destroyer, were identified today by the Navy as the two vessels reported lost in the naval operation supporting the Ormoc landing in the Philippines on the third anniversary of Pearl Harbor.

Under the bare, gray branches of trees planted in memory of veterans of World War I, the Salvation Army conducted yesterday a service of praise and prayer for men and women now in the armed forces. Shivering passers-by stopped in silent groups and forgot for a moment the bright parcels in their arms as they joined in the noon-hour meeting at Madison Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

On top of all the misfortunes that befell the Brooklyn Tigers in their National Football League endeavors throughout the 1944 campaign comes the news that they may be without a home grldiron in 1945. In other words, as someone once said: "Things weren't bad enough, they had to go and put a hill in front of the poorhouse."

Yesterday, in the belief that many women would do their weekend marketing on that day, we offered our suggestions for the Christmas dinner. Today we follow with some recipes for it (see below in the menus for next week if you missed it).

Lord Wardington, chairman of the Bank of London and South America, in his remarks to stockholders in the bank's annual report, discussed at some length the potentialities in Latin-American trade both to the United Kingdom and the United States.

Jule Marshall of Larchmont, an archer who has two deer to his credit and was out for a third during the recent bow-and-arrow season in Westchester, has drawn certain conclusions about his specialty. Incidentally, he did not get a deer this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Sixteen Senators from cattle States met in closed session today with representatives of the Office of Price Administration and the War Food Administration, to discuss the possibility that ceiling prices might be put on animals on the hoof.

Full agreement has been reached with the Bergian Government and Allied military authorities on the distribution of private relief to Belgium, it was disclosed yesterday by Maj. William Wickham Hoffman, president of the Belgian War Relief Society of the United States of America.

Mayor La Guardia joined hands yesterday with the city's retail butchers in demanding that the Federal Government step in immediately with some workable plan for averting a "meat holiday" here. With retailers threatening to stop sales beginning on Christmas, the Mayor said: "Washington cannot remain idly by in a situation where dealers want to comply with the law."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Exporters were advised today by the Foreign Economic Administration that proposed exportations to Turkey through commercial channels will no longer require consideration by the British-American Coordinating Committee in Turkey except for certain items.
Thursday's communique, as broadcast domestically from Bucharest and reported by the Federal Communication Commission:

Faced with a threatened strike of bakery wagon drivers and the possible spoilage of their products in a wage dispute, a group of major pie and bread producers in New York City decided yesterday to abandon all operations over the Christmas weekend.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Dec. 22 -- More than 500 workers in the Brunswick shipyards volunteered today to work Christmas Day "without pay as a gift to the boys overseas" and assure the launching of the seventh merchant ship in December.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, on the Western Front, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- With cooks, company clerks and military police fighting side by side, a thin line of doughboys from a single battered regiment miracuously held off an attack by an entire German division last Saturday morning and in an epic stand saved the city of Luxembourg from being engulfed.

John S. Olsen and Harold O. Johnson, explosive exponents of the slapstick antics, will return to Broadway tonight in what they describe as a "new musical madhouse" entitled "Laffing Room Only." Fashioned, more or less, after its famous predecessors, "Hellzapoppin" and "Sons O' Fun," the show is to open at the Winter Garden Theatre, marking the comic team's third engagement at that playhouse since 1938. The show is said to represent an investment of $300,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Russia has promised to meet the rising Allied demand for Red Army action by hurling three army groups against the Germans on the Eastern Front.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Britain's opinion of what the present war situation demands was made plain tonight by an announcement from Prime Minister Churchill's office that 250,000 more fighting men would be found for the United Kingdom's armies in 1945.

The family is the foundation of society. It is the unit that is the nourishment and strength of life. And yet, ironically, it is many times in delicate balance: today a family may be cheerful, healthy and flourishing; tomorrow it may be helpless, in the depths of sickness and despair.

With war casualties mounting and the war wounded reported to have inadequate nursing care, Mayor La Guardia yesterday called an emergency meeting for Jan. 4 to discuss what constructive plan will raise enlistment figures of nurses in this city.

Export advertising in the years immediately following the war will amount to at least $100,000,000 annually, of which $65,000,000 will be used in the press and on the radio, according to Joshua B. Powers, president of J.B. Powers, Inc., foreign publishers representatives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The War Department favors universal military training for purely combat purposes, in contrast with President Roosevelt's suggestion of training with educational and social aspects.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Communique 258:
ADVANCED HEADQUATERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A communique:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -- Republic has signed Jimmy Lydon, the former Henry Aldrich of the Paramount series of that title, to a term contract. His initial picture for the company will be "The Amazing Mr. M.," a murder mystery story involving a retired stage actor, which will have Joseph Schildkraut in the lead. Also set for the picture, scheduled for a start late in January, are Eugene Palletters Ona Munson and Ann Gillis.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Reinforcements were brought up to bolster stiffening Japanese resistance at Hochih tonight, the Chinese High Command announced, and observers here believed the enemy had decided to try to hold the Kwangsi Province town as one of its strong points screening the corridor between China and Indo-China.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- France soon will formally join the United Nations by signing a joint declaration and French officials expect Gen. Charles de Gaulle to be invited to sit with President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Stalin at their next meeting or at an early conference after that.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A communique:

The first performance of the season of Verdi's perennially popular "Rigoletto" could not be called an incompetent or unprofessional one, but neither could it be termed a triumph. Mr. Sodero directed with authority and deserves most of the credit for the precise, crisp pacing of the performance as a whole.

French members of the original Press Wireless station in Paris have been found and are at work once more in the re-established communications center, and equipment, which the men hid in cellars and attics when the Germans came in 1942, has been recovered intact and most of it placed in service, John Parkerson, Washington manager of Press Wireless, reported Thursday shortly after his return from a flying trip to Europe.

With clues unwittingly provided by a pair of Doberman Pinscher puppies, detectives located yesterday a diamond and ruby ring valued at $4,000 that had vanished seven hours before from a night table in the apartment of Mrs. Jean-Pierre Stern of 930 Fifth Avenue.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Short covering and professional commission-house buying advanced grain prices rapidly today on the Board of Trade, with rye in the lead.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Senator Harry S. Truman plans to accept no executive sideline jobs after he becomes Vice President on Jan. 20.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Charles P. Manship of Baton Rouge, publisher and former United States director of censorship in London, said today he had come away from England "with great admiration for the British people and their steadfast determination to win the war."

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- After a vigorous horseback ride on bridle paths of her estate here today in a temperature of 6 degrees above zero, Gen. Evangeline Cory Booth of the Salvation Army, who will be 79 years old on Christmas Day, was asked for a birthday statement.

EVEN if the University of Puerto Rico basketball squad doesn't win a game on its present competitive tour of the United States, the players at least have realized one burning ambition. All the way north on the train from Miami they scanned the skies disappointedly. The one thing they wanted to see above everything else was snow.

A report has been made public by the War Contracts subcommittee of the Senate Military Affairs Committee proposing a new kind of Federal budget, a "job budget." The whole document is instructive because it accepts nearly all the popular economic slogans that have lately been drifting about in the air, and attempts to enact them all together in a single bill.

In the presence of a repatriated American war captive, volunteer workers at the Brooklyn Red Cross Prisoner of War Packaging Center, 255 Eighteenth Street, sent the 1,000,000th parcel rolling off the fifty-woman assembly line yesterday.

Today's lone film newcomer is "Lake Placid Serenade," opening at the Republic Theatre. This ice-musical stars Vera Hruba Ralston former Czech figure-skating champion, and features skating specialty numbers by Twinkle Watts, McGowan and Mack and the Merry Meisters.

The New York Curb Exchange, with a thirty-five-foot Christmas tree and a twenty-five-voice boys' choir from St. Teresa's Church in Brooklyn, provided yesterday Wall Street's only formal Christmas celebration this year. The usual Wall Street community tree was omitted, principally because the PT-boat used to advertise the Sixth War Loan blocked the section of Wall Street in which it usually is erected.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The news that France had signed a treaty with Russia similar to the one Britain negotiated with the Soviet Union more than two years ago was received here with considerable outward enthusiasm. Yet there was evidence of dissapointment because Gen. Charles de Gaulle did not approach London before Moscow when the time came to think about reconstructing the old entente cordiale.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- Parisians' nerves, already taxed from lack of news about the German counter-offensive, were further jangled tonight by the report of the arrest of a number of German agents in the city.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation disclosed yesterday that it is negotiating for the sale of its telephone subsidiary in Spain, although no definite agreement has been reached. In the event a deal is concluded, the subsidiary, Compania Telfonica Nacional de Espana, would be acquired by the Spanish Government.

While the volume of business in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was small yesterday, the undertone was steady and final prices were 3 points higher to 4 points lower than on Thursday.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Although the approaching Christmas holiday checked business today on the stock markets, the undertone was firm. Today was the last working day before the holiday and the market closed earlier than usual.

Dr. Hahn's pamphlet on deficit financing, published by the American Chamber of Commerce, is cited as an authority in THE NEW YORK TIMES' case against any recourse to deficit financing in post-war America.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Dec. 22 -- The fog that had shrouded the battlefield for two days turned to snow last night. It hid the mud and enhanced the beauty of the fir groves through which our men are fighting, but increased their discomfort. So it will be a white Christmas here in the Eifel Range -- but what a Christmas!

Richard Wright's autobiography of his early life in the South, "Black Boy," and "Apartment in Athens," Glenway Wescott's novel about occupied Greece, have been chosen by the Book-of-the-Month Club as their dual selection for March. Harper is publisher of both books.

Pretty, dark-haired Mrs. Alice Kingsley Wiltshire was late for work but forgiven yesterday morning. Through the day she kept exclaiming, "The nicest Christmas present ever given to me!" The personnel of Abbott Kimball Co., advertising agency, 250 Park Avenue, agreed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Secretary Forrestal approved today the awarding of the Purple Heart decorations to three war correspondents killed or injured in Pacific war action, Jack Singer of the International News Service (posthumous); Charles H. McMurtry of The Association Press, and Joe James Custer, United Press.

The ski outlook for the Christmas period continues to be on the cheerful side, late reports from the Northlands indicated yesterday. In many areas, where there isn't sufficient snow to allow the entire use of all facilities, there's the knowledge that a solid base prevails and only a few inches of white precipitation will permit the running of these trails and slopes.
A second Thursday communique, as transmitted by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, Near Echternach, Dec. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- The threat from the northeast to Luxembourg City that developed swiftly last Saturday morning seemed definitely to have subsided today as American defenders rallied quickly from their initial surprise.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- The Oklahoma City, second light cruiser of the Cleveland class to be sent this month from the Philadelphia Navy Yard to join the United States Fleet, was commissioned this afternoon in the presence of more than 200 guests, most of whom came from Oklahoma City for the occasion.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 22 -- Overseas combat veterans are streaming into the Hotel Dennis today, rubbing their eyes at the luxury of civilian appointments and service after their months in barracks and foxholes. The first group of arrivals marks the opening of the Army Ground and Service Forces Redistribution Station here, established for the reclassification and reassignment of combat veterans of those two branches of the service.

HEADQUARTERS OF 21ST BOMBER COMMAND, Saipan, Saturday, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- Only a few crews got glimpses of the target. The majority of the crews reported that Nagoya was completely overcast, making observation of bombing results impossible.

There is one way of spending a pleasantly relaxed half hour in an armchair after a fairly heavy Yuletide dinner. One might take in one hand the complete popular vote in the recent election as tabulated a few days ago by The Associated Press.
TULSA, Okla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- ''Holy smokes!" yelled Sgt. Joseph Waldt, "What a Christmas present!"

TRENTON, Dec. 23 -- Fifty-one individuals and a Hudson County service station have been indicted by a Federal grand jury here in a campaign against violations of gasoline rationing regulations in New Jersey. It was said at the United States Attorney's office today that additional indictments probably would be found not only in Trenton but also by grand juries sitting in Newark and Camden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Failure of the Office of Price Administration, through oversight, to consult with producers of live cattle, as required by law, forced abandonment today of plans to issue ceilings for cattle "on the hoof."
PARIS, Dec. 23 -- Three German parachutist spies, dressed in American uniforms, have been captured and executed a few miles behind the American lines, Supreme Headquarters announced today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Thomas W. Lamont's letter in THE TIMES of Nov. 19 states with great clarity the underlying facts relating to Germany's connection with war during the last eighty years; but does it state an effective remedy?
After asking no less than a hundred GI's over here in New Guinea "whom or what they were fighting," they all gave me the same answer, namely, either that -- Hitler or that -- Tojo, or both.

More scholarship grants were available in 1944 for recruiting and training social workers in American colleges than in any other previous year, according to a survey completed yesterday by the Family Welfare Association of America. The report, covering 228 member organizations in the United States and Canada, discloses that fifty family agencies in twenty States had available $114,360 for scholarship grants -- an increase of $40,565 over last year.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 23 -- Close to 5,000 Allied planes from Flying Fortresses and Lancasters down to Thunderbolts and Spitfires hacked and hammered at the Germans from armored spearheads to communications zones today while American infantry made the first move in the great counter-campaign in Belgium and Luxembourg, smashing into the southern flank of the German offensive east of Arlon.

Christmas came early to the dog and cat world yesterday as 300 yelping, squirming pets at the Humane Society's annual Christmas party received brilliant red and green sweaters, plaid blankets, harnesses and collars from a Santa Claus who, though female, doubted they would know the difference.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Sunday, Dec. 21 -- Liberators escorted by Philippines-based fighters started large-scale land-based air attacks on the enemy's Luzon airfields by destroying or damaging nearly a hundred Japanese

LAST summer thousands of men in the armed forces of the United States were saying to themselves, "Maybe we'll get home for Christmas." Even though that hope was never certain, it did shine for a while like a light on the horizon, and it threw the brightness of its possibility on the days between. But now, except for a very few, that hope has vanished.

SPORTS are just completing a third year as wartime diversion and, all things considered, have done well. Spectator interest was overwhelming and so was the quantity of folding money the fans took into all sports, particularly into horse racing, where the betting reached astronomical heights. Everything was perfect except for the quality of competition, which was slightly less than somewhat -- to use a Runyonesque phrase.

The Rhineland, now the field for battles that may decide this war, has been a battleground since the days of the Roman and the Teuton. For the past twenty-five years it has been one of Europe's many trouble spots -- a symbol in turn of the Versailles Treaty and of the Nazi attack on Versailles.

Battle maps are being drawn for the impending struggle between the smaller organized stock exchanges and the over-the-counter markets. The former now have evidence that trading costs the average customer from two to six times as much over the counter as it does on an auction market.

Hitting the lowest mark for an American League leader since 1908, Lou Boudreau, manager and shortstop of the Indians, won the batting championship with an average of .327, just 1 point below Luke Appling's 1943 winning mark.

THE interesting thing about Katharine Brush's work has always been not so much what she says as how she says it. The four short novels in this book are about nothing special. But the Brush method is unique. The stories in an odd way resemble petit point tapestry; here are the same countless tiny background stitches building up a slender design.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Dec. 21 (Delayed) -- As Christmas nears, the minds of the American soldiers fighting the Battle of the Philippines are turning toward home but also in the direction of the American soldiers captured on Bataan and the American civilians who are still Japanese captives.

Twenty-five hundred children were guests yesterday at a Christmas party at the City Center Theatre, but the presents -- 5,000 pounds of warm clothing and canned foods -- went to youngsters in war-devastated countries in Europe. The party, which featured an hour entertainment by screen, radio and stage stars, was sponsored by Russian War Relief.

IN Italy the second volume of George Santayana's autobiography, "Persons and Places," is being copied for mailing to the United States. The publisher is listing it for spring. And there will be still another volume, after that.
