THE Deep Delta is the 115 miles or so of alluvial lowland along the Mississippi River between New Orleans and the Gulf. The river made it, and the river is still making it -- and taking it away. Because geological history is still being made here, because of the mixture of peoples inhabiting the section and because of events already transpired, the Deep Delta forms one of the most distinctive regions in the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The Germans claimed today that Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt's offensive was continuing to progress in the center, where on both sides of the River Gurthe, which the enemy crossed yesterday, the Germans were said to be pursuing beaten American formations.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Dec. 23 -- Four white swans swam on the Tappan Zee. One died suddenly, but still there were five swans breasting the water near here today, deepening the mystery surrounding the birds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- Tokyo reported today that three B-29 Superfortresses had flown over the main Japanese island of Honshu, one dropping explosive and fire bombs on Tokyo while another scouted Hong Kong, biggest naval base on the east China coast.
SOMEWHERE IN BELGIUM, Dec. 22 (Delayed) -- An open Christmas letter "to General Eisenhower and his brave warriors" was published in a local newspaper today.

When the National Child Labor Committee, meeting in Carnegie Hall in 1904, began its valiant crusade, the opposition said, "Child labor is good for children; it teaches them obedience, thrift and industry," and "Without the labor of children, they and their parents would starve."

Three thousand Jewish refugees from Rumania, Hungary, Poland, Greece and Spain entered Palestine in the six-week period between Nov. 1 and Dec. 15, it was announced yesterday by Dr. James G. Heller, national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, through the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine.

HAVANA, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Havana's Oriental Park reopened today for a seven-month, three-times-a-week horse-racing schedule with hopes that the quality of its meeting might be improved as a result of the request to close United States tracks within the next ten days.

" CONTINENTS END" is a very satisfactory addition to a series of regional anthologies which already includes a number of fine volumes. It is an unusual anthology, indeed, which presents so little with which one wishes to quarrel and which omits so little that one would like to see included.

THERE are some wounds that doctors cannot cure -- wounds to the spirit caused by curious or shuddering stares, prying questions, pity and misplaced solicitude. This type of wound concerns the staffs of our Army hospitals and convalescent centers because they see men who have been disabled leave for their convalescent furloughs with high hearts and eager spirits -- and all too often come back disheartened, pugnacious, or bitter.

Some vitamins may cost hundreds of dollars a pound. A few cents' worth a day of any one prescribed by a physician may spell the difference between health and sickness. But tons and tons of natural raw material must be handled in a pharmaceutical plant to obtain as much as a thimbleful of any vitamin.

SHALL the post-war home be streamlined or cozy? Shall it be, to quote one point of view, "as efficient as a Frigidaire and as cold" or, to quote the man in the other corner, "cute, drafty and dirty"? Or shall it be something in between? The other day we received a letter that seemed to be a good starting point for a debate on these questions:

THE connoisseurs of comedy have pointed out with a good measure of truth that radio humor this season has not been all it might be, but here and there on the dial are relatively new shows which quietly have been garnering their share of laughs and affording the dial twister a real surcease from the world's material worries.

ANY man, woman or child who works in the theatre and does not get out after -- I'll be generous and say five years -- is a hopeless gambler; in other words, an idiot. I am told there are gamblers who succeed consistently -- Nick the Greek, for instance. I am also told that salmon swim upstream, spawn their eggs and die. Anything can happen. Even to idiots.

Last-minute Christmas shoppers jammed stores last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Army and Navy Journal said today there had been a "clarification of the murky situation which contained possibilities of danger to the grand alliance." The unofficial but authoritative service publication, which has been critical of certain policies of Britain and Russia, added:...

The disclosure last week by an official of the Amtorg Trading Corporation, trading agency of the Soviet Union here, that invitations have been issued to a limited number of American manufacturers to participate in a permanent commercial exhibition in Moscow, raises anew speculation about what products Russia may seek in this market.

While Republican leaders throughout the country are not inclined to hold Gov. Thomas E. Dewey personally responsible for their party's defeat, the question of his position in the party has already been raised.

BURNS MANTLE issued the first of his now famous "Best Plays" series to cover the season of 1919-20. Possibly even he did not then guess that it would continue for so long or become, as it has, so valuable. But as the years passed the admirably planned and admirably executed record continued to appear annually.

THIS slim volume from England comes with a foreword by the Master of Balliol College, Oxford, Dr. A.D. Lindsay. "If we are going to have the least chance of bringing young Germans back to sanity after Germany is beaten," he writes, "we had better understand what made them insane."

LONDON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Col. Dave Schilling, who commands an ace fighter group in Europe, became the leading ace in the European theatre today by getting five German planes, making his total bagged thirty-four and a half--of which twenty-four and a half were in the air and ten on the ground.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Dec 23 -- More than anything that has happened since D-day, the German counter-offensive in Belgium and Luxembourg has revealed to the world the striking Dower and organizing ability which the Wehrmacht retains after five years and four months of war.

One of the star families to which eugenists always point with alarm and use as an argument for sterilization of the socially unfit are the "Kallikaks," brought to light by Dr. Henry H. Goddard in 1912. Kallikak is not the real name but a coinage of Goddard's -- a compound from Greek words meaning "good" and "bad."

SINCE the last previous round-up appeared in these columns, July 2 and July 9, books on art have been coming in at an accelerated pace. The pile is so high now that postponement until next summer would be sure to present difficulties. So herewith I am offering a parcel of comment on the volumes at hand.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23 -- The peonage system as applied to paroled convicts in Louisiana is on the way out. The recalling of three prisoners from a big dairy farm in up-State Louisiana, where they were found to be working ten to fourteen hours a day for 75 cents and to be otherwise mistreated, has crystallized sentiment to such an extent that the entire parole system may be revised.

BORN on a Missouri farm. Sam was not only a highly intelligent mule but one with a sense of humor. His mischievous tricks sometimes made trouble for 15year-old Elmer, but there was a deep affection between the two and Elmer grieved when Sam was auctioned off on Mule Day.

THERE is certainly no reason for doubting that "Situation Normal . . ." is, as it purports to be, a sort of field report, not originally intended for publication, from a young motion-picture writer, Arthur Miller, to his producer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Horse racing was banned indefinitely because of the war today when steps were taken by James F. Byrnes, director of War Mobilization and Reconversion, to close all the tracks by Jan. 3 to save labor and critical materials.

The Junior Assembly, pre-eminent subscription dance given annually in this city for debutantes of the season, took place last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, its locale for many years. The ball exemplified, as usual, the traditions of formality and exclusiveness established several decades ago when the assemblies were first organized as the Junior Cotillions by the late Mrs. Arthur Murray Dodge.

GRACE LIVINGSTON HILL dispenses romance and religion in equitable proportions in her stories of young people who seek to live the good life. When she plots their romantic flights God is her co-pilot. In "Time of the Singing of Birds" she poses the problem of the return of Lieut. Barney Vance, invalided home with honors, to face life without the mother who died while he was abroad.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- Notwithstanding the slight improvement in transportation during the current week, city people in France and especially Parisians are still resigned to a cheerless Christmas materially, although convinced that this is the last Feast of the Nativity under war conditions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- Serious setbacks on the western European front and difficulties of shopping in war-swollen centers dampened the Christmas spirit on the West Coast this week and caused more than the usual amount of grumbling, although some of it was directed at the Army order ending mass exclusion of persons of Japanese ancestry.

THE time was late morning on a day just before the opening of a great attack. The place was alongside a country road by an abandoned farmhouse well inside the Siegfried Line. Half hidden under trees behind the road were four little Piper Cubs such as one sees flitting over the German lines from the North Sea to the Vosges Mountains.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 23 -- The leaders of the Basque, Catalan and Galician parties here announced today the signing of a "pact of solidarity and alliance" to unify their efforts for the overthrow of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime and for the recognition of their independence as autonomous states within Spain after the expected re-establishment of the republic.

DETAILS regarding the Pan American Union's "Pan-Americanism in Postage Stamps" national contest for high school students were made available last week by Albert F. Kunze, chief of the Union's Philatelic Section at Washington.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 23 -- As might have been expected, two things dominate the Reich press these days -- the west front offensive and the statement attributed to President Roosevelt on the non-existence of a formally written Atlantic Charter. Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels naturally makes the most of both.

AROUND 1906 a boy from Missouri wrote the score for the junior operetta at Stanford University. Stanford undergraduates of that era don't remember much about the accomplishment, but it did something to the composer, Homer Curran.
PARIS, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Thousands of gallons of American gasoline intended for the Allies' war machines at the front are being hijacked daily and fed into the French black market.

Racetracks of New York and other Eastern seaboard States from Maryland to Massachusetts promised immediate compliance with yesterday's Government request that racing be halted, and Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York Racing Commission, said that the winning of the war was "our (racing's) only business."

HARDENING of the arteries can occur in more ways than the merely physical. It is something we have to guard against both in our intellectual and emotional reactions -- and, consequently, in our response to the books we read.
LONDON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

NOT without symbolic suggestion does the heart of Mexico beat in the shadow of volcanoes. For it is a land where strange violence in mankind and in nature seems to lie in ambush, where dire memories are rooted deep in racial consciousness.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in President Wilson's Cabinet during World War I, died seven years ago, but today a confidential episode reflecting his faith in humanity was related for the first time.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 22 -- Mexico's Federal budget for 1945 will amount to 1,004,000,000 pesos, 96,000,000 pesos less than in 1944, it was announced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Senators Carl A. Hatch of New Mexico and Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota, after an hour's conference with President Roosevelt on foreign policy, issued a statement today stressing the gravity of the international situation and the need for a "supreme effort" now to overcome Allied disunity.

Capt John J. Voll, leading ace of the Mediterranean-based Fifteenth Fighter Squadron, told yesterday of downing three German planes without firing a shot, maneuvering two so they collided and crashed and luring a third to crash into the ground.

THE annual Christmas exhibition at The Cloisters, imaginatively installed with appropriate setting of flowers and greenery, is called this year "Seven Joys of Our Lady." Seven paintings illustrating the joys -- works by fifteenth-century Italian painters -- have been borrowed from the John G. Johnson Collection of Philadelphia and these are supplemented with choice material from the medieval collection of The Cloisters and from the collections of the parent institution, the Metropolitan Museum.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23 -- Best Effort, owned by C.C. Tanner, came from behind today under top weight of 122 pounds to win the $2,500 added Ponchartrain Handicap, feature of the Fair Grounds inaugural card.

The public generally is heeding admonitions of the Office of Defense Transportation not to make long trips unless they are absolutely necessary, a check-up on holiday passenger traffic disclosed yesterday.

COBI was a yellow baby camel. Marching along by his mother in the caravan he watched Kaspar, the great white camel who led the caravan, admired him and began to wish that some day he, too might become white.
ROME, Dec. 23 -- Marcello Soleri, Treasury Minister announced the Italian budget for the first six months of 1945 today and, as anticipated, it does not offer much hope of a prosperous new year.

The thirty-third annual Christmas appeal for the Neediest Cases of New York closed its second week yesterday with a total of 7,408 contributors who have given $219,318.60, a splendid response in this troubled war year on the part of the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES to date.

To help disabled veterans determine and train for careers at which they are most likely to succeed, two veterans' advisement and training centers will soon be established in New Jersey by the United States Veterans Administration. The centers, which will be staffed by vocational advisers and training officers, will be located at Rutgers University and Newark College of Engineering.

WHEN Queen Victoria died in 1901 a state of mind died with her, and so did a book called "The Wide, Wide World," in which the curious preoccupations and evasions of the Victorian mind reach full flower. But Susan Warner's novel ranks with the best sellers of all time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Another of Navy's one-time football greats, Comdr. Frank Wick horst, is going to sea. The Navy Department said today that "Wick," tackle and captain of one of Annapolis' greatest elevens, 1926, had been assigned to carrier duty in the Pacific soon after the first of the year.

AN amateur jazz critic spoke his mind in the columns of THE TIMES last Sunday. And in the face of growing interest and relatively few signposts, whatever THE TIMES has to say about our music is important.

Like that mystifying hardy perennial of your suburban garden which seems to thrive better the more adverse conditions become, the field of sports emerges from its third war year with an extraordinarily gratifying record in its wake.

ROME, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Six hundred heavily-armed Carabinieri supported by light tanks surrounded the Roman suburb of Tormarancio during the night arrested some 200 Roman gangsters and seized large stores of arms, the Carabinieri command announced today.

ASECESSION movement has broken out in the ranks of Dublin's Abbey Theatre, the repercussions of which threaten to undermine that famous group. Our transocean scout reports that the position taken by the dissidents is that Abbey's directors, in their nationalistic efforts to Gaelicize the theatre, are working against its best Anglo-Irish traditions.

THE recipes on this page are for appropriate holiday beverages, each one contributed by an expert. For the most part they furnish a small number of servings, for with entertaining keyed to a wartime pitch gatherings are apt to be curtailed in size.
MONTREAL, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Canadiens maintained their margin at the top in the National Hockey League tonight when they beat the Black Hawks, 2 -- 1.

FOUR Army chaplains -- a Jewish rabbi, a Catholic priest and two Protestant ministers -- stood hand-in-hand on the deck of a sinking transport in the North Atlantic one bitter morning in the winter of 1942-43. Struck by a U-boat's torpedo, the ship was doomed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Virtually all point-free meats and canned vegetables will be back on the ration list by the start of the New Year, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Textile Workers Union of America, CIO, expressed scorn today at a suggestion of a fifty-five-cent hourly minimum wage in the textile industry, saying that it would fail to solve any of the problems cited by the union in its case before the War Labor Board.

Having attained a volume for the year which is outstanding in the history of merchandising, department store yard goods buyers are looking forward to 1945 with some misgivings but are still confident that there will be sufficient cottons, rayons and woolens available to keep their volume equal to that of 1944 if not greater, according to textile men last week.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Huddersfield Town won the League North title today, Cardiff City captured the League West honors and Chelsea and Clyde were displaced as leaders of the League South and Scottish Southern divisions, respectively, as soccer teams began a rush Christmas week-end schedule.
ROME, Dec. 23 -- Pope Plus XII will celebrate the first of the traditional three Christmas masses in St. Peter's at midnight tomorrow.

THE premiere of the opera which Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d are making from Franz Molnar's "Liliom," is now predicated for next March. More than half of the score, combining song, speech and orchestral commentary, is complete.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A test of the prestige and effectiveness of the National War Labor Board as the wartime arbiter of labor disputes was provoked again this week by Montgomery Ward Co., for the second time in seven months.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle's Government has decided to continue until next September the subsidies of Catholic education that were instituted by the Vichy regime. Thus Catholics have won the first round in the renewed struggle between clericals and anti-clericals which has been gathering heat since the liberation.

Holdings of the Rockefeller family in the Colorado Fuel and Iron Company have been acquired by a Wall Street syndicate, according to The Associated Press, which yesterday issued the following statement as authorized by Charles Allen Jr., head of the New York investment house of that name:
MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- Something like a Yuletide spirit prevails here although neither Christmas nor New Year is a legal holiday in the U.S.S.R.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- A wide gap between the joint military and political planning of the three great powers was disclosed this week by divergencies of Allied policy that profoundly shook public faith in the future unity of the United Nations. The existence of this gap offers one explanation of how disagreements arose over the British methods in Greece and the Soviet attitude toward Poland.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 23 -- Retail butchers in New Jersey see little hope in Mayor La Guardia's plan in behalf of retail butchers in New York to obtain meat from wholesalers at ceiling prices.

THE, Doe family, father, mother Dottie and Bobbie, tired of a crowded apartment in the city, looked for a house in the country, but one was too large, one was too small, one too old, one too new. In short, the Does had to build their own.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- At daybreak on Jan. 3 an undersized man, carrying a knapsack and followed by a woman and two children, each with a disreputable looking bundle, will trudge through the gate of the Manzanar Relocation Center and take his stand at the side of the main road from the Owens Valley into Los Angeles.

PARIS (By Wireless) WITHIN a few months of her liberation France has risen from an abyss of defeat, humiliation and powerlessness to a mood of pride and self-respect and to the diplomatic position of a great power with which other powers have sought alliances.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Prices of grains fluctuated erratically today on the Board of Trade and showed an easy undertone as a whole. A Northwestern mill was on the selling side of May wheat, regarded as hedging against purchases of cash grain, but the new crop months received fair support from commission houses.

HONOLULU, Dec. 22 -- The failure of the United States Government to alleviate the housing shortage in Hawaii was crticized here today by The Honolulu Advertiser in a front page editorial accusing the Government, as well as Governor Stainback of callous indifference to a situation which was asserted to be seriously affecting the war effort.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 24 -- Russian troops, clamping a huge pincers on Budapest with renewed offensives northwest and southwest of the city, yesterday almost three-quarters encircled the besieged Hungarian capital. The enemy garrison's escape gap was narrowed from thirty-five to thirty miles.
In a sudden turn of fortune's wheel the Germans seized the initiative in the campaign in western Europe last week and demonstrated once again that nothing is certain in war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company filed today an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $60,000,000 of its general mortgage bonds, Series F. It will sell $58,890,000 of these bonds at competitive bidding and will use the proceeds and any other necessary funds to redeem by April 1, next, its $60,000,000 of forty-year 4 1/2 per cent gold debentures at 102 1/2 and accrued interest.

WITH the firm hand of winter laid upon the land, it seems impossible that there should still be flowers blooming in the garden. Yet where the Christmas rose is growing there are always blossoms in December.

MIDDLEBURGH, the Netherlands, Dec. 19 (Delayed) -- All the grief that war can bring to the home man has afflicted those of the patient Netherlanders on this island of Walcheren. Fire has been succeeded by water as the author of destruction and only modern science spares these people from the misery of another plague.

This note comes from a New Yorker, at present stationed in England. A short time ago I attended a symphonic concert at the Royal Albert Hall at which Dame Myra Hess played the Emperor Concerto. The purpose of this letter is not to state this fact, but to remark on the manner in which the rendition was given.

We are at the end of one of the worst weeks since the United States entered the war. At Pearl Harbor, in the Philippines, in Burma, Malaya and the Netherlands East Indies, in Rommel's advance to El Alamein, the United Nations forces were either surprised or they were overcome by the greater striking power of an enemy on the aggressive, or both situations were present.

FILM exhibition in France is rapidly approaching normalcy and only about 8 to 10 per cent of the 3,825 theatres in operation previous to the country's liberation last summer still remain closed, according to a report released today by the Office of War Information Overseas Motion Picture Bureau.

Alcoholics Anonymous, the organization devoting its efforts to the rehabilitation of persons addicted to excessive use of liquor, observed its tenth anniversary last night with the opening of its new clubhouse, 405 West Forty-first Street, and demonstrated that it is not necessary to be tipsy to have a good time.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- In the presence of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, Minister of Justice Francois de Menthon presided today over the annual assembly of the Council of State, which is approximately equivalent to the Supreme Court of the United States except in criminal matters.

America's role in the effort to shape a peaceful post-war world was under examination last week. HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 23 -- As a fitting climax to the successful 20-day meeting that ended at Gulfstream Park today, representatives of Mrs. Lottie Wolf, Detroit owner, ran first and third in the Maryland Purse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A revised edition of the buyers' guide for surplus property, publication of the Surplus War Property Administration, is now available at the Superintendent of Documents, and can be obtained for 10 cents, Mason Britton, successor to W.L. Clayton as head of the SWPA, announced today.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Tropical Park decided today to open a scheduled horse-race meeting Monday and operate until Jan. 3, when the Government has requested that all racing be suspended.

BELIEVE it or not, folks, but it's possible once more to make a down payment on a set of dishes simply by purchasing an admission to the movies. Well, if you can't do it in Brooklyn right away, just be patient for another little while.

HATPINS are making head lines after a thirty-year exile. Most are plain, but others, ablaze with sapphires or sequins, are glittering reminders of the gay Floradora days. Look at women's hats now and you'll find that every other hat has at least one hatpin thrust through; some have two or three.

BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Yale's long basketball losing string against Dartmouth, which measured twelve games since 1938, ended tonight when the Ells nullified the brilliant individual work of Freshman Ed Leede and gained a 45-42 victory in the feature event of the Boston Garden's second edition of its intercollegiate doubleheader program.

As diligent readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine we were disappointed to find that your article "Why College Girls Dress That Way" contained no mention of Skidmore College. This rankled particularly, since the accompanying photographs were, without any doubt, taken on the Skidmore campus.

ROME, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Canadian troops of the British Eighth Army, pushing ahead against strong opposition, have established a front more than five miles wide along the east bank of the Senio River Northeast of Faenza, while American troops have made local gains near Mount Belmonte, south of Bologna, Allied Headquarters announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A Lincoln Birthday speech here may give Thomas E. Dewey his first public opportunity since the election to keynote Republican views on home and foreign affairs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Only 500 hogs were on sale today, not enough to test market values, and prices were nominally steady. Compared with a week ago all weights of barrow and gilts were steady to 25 cents higher, sows were steady to up 10 cents. The week's top was $14.75. John F. O'Connell, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, will confer within a few days with representatives of the various segments of the wine and liquor industry to receive proposals for new legislation to be presented to the State Legislature when it convenes in Albany next month, it was learned last week.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- Mitchell bombers, manned by Marine pilots, attacked Japanese shipping with rocket projectiles in the Bonin and Volcano island groups Thursday in the fifteenth of the daily attacks on the chain of islets guarding the southern approaches to Japan, Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.
MILTON CROSS is a paradox. A trained singer, he talked his way into the Metropolitan Opera, where on Saturday afternoons he takes a leading part in the proceedings but has yet to sing a note.

Threatened with an upset in the first half, the City College basketball team assumed control in the second to administer a 74 -- 49 trouncing to Trinity College on the Beavers' court last night. The Hartford outfit showed surprising early strength, the first half ending with the Lavender leading by 31 to 30.

CHRISTMAS is a friendly time. It draws friends together in person and in spirit. It sends our thoughts to friends far away, forgotten, perhaps, through the busy year, and it brings their thoughts to us. At Christmas the blessed circle of friendship, with all that it means in comfort for the heart and strength for the soul, is, for once in the year, complete.

One of the teams the Rangers must beat out if they are to earn a place in the National Hockey League play-offs will oppose the Blueshirts at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Chicago Black Hawks, occupants of the loop cellar and regarded as the weakest sextet in the circuit, will exchange pokes and body cheeks with Frank Boucher's athletes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The American B-29 Superfortress, now entering its seventh month of longrange aerial operations against the Japanese homeland and occupied territories, has emerged as an instrument of definite and effectively proved value.

Manufacturers feel that merchandise in 1945 will be more difficult to obtain than in 1944 in almost all markets, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

At the request of its car bodies committee, THE NEW YORK TIMES, together with three other newspapers in the United States, has asked its readers to express their opinions, as to changes, if any, which should be made in the size of car bodies, seating arrangement, provisions for comfort, luggage space, trimmings, ornamentation, soundproofing, hardware, running boards, and so on.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Government invoked today its wartime powers over priority ratings and the allocation of materials in an effort to insure an adequate labor force in critical war labor areas.

MAJOR company production schedules for 1945 indicate that there will be a sharp increase in musicals. For the most part, however, the tune films will be of a new cinematic order. That is, there will be fewer musical comedies of "The Show Must Go On With the Understudy" order, garnered with lavish production numbers.

PARIS, Dec. 23 -- Rene Pleven, Minister of Finance, announced tonight a last-minute addition to the proceeds of the Liberation Loan, which closed on Wednesday evening, raising the total to "about 160,000,000,000 francs."

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Physicians reported today that "virus pneumonia" has been traced to pigeons and that infected birds in the United States may cause many cases not even recognized.

THEY gave the school play last Wednesday in the big room of the old schoolhouse, the room in which hot lunches are served during the winter and in which the ladies struggle with the library two afternoons a week. ERNEST Bloch's symphony "Israel" will be the major offering on this week's programs of the Philharmonic-Symphony, with Artur Rodzinski returning from a brief vacation to take over the podium. "Israel" was first performed in 1917 and has received several performances since then.

A MYNA bird, Pepe, was born with a halo. There seemed to be no getting rid of it, and as Pepe grew older it complicated his life, for it not only gave him an unsought for reputation for goodness, but by making him "different." caused him to lose all chance of enjoying himself with the foolish and mischievous myna birds of his own age.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion is the conduit through which all the energies that make up the home front of the war are governed and transmitted. Congress, of course, supplied the power that released these energies and the authority by which the OWMR correlates, controls, revises and regulates them. But its deputy in direct charge of all this is James F. Byrnes, Director of OWMR.

FOR many years now distinguished foreigners returning to Europe after a visit to New York City have been rather patronizing about American civilization. And to this, American apologists have murmured: "But New York is not America."

INSIDE a small cafe in a shell-torn town, not too far from the Siegfried Line, about a dozen dirty, bearded doughfoots were eating warmed-up rations and sipping some cheap champagne while listening to a short, fat corporal playing and humming dreamy, sentimental tunes on a battered piano.

Many buyers are scheduled to arrive in the wholesale markets here next month, but in face of steadily tightening supply conditions in apparel and fabric lines, the $64 question is how much merchandise will be available during the first quarter of next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The people have been supplied with essential fuel during the past year, and suffering from cold has been kept to a minimum, but the mines were unable to meet fully the unprecedented war demands of industry, Secretary Ickes stated today in a year-end review of the coal situation.

The Italians used to buy a thousand United States mules each year, put them to work in Ethiopia and then honor them by erecting a large, bronze monument in a park in Rome.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- Eastern and Western football stars raced through heavy workouts today in preparing for their big charity game here on New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The controversy which is swirling about the Alaskan policies of the Department of the Interior is raging over the fundamental question as to whether the people of Alaska -- all the people -- shall get a square deal.

Whether or not the "meat holiday" planned to begin on Tuesday is called off or not, it was indicated yesterday by representatives of the retail butchers that the housewife will be able to buy very little meat after that date if their recommendations to substitute a boycott instead against wholesalers selling above ceilings is approved by the butchers at a mass meeting this afternoon.

Exercises marking the promotion of thirty-three members of the Police Department to higher rank were held yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's office at City Hall. The Mayor yielded his chair to First Lieut. G. Frank Curran, 27 years old, of 2130 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, a former patrolman who lost his right arm in action with American troops in Italy last June.

The powerful Allied-controlled Luxembourg radio ended a mysterious four-day silence last night with an urgent warning to its listeners to ignore German broadcasts designed to stampede them into actions that would hinder Allied military counter-measures "now in progress" on the western front.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Adolf A. Berle is slated for appointment as Ambassador to Brazil, it was learned authoritatively today. He resigned as assistant Secretary of State in the recent Departmental shakeup.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 24 -- Nearly 100 Mosquitos of the Royal Air Force, many of them carrying two-ton bombs, attacked German railroad junctions a few miles northeast of Bonn and east of Coblenz last night. The targets were on main lines from central Germany to the area of the Nazis' attack.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Veterans Administration completed this week the ground rules for making loans to veterans under "the GI Bill of Rights." It issued the regulations covering credit guarantees to buy or establish small businesses. Rules have already been laid down for similar loans covering the purchase of homes or farms.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Greece and Poland together have created a kind of harmonic dissonance in British politics. Labor, on the left, distrusts the motives of the Government in allowing British troops to become embroiled in a Greek civil war to maintain Premier Papandreou in power.

PLEASANT entertainment along with a chapter of American history is offered on the weekly tours made by convalescent GI's through the historic buildings and famous gardens of old Williamsburg in Virginia.

A NEW approach to exercise in which one uses brain as well as muscle and which considers the individual's physical characteristics, personality and work is that of "physical re-education," as taught by Mrs. Carola H. Speads of this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The bill providing for post-war flood control projects of an estimated value of $1,000,000,000 has been signed by President Roosevelt with the understanding that nothing in it would jeopardize the creation of the proposed Missouri Valley Authority, it was announced today.

TONIGHT the children will hang their stockings, sing traditional carols, listen to "The Night Before Christmas," or in other ways share in the little ceremonies that belong to the family's tradition of Christmas Eve.
BOSTON, Dec. 23 -- A sizable increase in the number of women applying for war jobs within the last two weeks in New England is reported by the War Manpower Commission.

Christmas trade ended here last week, with record high sales volume maintained. Department stores had gains of 35 per cent or more for the week and from 18 to 20 per cent for the period from Dec. 1 to 24. Inventories were well under a year ago.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- New York State faces a possible revenue loss of $27,000,000 in 1945 as a result of the request by James F. Byrnes, War Mobilization Director, that all race tracks close by Jan. 3 and remain closed until war conditions permit their reopening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Representative Brooks of Louisiana said today that the House Military Committee would investigate what he called a "complete blackout" of news to American fighting men abroad.

KATHERINE DUNHAM, who has been touring with her company for the past year, will return for a three-week engagement at the Century Theatre on Tuesday evening. The program still bears the title of "Tropical Revue," as it did when it played its initial engagement of three months here last season, and many of the most successful numbers of that engagement will be repeated.

The Oratorio Society of New York, now in its seventy-second consecutive season, gave its 121st performance of Handel's "The Messiah" last night in Carnegie Hall before a large audience that stood during the singing of the "Hallelujah" chorus, and lingered long after the last note of the evening to express its appreciation in enthusiastic applause.

Tanned and several pounds heavier, President Roosevelt was back in the White House last week. He had just finished a three weeks' post-election vacation at the "Little White House" at Warm Springs, Ga. He had kept up with war reports and Congressional news, signing some seventy-five bills, vetoing a few during his absence from Washington.

MADRID, Dec. 23 -- While official Spain has been largely preoccupied during the past week with what has been termed "the foreign press offensive," it still has had time to contemplate seriously the international scene, particularly with respect to France. As yet there has been no official comment on the French-Russian accord, but there has been sufficient press coverage on communistic activities in France to indicate more than passing concern.

A new type of resinous coating material called "allyl starch" has been developed by Dr. Peter L. Nichols Jr. and Robert M. Hamilton of the Bureau of Agricultural Chemistry, Eastern Regional Laboratory. It looks like varnish, withstands high temperatures and the action of most chemicals and solvents, and can be made from sugars and starches of farm crops.

For the first time in medical history an entire island in the Pacific is being sprayed with DDT. Twenty-two hours after the first planes landed on the island a nearly invisible mist of a DDT solution was settling over mosquito-breeding mangrove swamps. The spray, a mixture of DDT in oil, kills every insect on contact.

St. John's conquered Puerto Rico, 41 -- 35, and De Paul overwhelmed L.I.U. by 74 -- 47 in last night's college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden, and though one of the two local quintets won, both lost prestige. It was a sorry night for the metropolitan teams, especially for Long Island, which many had been tabbing as the outstanding court combination in this area.

ATHENS, Dec. 23 -- The long- threatened attack by Greek Elas forces upon Gen. Napoleon Zervas and his right-wing Edes army, estimated at about 10,000, in Epirus, has developed and hostilities between the two main resistance groups have flared up anew.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 (AP) -- A Soviet extraordinary state commission investigating war crimes reported today that 700,000 persons, including an undetermined number of citizens of the United States and Britain, had been killed by the Germans in three camps in Lwow province, Poland.

OMAHA, Dec. 23 -- Reports reach the Middle West that large numbers of its people who went to work in the Kaiser shipyards and other Pacific Coast war industries have been leaving their jobs. Moreover, the uses are constantly increasing in number.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Philip Murray, CIO president, wrote an article for the Dec. 19 issue of "War and the Working Classes," official Soviet trade union organ, urging organized labor to guard the wartime coalition of the United States, Britain and Russia in the interest of a secure peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The first step in Congressional action on a peacetime compulsory military training program was taken this week when Chairman Andrew J. May, Democrat, of Kentucky, announced that a House committee expected to hold hearings on the subject early in the next Congress.

LONDON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Moscow announced tonight that a provisional Hungarian National Assembly had been elected in liberated parts of that country and had started work at Debrecen to establish a new provisional government that would cooperate with the United Nations.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Sunday, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A single C-47 transport dropped all the Eleventh Division paratroopers and equipment for the Leyte operation. Special parachute racks were built under the plane's body to carry the weight of mountain guns.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The value of non-lend-lease exports in November reached the high level of $283,000,000, which compared favorably with the pre-war level of commercial exports, while the major portion of the total of $1,186,000,000 of November exports was comprised of lend-lease goods, the Commerce Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today that its general index of basic commodity prices, based on the August, 1939, level, advanced from 182.4 on Dec. 15 to 182.9 on Dec. 22. The stock market extended yesterday its moderate recovery, but its strength proved to be meager as trading was reduced. Gains in selected stocks ruled at the close with the rails again in the lead. Business on the Stock Exchange was the smallest in a month and transfers of 529,850 shares, compared with the previous Saturday's turnover of 1,021,340 shares.

JUST in case anybody has a moment to spare from the Christmas Eve chores and would like to lay out an itinerary of Broadway filmgoing for this week, we are here on this holiday morning with a crisp shopping list in hand. ON Dec. 28 it will be seventy-five years since William F. Semple of Mount Vernon, Ohio, took out the first patent on chewing gum. He did not invent gum, nor was he the first to conceive of flavoring it; but, being an American, he was the first to attach property rights to the ageless human pastime of chewing -- and the gum business was born.

No year in the long history of the American Merchant Marine has produced such outstanding shipping achievements as have taken place in 1944, when, with the American merchant fleet at its largest in history, new records in the transportation of war cargo were set, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared yesterday.

OTTAWA, Dec. 23 -- The strength of the German attack and the heavy reverse inflicted on the American First Army during the past week have brought everyone in Canada sharply back from optimistic discussion of the post-war plans and querulous criticism of Prime Minister Churchill's and other policies to a grim realization that the war is not yet won.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Chinese troops, supported by American fighter planes, pressed their attack on the key railroad town of Hochih in Kwangsi Province from three sides tonight, the Chinese High Command announced.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Opening of the Tropical Park racing season tomorrow and the Orange Bowl football game on New Year's Day are key attractions here. Fishing, too, has a large following. Bridge fishing at Baker's haulover, Sunny Isles pier and other points continues good.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The International Red Cross at Geneva plans to broadcast Christmas greetings to the world's more than 3,000,000 war prisoners.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- Long-faced jockeys and trainers at Santa Anita race track, due to reopen next Saturday for its first meeting since Pearl Harbor, agreed tonight that a decision of track officials to call off the projected fifty-five-day meeting was the "only thing to do."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Advancement of the date for rationing five canned vegetables from the first of the new year to next Tuesday, a formal statement of the restoration of rationing on most meats, as of next Sunday, and a drastic cut in the amount of sugar to be released for home canning next year, were announced tonight by the Office of Price Administration.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Horse owners here apparently are going all out to wring a whole season's thrills -- and all the folding money possible -- out of the days of racing left them between Christmas Day and the Government's Jan. 3 deadline for race-track closing.

Carl yon Rundstedt's tanks and infantry swept through the Ardennes into towns and cities of Belgium that lie in the historic path of German aggression, I have found myself thinking of the little bookshop I visited in one of them just a short time ago, of an orphaned boy of 3 and the middle-aged married couple who had saved him from his parents' fate.

Your editorial of Dec. 22 calls the turn nicely on the universal panacea of large-scale public-works projects Everyone seems to think that simply building buildings and parks and monuments indiscriminately is the solution of all post-war unemployment problems. The effect on public debt and inflation and taxation seems to be swept away in the magic of this alleged cure. all.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 24 -- The mightiest tactical air assault of the war and a series of determined attacks by American troops have at least temporarily halted the German offensive in eastern Belgium.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Domestic demand for cash lard and rendered pork fat plus normal exports shipment is sufficient to absorb the bulk of the curent output of packers, resulting in little or no accumulation of supplies. Brokers say this accounts for the current light offerings for lend-lease and other Government operations.

Teachers of English, meeting at the annual gathering of the National Council of Teachers of English, were rightfully concerned over a tendency to reduce the time given to English instruction in many of the nation's 25,000 high schools. War experience has shown several weaknesses in our secondary school system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- A campaign to bring about better understanding of the possibilities and limitations of trade with Latin America will be opened at a luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania in New York on Jan. 10 to be attended by diplomatic representatives of the other American republics.

AN AMERICAN COMMAND POST, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- German Storm Troopers butchered at least ninety defenseless Belgian civilians -- old men, women and children -- in four battle-front towns during the past few days, it was revealed today.

A call to hope in God as "an essential virtue" necessary to the soul's salvation was sounded yesterday by the Very Rev. Thomas A. Barry, superior of the New York Apostolate, in an Advent Sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided in the sanctuary.

Whether bookmaking, long a target for the official wrath of Mayor La Guardia, will be sharply reduced in New York City and elsewhere as a result of the move to halt horse racing on Jan. 3 became a subject for divergent opinion yesterday.
Trailing by two goals at one stage, the New York Rangers managed to earn a tie in their National Hockey League game with the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden last night.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 20 (Delayed) -- The first session of the people's tribunals to judge former Deputies, Cabinet members and royal advisers started today in two separate courts.

Mayor La Guardia devoted his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall yesterday to a Christmas program that included a prayer for the safety of the city's sons on the battlefronts and a plea for a "God's peace" that will bring a happy future for the children of the world.

Although many persons think of God as dead, Christians are convinced that He is the only God that lives, and that He lives independently of whether man remembers Him or forgets Him, the Rev. Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell of Providence, R.I., said yesterday in a sermon at Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Once again the stock markets have demonstrated their ability to withstand bad news and the dangerous complexities of the foreign political situation. The pronounced lack of business during the past week can fairly be said to be due almost entirely to seasonal influences, while there has been no measurable recession of prices.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $50,353,585,226. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, discount bills and notes, as follows:
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- It was the night before Christmas in Paris and planes throbbed over the rooftops in the clear moonlight of the coldest night of the season.

ON THE FIFTH ARMY FRONT, Italy, Dec. 24 -- It snowed heavily here in the high Apennines beyond Futa Pass yesterday and today, so it looks like the post cards this Christmas Eve -- only it does not feel much like it.

The fifteen-story apartment house on a plot 162 by 105 feet at 235 West Seventy-sixth Street, northwest corner of Broadway, has been purchased by Max Citrin, operator, who was represented by Edward J. Grenier, attorney. It is assessed for $1,125,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A force of perhaps a half-hundred Superfortresses set off "heavy explosions in military installations" in the latest strike at Iwo, enemy island midway between Japan and Saipan, the Twentieth Air Force announced today.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Monday, Dec. 25 -- American land-based bombers were again over Manila on Saturday, when they destroyed an estimated twenty-five planes at Grace Park airfield. There was no Japanese interception.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, on the Western Front, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Walking Christmas trees and snowbanks provided a bizarre touch to bloody Christmas Eve fighting along the German bulge on the Allied front. Both were German efforts at camouflage and both failed.

ASHTABULA, Ohio Dec. 24 (AP) -- Because of the generosity of friends, neighbors and total strangers who read of her plight, 4-year-old Barbara Ann Rigo will have a chance this Christmas for one of the greatest of all gift -- normal sight.

Dressing for the boys is the specialty of the girls who attend the dances held at Delmonico's open house for officers seven nights a week. Except for Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays, when formal attire is requested, the rules are fairly flexible, some girls coming straight from the office in suits, but the trend is toward formal informality.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Tropical Park will stage its classiest inaugural program tomorrow -- to open its shortest horse race meeting.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 24 -- The spirit of Christmas is difficult to recapture on the sun-and-rain-drenched islands of the Pacific, but an effort has been made to make the holiday seem real to thousands of Americans.

P. Walker Morrison, Lazarus Joseph and Leon Leighton, trustees of Series B-K mortgage investments, have sold the six-story apartment building containing forty-eight suites at 227 Haven Avenue for cash over a first mortgage of $144,000 held by the Harlem Savings Bank.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- 'Twas the day before Christmas and all over Long Island Sound hardly a breath was stirring, but out on the water the inveterate dinghy sailors struggled through five races, Alton O'Brien winning three contests and compiling the top score of 93 points.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Monday, Dec. 25 (UP) -- A communique:

A jeep for Jackie, a don for Jane and 3,000 other gifts have been made at Mount Sinai Hospital to brighten this Christmas morning for every sick child in the wards, for each child treated in the clinics and for the children of all adult patients.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Twenty-four States are "ready to go" on $823,039,686 worth of post-war public works projects, the Council of State Governments reported today.

Up to this Christmas morning, the thirty-third for the Neediest Cases Fund, a total of 7,931 readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES have responded to the annual Christmas appeal in behalf of the most distressed men, women and children in the city with a generous, heart-warming flow of gifts that aggregate $231,231.89 to date.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS near St. Vith, Belgium, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Behind the dramatic fall of this small Belgian crossroads, whose vital highway network was denied to the Germans in a week of steady battling, lies a story of the heroism of a football star turned warrior.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, said today that the Sixth War Loan drive, which aimed at $14,000,000,000, had hit $20,360,000,000 and the figure was still going up.

Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande" and Mozart's "The Magic Flute" will be presented for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House in the sixth week, which begins next Monday. In "The Magic Flute" Mimi Benzell will make her debut as the Queen of the Night.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 24 -- One of the most telling single blows delivered by Allied air power today against the German counter-offensive was an attack by a twelve-plane squadron of P-47's of the Nineteenth Tactical Air Command led by Capt. Warren F. Woirol of Cincinnati, Ohio, on an enemy convoy of 300 gasoline trucks north of Echternach.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

" Sophie," which will be presented tonight at the Playhouse under the auspices of Meyer Davis and George Ross, introduces Katina Paxinou, Greek actress, in a contemporary comedy. Before gaining Hollywood fame for her memorable portrayal of Pilar in "For Whom the Bell Toils," Miss Paxinou had essayed only two Broadway appearances: "Elektra" (in Greek) in 1930, and in "Hedda Gabler" (in English) for a brief run early in 1942.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Fishing and hunting are precisely what the doctor ordered for the frayed nerves of returning war veterans, and a House group intends to see that the men get plenty of both.

CHICAGO, Dec 24 -- Shorts in December Rye on the Chicago Board of Trade were squeezed last week, the future soaring the permissible limit of 5 cents a bushel on Thursday to $1.16 1/2, where it closed, up 5 1/4 cents for the week.

The importance of maintaining good-will among the Allies as a means of achieving future world peace was emphasized yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. J. Valdeman Moldenhawer, the pastor, in his sermon at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.

Your recent editorial "The President on Research," which was based on President Roosevelt's letter to Dr. Vannevar Bush, director of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, presented very well the importance of continuing civilian and military research for the needs of national security.

CALAIS, Me., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Only a lighthouse keeper and his wife remain to observe Christmas on the lonely spot where the first recorded celebration of the Nativity on the North American Continent was held.

GUAM, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander of the Pacific Ocean areas, said today that "until we have bases close to the Japanese homeland, the tough part of the war will still be ahead of us."

Christmas night at Madison Square Garden will find another college basketball double-header, carrying on the holiday week court carnival. Brooklyn College versus Western Kentucky and N.Y.U. versus Tennessee is the Yuletide dish that awaits local followers of the sport and a near-capacity turnout would not be surprising tonight.

In honor of the 100th anniversary of their congregation, 100 children of the Religious School of Temple Emanu-El, ranging from 10 to 18 years old, held a special rededication service yesterday at the temple. With pupils of the Central Synagogue Religious School, they read prayers and presented a musical program before 500 guests.

At the recent annual convention of the National Farmers Union, Secretary of Agriculture Claude E. Wickard expressed conviction that the small-family farm will have a continuing important place in the nation's agricultural set-up. The Secretary said: "The small farm makes for fairer distribution of farm income, for better care of the soil, for better citizenship and for happier living."

Declaring that censorship is generally unpalatable to democratic peoples, the Rev. Dr. Allen E. Claxton, the pastor of the Broadway Temple-Washington Heights Methodist Church, 174th Street and Broadway, said in his sermon there yesterday morning that we prefer to know the best and the worst in the news.

There were reasons why Charles Dana Gibson was the most celebrated pen-and-ink artist of his time as well as a painter applauded by the critics of his later work. He was both a social satirist and the delineator of the spirit of an era. He even had a part in the creation of that spirit.

The somber overtones of war hung heavy over this Christmas Day as President Roosevelt led the nation yesterday in observances on the eve of the holiday festival. Reverently, the city approached the day with services in virtually all churches and the singing of carols. Mayor La Guardia turned his Sunday broadcast into a thirty-minute program of scripture reading and sacred song.

Savings by the general public in the 246 savings and loan associations in New York State increased $61,574,200, or 13.9 per cent, in the first eleven months of this year, it was announced yesterday by Z.V. Woodward, executive vice president of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

Judging from the response of children to the Know Your City broadcast series, sponsored by the City History Club and the Board of Education over WNYC, at least one generatiion of New Yorkers can contradict the statement that "only out-of-towners" have seen the city's sights.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- The German counter-offensive on the western front may turn into a "pyrrhic victory" for Germany, a Russian military commentator, Col. V. Kravtzoff, said today, pointing out that the advance had taken the Germans from the permanent West Wall fortifications to extremely vulnerable positions in Belgium and Luxembourg.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 25 -- Red Army troops in a twenty-five-mile breakthrough deep into enemy defenses west of Budapest, yesterday captured the outer key fortresses of Szekesfehervar and Bicske, cutting the main retreat routes from the Hungarian capital to Vienna and leaving the German garrison only a seventeen and one-half-mile-wide escape corridor.

With the 1944-45 ski season now in full swing, a survey of the changes and improvements made at the major ski centers in northeastern United States and Canada has revealed that all the principal areas will continue "carrying on" with the knowledge that a nation's foremost asset is its physical fitness.

The thought of peace on earth, good-will among men, may stab millions of hearts this year, as it did last year, and the year before that, and for too many years back, with its awful irony. But if the idea which Christmas represents had not come into the world we would not feel this irony, which is only another side of faith and hope.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- In Paris and other large urban centers, the registration of voters closed this evening in preparation for the local elections to be held next February.

To the many uncles, fathers and other men who do not find the traditional cigars under today's tree the Office of Price Administration offers the promise of a smokier New Year, with more of the popular-price brands and sizes due to reach retailers within the next few weeks.

Two hundred and fifty service men overseas have had their shopping problems simplified for them this Christmas by the Shopping Bureau of the Catholic Community Service Society, which has hurdled all sorts of obstacles in obtaining for their families and friends the often restricted items they have requested.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- In a message broadcast during the National Community Christmas Tree ceremonies at the White House this evening President Roosevelt proclaimed "the determination of right thinking people and nations that Christmases such as those that we have known in these wartime years" shall never come again.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Wheat sold at the highest price of the season last week, grain for December delivery advancing sharply on short covering to break the previous high established last January, and high protein hard winter and spring and the soft red winter varieties sold in the cash market at the Office of Price Administration ceiling.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- One cannot buy a dictionary in Paris. Pupils in schools are hard-pressed to find paper on which to write. What textbooks there are must be passed around from student to student.

From his sick bed in St. Luke's Hospital the Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, sent a Christmas blessing that was read at the midnight eucharist service last night and will be read again today at the 11 A.M. eucharist service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Allies "will carry on the war until the complete military defeat of Germany has been achieved; the longer the fight lasts the greater will be Germany's defeat and the more severe will be the peace," said Dr. Eduard Benes, President of Czechoslovakia, yesterday in a Christmas address to the Czech people.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24 James Dunn, who returns to the screen as Johnny Nolan in "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn," has been named by Twentieth Century-Fox for the lead of "Dancing Through," a story of New York taxi dance halls to be produced late next summer by George Jessel.

The Rovers had to fight to the bitter end to stave off the Washington Lions in the Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. Twice leading by a comfortable margin of three goals, the New York athletes, nevertheless, had all they could do to triumph, 8 to 7.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 24 -- With nearly all of their Army trainees gone and their Navy units curtailed and facing still sharper cuts America's colleges and universities now have an aggregate student attendance of about a third less than in the fall of 1939, the last normal peacetime year, Dr. Raymond Waiters, president of the University of Cincinnati, reported here tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 -- Lack of fresh incentive kept cotton futures on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange within narrow confines last week and net results were gains of 1 to 6 points after all active positions had fluctuated in the shortened week within a half dollar a bale.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- The Berlin radio asserted tonight that German forces along the northern flank of their counter-offensive area had undergone a "critical" twenty-four hours. While the situation now was said to be under German control, the enemy broadcast added that it was evident that the Allies were trying to cut the German salient free from its communications and supply centers.

Five new films, including one importation from Mexico, will open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

At the week's beginning, financial markets made little response to the strong German counterattack, with penetration into Belgium. Later in the week prices yielded, losing about 1 1/2 points from Monday's highest. Even so, prices remained throughout the week above the top level of July, and recovered at the week-end.

Making the last of six guest appearances as conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, George Szell yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall presented Mozart's piano concerto in D minor, Koechel 466, with Artur Schnable at the piano, and repeated Brahms' Fourth Symphony, in E minor, from last week's programs.
AN ALLIED BASE, Netherlands New Guinea, Dec. 24 -- A set of curious changes brought Irving Berlin, song-writer and director of "This Is the Army," to this base unheralded.

The "business holiday" of New York's retail meat dealers in protest against Office of Price Administration regulations is under way today, following the failure yesterday afternoon of trade leaders to persuade 3,000 butchers, at a disorderly meeting in Manhattan Center, to call off or postpone the shutdown.

KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- British troops on the Arakan front have occupied Donbaik, advancing within eight miles of clearing the Japanese from the entire western coast of the Mayu Peninsula, a Southeast Asia Command communique disclosed today.
PARIS, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Maj. Glenn Miller, director of the United States Air Force Band and a former orchestra leader, is missing on a flight from England to Paris, it was announced today.

Christmas cheer flashed around the country yesterday as special Yuletide "gifts" flowed from here to California, Alaska, Maine and points east, west, south and north, sent on their way by the simple expedient of lifting thousands of telephone receivers from their hooks and the words: "Operator, get me --."

ROME, Dec. 24 -- Pope Pius, in a Christmas message to the world, said today that he looked forward to a society where an international organization, with the power and consent of democracy-loving millions, would see that further aggression would be prevented.

Olsen and Johnson, who pyramided a vaudeville act into a corporate structure closely approximating United States Steel, are back in town again with the third edition of their personal affray. This one they call "Laffing Room Only," and to the accompaniment of guns, slapstick, audience participation and assorted noises and violence it opened Saturday evening at the Winter Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today the following changes in rationing point values (processed foods and butter point values are effective at 12:01 A.M., Tuesday, Dec. 26: all others are effective at 12:01 A.M., Sunday, Dec. 31.):

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The CIO expressed belief today the problem of workers leaving war plants for peacetime jobs "has been greatly overstressed." A study of the situation, published in the current issue of the CIO Economic Outlook, characterized the "exodus" of war workers to jobs with better long-range outlook as "fictional."

WALCHEREN, the Netherlands, Dec. 20 (Delayed) -- When three amphibious "ducks" lumbered up to a loading stage in Domburg yesterday to evacuate marooned families, one man was ready and waiting. All the rest had figured out excuses for not leaving or had gone underground as they had learned to do so well during the enemy occupation.
The sudden German drive into Belgium and the grueling fighting in the drenched jungles of the Philippines bring a new atmosphere and a new meaning to this Christmas.

In your editorial "Between the Lines" you pay fitting tribute to the four chaplains who went down on the Dorchester because they gave their lifebelts to soldiers. This week when General Somervell presented Distinguished Service Crosses to the relatives of the chaplains, I wish that he might also have made some mention of the man in command of that troopship, Capt. Hans Danielsen.

CHRISTMAS DAY, 1944, is the eighth consecutive anniversary of the birth of the Prince of Peace since the Japanese war lords launched their campaign for the subjugation of Asia, the sixth since the Germans applied the torch to the civilization of Europe, the fourth since the United States became engulfed in the maelstrom of the second World War.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 24 -- Output of raw steel last week was unchanged at 96.5 per cent of rated capacity. Indications were that the rate this week would not have the normal holiday slump. Because of urgent war demands upon the steel industry recently, extra effort is being made to produce steel.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 24 -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German propaganda Minister, broadcast tonight an appeal to Germany to celebrate the sixth war Christmas with "yet more unbounded faith in our Fuehrer," whose health, spirit and morale he said "had never been better."
Henri L. Bonnet, the new French Ambassador to the United States, arrived from Paris at La Guardia Field at 5:15 P.M. yesterday aboard a transatlantic plane of the Army Air Transport Command.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Richard K. Law, British Minister of State, who arrived in Washington last week to obtain shipping for carrying relief supplies to the liberated countries of Europe, starts his talks amid an awareness of the relationship between the physical well-being of peoples and their social and political stability.

On Christmas Eve, General Eisenhower's Supreme Headquarters was in the fortunate position of being able to issue the best Christmas tidings that could be expected at a moment when the forces of darkness that fight against everything for which this day stands have again broken out of their lair.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- This community's thirty-first Nativity pageant was enacted this evening on the sloping lawn of the Reformed Church on Pondfield Road, at the Civic Center, before an audience of 2,000.

The four-story building containing a store and three apartments at 277 Flatbush Avenue, in Brooklyn, was sold by the Brooklyn Savings Bank to Frank E. Sachtleben for cash over a purchase-money mortgage of $5,500 for ten years. It is assessed at $18,000 and was sold through Harold E. White, broker.
YPSILANTI, Mich., Dec. 24 -- An American Airlines flagship made a safe forced landing two miles southeast of Saline just before noon today after a midair collision with a light training plane.
LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique :

It is not merry on the fighting fronts, and not all our wishing can make it so. It is not too merry on the American outposts that almost ring the earth: in the snow of Alaska and the Aleutians, on tropic islands, on strange and lonesome coasts. Christmas is a season for home-coming, and it can't ever be at its merriest away from home.

American boys are finding God in the foxholes, and that is a splendid thing, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, the pastor, said yesterday morning in a sermon in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. But he added that those on the home front must see to it that when they come back they will find God in America.

LONDON Dec. 24 -- This is Britain's sixth wartime Christmas Eve. The hope that the war might be finished by now has given way to the prayer that it may be won, in Europe at least, by this time next year.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The Germans, who have been attacking southern England with their V-weapons since mid-June, have now extended their long-range bombing offensive to northern England as well, it was announced today.

BETHLEHEM, Monday, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The miracle of the ages was re-enacted in Bethlehem last night and symbolically a Babe was born again in the very grotto where nearly 2,000 years ago Christ was born.
CHERRY POINT, N.C., Dec. 24 -- The first women Marines to qualify for flight pay -- fourteen of them -- have been assigned to duty here as plane-crew personnel at the Marine air station.

Although professional sport appeared to find itself in a precarious position yesterday in the wake of War Mobilization Director James F. Byrnes' bombshell edict requesting the suspension of horse racing and a closer draft scrutiny of all other sport activities, sports leaders last night were still striving to bind a silver lining in a situation that loomed none too cheerful.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Britons whose horse and dog tracks have operated throughout the war, although on a rationed basis, were surprised yesterday to learn that racing parks would be closed in the United States.

The domestic cotton market was quiet last week, with prices holding within a narrow range. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 3 to 5 points.

ATHENS, Dec. 24 -- The position of the Edes forces of Gen. Napoleon Zervas in Epirus appears to have deteriorated to such an extent that he can no longer be expected to hold on to the mainland at all.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Dec. 24 -- A six-foot gum tree stood tonight in the square of a tiny Leyte village composed largely of nipa huts. Upon it were cotton balls and over its branches were looped colored strings. It was the GI's attempt at a Christmas tree.
ATHENS, Dec. 24 -- Gen. Napoleon Zervas, leader of the Edes troops (armed forces of the Rightist National Deomcratic Front), has been eliminated from the Greek political scene.

The strike of 450 pie and dark bread delivery salesmen, which caused a shortage of 420,000 pies on Christmas tables, appeared to have been settled yesterday as a result of a conference of representatives of employers and employes held at City Hall an the initiative of Mayor La Guardia.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 25 -- The sun shone yesterday and the greatest fleet of bombers ever assembled for a single operation -- more than 2,000 Flying Fortresses and Liberators of the United States Eighth Air Force -- went to the aid of American ground forces trying to beat back Nazi Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt's big counter-offensive in Belgium.

Stuart Chase, the economist pointing in a report for the Twentieth Century Fund to 400 organized lobbies in Washington, assert that the bitter battle between warring pressure groups menaces the economic welfare of the nation. "In the pressure group free-for-a holds the stage," he declares, "economic breakdown is not far away.

British children this Christmas morning may find oranges in their stockings at the hearth. The largest citrus shipment ever dispatched from Haifa -- 1,500,000 cases -- was on its way Londonward last week.

TOLEDO, Dec. 24 -- Mrs. Nina Housden, 33 years old, of Highland Park, Mich., who was held here by the police on suspicion of slaying her husband, Charles Housden, 36, a Greyhound bus driver operating from Bay City to Toledo, signed waiver papers today and, after an alleged confession that she slew her husband, was turned over to Highland Park police.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 24 (AP) -- A power-packed team of Northern all-stars dug in for heavy practice today, determined to even the score with the South in next Saturday's renewal of the annual Blue-Gray football classic.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 --Manufacturers with post-war aspirations in the home appliance field and old-line members of the industry have started vying in earnest for dealers to handle their lines of goods when post-war products begin to flow.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- The Minister of the Interior warned prefects today of a tendency among some Government officials to insert in their personal records exaggerated reports of the part that they may have played in the resistance movement.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- Race track operators in the nation's winter sports capital will carry on right up to the Government's deadline, and Tropical Park will open tomorrow before what is expected to be a record crowd of more than 10,000.

ATHENS, Dec. 25 -- Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden arrived here today to bring to bear the highest powers of the British Government in the Greek crisis and they immediately summoned leaders of the Left-Wing Elas forces to a conference of all political elements tomorrow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 25 -- Preston Sturges, who left Paramount a year ago to form California Pictures Corporation in partnership with Howard Hughes, will release his first two independently produced pictures through United Artists, according to an announcement by Gradwell Sears of the latter organization.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (AP) --Al Wellman's gelding Many Lands nipped the favored Brownie for a nose victory in the five-and-a-half furlong $2,500 added Christmas Handicap today.

ROME, Dec. 18 (Delayed) -- A unique pack-train is now in operation carrying clothing, medical supplies and powdered milk donated by the American Relief for Italy to remote mountain villages in the most devastated section of the liberated zone.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Red Wings took a 5-2 lead in the second period tonight, hung on to beat Toronto for the fourth time this season, 6 -- 4, and moved within a single point of the National Hockey League leading Canadiens. A holiday throng of 10,907 fans watched the game.
