THINKING about the Germans (and who has not almost daily for a decade?), one always returns to the same dead end. Part of the German madness is easily explainable. The young soldier doesn't know any better, his mind and character have been corrupted by the world's greatest masters of corruption. But men seek in vain for an explanation that will apply to the Germans who were mature in 1933 and who consequently should know better.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- "Escape" periods awarded to plants where maintenance of membership had already operated a year or more have resulted in "negligible" losses in union membership, according to a survey made by the Bureau of Labor Statistics for the War Labor Board.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Tuesday, Dec. 26 -- Japanese losses on Leyte total 113,221, of whom 54,338 are counted dead, and Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita has suffered "perhaps the greatest defeat in the military annals of the Japanese Army," Gen. Douglas MacArthur declared today.

Thousands of men, women and children, briefly putting aside thoughts of the hatred and suffering tied up with a world at war, flocked to churches throughout the city yesterday to celebrate in song and prayer the birth of Christ.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Communique 261:

LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Berlin radio said tonight that American forces in "great strength," with seasoned divisions from both the Third and Seventh Armies, went over to the attack on a broad front yesterday and advances had been scored up the Arlon-Bastogne road.

SOMEWHERE IN BELGIUM, Dec. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- The adjutant of an anti-aircraft automatic weapons battalion explained today how cooks, clerks and mechanics of his headquarters battery, pinch-hitting as infantrymen, had fought bravely in the front lines for seven days to help hold back German armor that had made a deep penetration of an American sector.

In wards wreathed with holly and crowded with visitors, wounded service men in hospitals in this area celebrated yesterday a Christmas merrier than many had believed possible. Not only the outward signs of the holiday -- gaily wrapped presents and tasty turkey dinners -- but also the warm, cheerful spirit of the season was everywhere evident.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Senate would announce its foreign policy principles in advance under a proposal sounded today by the four Senators who wrote the B2H2 resolution on international security.

IN THE STAVELOT SECTOR, Belgium, Dec. 25 -- Despite the intensity of the fighting in this narrow mountain pass not unlike the Adirondacks, both the Americans and Germans halted their fighting for short periods today and yesterday to watch the tremendous air show over their heads.

SPAGHETTI BOWL HEADQUARTERS, Italy, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The possible starting line-ups for the New Year's Day football game between the Fifth Army and the Twelfth Air Force, scheduled in the Spaghetti Bowl at an unannounced site, are filled with former college players.

Having been close to the Americans of Japanese ancestry, I have seen them taken from their homes and herded together in the relocation centers, objects of suspicion and distrust, scorned by thousands of their fellow-Americans. These people who helped build America, who worked shoulder to shoulder with Saxons, Danes, Norwegians, Swedes, French, Poles, Irish, Scotch and all the other peoples, came together here as free men to build this citadel of freedom.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 25 -- Swiss anti-aircraft guns shortly afternoon today downed an American Flying Fortress, killing two members of the crew. Six others were interned and one is missing.

Wives and mothers of service men overseas took the Army and Navy edict of "no cabled Christmas messages" in their stride, it was reported yesterday by executives at four leading cable companies. A Western Union official revealed that "a substantial number of good-will letters" had been received from women relatives of men at fighting fronts saying they "realized it was a war measure and that they were ready to abide by it."

Prince Bernhard, speaking as Commander in Chief to the Netherlands armed forces, praised yesterday the valor of Netherlands resistance fighters still in enemy-held territory as an inspiring example to their countrymen.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 25 -- German Panzer forces have resumed their offensive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- The Postoffice Department had the Christmas rush beaten again today, thanks largely to an estimated 150,000 women volunteer helpers and the fact that many people mailed early.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A series of stabbing attacks at Japanese supply lines northeast and northwest of enemy-held Kweilin, capital of Kwangsi Province, was announced tonight by the Chinese High Command.

The Czechoslovak State Prize for Literature for 1944 will be presented on Saturday to Prof. S. Harrison Thomson by Vladimir S. Hurban, Czechoslovak Ambassador to the United States. The award, for Professor Thomson's book, "Czechoslovakia in European History," was announced on Oct. 28,th country's Independence day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- A pledge that authorizations for low-cost garment programs will contain provisions insuring that merchants in small towns will be able to get such merchandise for men, women and children on a more equitable basis, is contained in a letter received by Representative Wright Patman of Texas, from J. A. Krug, Chairman of the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The Federal Children's Bureau, which on advice of medical experts is opposed to group care of children under two years of age, has helped to work out a successful foster family care system in San Diego, Bessie E. Trout, child care consultant who recently spent two months directing the project, reported here today.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 25 -- For the second time this month Pacific sea and air forces on Saturday battered the Japanese air base on Iwo Island, in the Volcanos, in a coordinated attack that came as a climax to seventeen straight days of neutralization raids by land-based bombers.
The German counter-offensive in the West will inevitably complicate Allied supply and replacement problems, some of them already serious.

The threat of the city's 10,000 retail butcher stores to close down for a "business holiday" in protest against what was termed a squeeze between unlimited livestock prices and fixed retail ceilings will reach the showdown stage today.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Instructed to hit "anything that moves" in the third straight day of sustained assaults against the German counter-offensive, some 4,000 Allied war planes yesterday knocked out 110 Nazi tanks and 1,022 motor vehicles, set fire to thirty towns and blasted sixteen transport centers behind enemy lines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Physical standards for military service have not been lowered, but this does not necessarily mean that 4-F professional athletes called up for re-examination would be again rejected.

The Dayton Rubber Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 60,000 shares of common stock, of which 50,000 shares will represent new financing by the company and the remainder a sale of holdings of J.A. MacMillan, chairman, and his wife.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Eugene Cardinal Tisserant said publicly in Paris the other day what he thought of the movement of liberation and of the new France in the making.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The pamphlet report for 1943 of the Baldwin Locomotive Works, is sued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $4,840,157 after charges, taxes and renegotiation settlement, equal after preferred dividend payments to $3.67 each on 1,274,152 shares of common stock outstanding.

It would appear that Germany has enjoyed the use of virtually as much raw steel capacity to devote to its western front for the three years since Pearl Harbor as have Great Britain and the United States, according to the latest appraisals of the military situation by the American Iron and Steel Institute and other authorities.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Through the darkness of central London holiday crowds moved in groups of twos and threes tonight instead of in a continuous stream of closely packed humanity. There were fewer people in the theatre district than on a normal week-end night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- In the midst of the gravest kind of news an odd but attractive item has made its way into the press for the second time in history. A majority of the Electoral College is about to materialize into a group of human beings and sit face to face with those who by its act are to be the next President and Vice President of the United States.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP) -- A big Christmas crowd gave racing a merry start on its last lap today by betting a record sum of $716,716 at Tropical Park's inaugural program.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Paced by All-America back Les Horvath of Ohio State, Eastern football stars had their best workout today preparatory to the East-West charity contest New Year's Day.

Major emphasis in the current meat crisis has been placed upon the unsatisfactory relationships between livestock prices and the fixed prices of meat at various stages of distribution. Practically all of the proposed solutions are designed to do something about these prices: either to fix livestock prices, to pay subsidies, or to raise retail ceilings.

FLORENCE, Italy, Dec. 23 (Delayed) -- More than four months after its liberation Florence is a very discontented city, facing a Christmas as bleak as the bitter weather now sweeping down the Arno Valley.

KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 25 (AP) -- British Fourteenth Army troops have pushed ten miles toward the town of Ye-u, only seventy miles northwest of Mandalay, in a Burma jungle advance against slight opposition, Southeast Asia Command Headquarters said today.
NEW YORK Carl A. Berendsen, the Minister from New Zealand, and Mrs. Berendsen have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington.

STRASBOURG, Dec. 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- This has become a city of borrowed light in the shadow of frontline war.

RKO's "None But the Lonely Heart" and the Army Air Forces' "Memphis Belle" were chosen the best drama and documentary films of the last year, respectively, in the nineteenth annual selection of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures.

There will be a record influx of buyers into the wholesale markets here after the turn of the year in view of the huge Government demands which will cut sharply into civilian supplies for the first half of next year, according to the market reports prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Additional supplies of dress shirts will be made available to store buyers after the first of the year, industry spokesmen said yesterday. Persistent inquiries for reorders due to extreme shortages in the dress shirt field undoubtedly have prompted producers to channel larger cutting-up operations to these numbers, with sports shirt supplies to become smaller as a result.

Reorganization in the leadership and direction of the American Zionist Emergency Council, headed jointly by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise and Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, was believed likely yesterday as a result of differences arising from the recent deferral by the Senate foreign relations committee of a resolution urging free entry of Jews into Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers Union, will present a demand for a general wage increase in excess of the Little Steel wage ceiling formula, which limits raises to 15 per cent above the January, 1941, level, at his first contract negotiation meeting with the coal operators here on March 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The NAM News says top Government officials expect Russia to withdraw from lend-lease at the and of pending commitments.

With a good sense of box office well as of taste, the operators the New York City Center Theatre have brought back for a week's engagement those superb performances, Paul Draper and Larry Adler, top dancer and harmonica player, respectively.

In contrast, during the entire period of the First World War the total Government purchase was less than seven billion board feet.

ROME, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A heavy Christmas snowfall carpeted the Italian front today, confining activity to probing stabs at enemy positions after heavy German artillery, mortar and machine-gun fire throughout the night.

The New York Herald Tribune and The New York Daily News reported yesterday that their charity funds had aided a larger number of persons during this holiday season than a year ago. The Herald Tribune conducts "The Tribune Fresh Air Fund" and The News operates "The Friend in Need Department."

WITH UNITED STATES LONGTOM GUNNERS, Before the Siegfried Line, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Four artillerymen solemnly inscribed their names on the 155-mm shells they sent smashing against the enemy lines today just as they did two Christmases ago when five campaigns lay ahead of them.

ALBANY, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Parents of newly born babies will be permitted to decide whether birth notices will be furnished to newspapers under a revised State Health Department birth certificate form for use outside New York City.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, in Belgium, Dec. 25 -- The message crackled in over the radio: "We're still holding out" -- and our relief units forgot their weariness this Christmas Day as they stumbled through the snow in a renewed drive to rescue the heroic defenders of Bastogne.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 25 -- An Army transport plane crashed in a heavily wooded section of the York Hills at 4:27 o'clock this morning, killing ten soldiers and injuring seventeen.

Eddie Condon, "featuring some of the greatest American musicians," drew a good-sized crowd to Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon for his Christmas jazz concert. All things considered, Mr. Condon gives about as good a jazz performance as is to be heard anywhere today.

ATHENS, Dec. 25 -- The Elas representatives will be invited to confer on the basis of the Elas' declared willingness to withdraw from the Athens area and to require its supporters in metropolitan districts to lay down their arms.

This being a year for families in the theatre, it was only natural that Rose C. Feld's stories about the Americanization of Sophie Halenczik should reach the stage. Last evening Meyer Davis and George Ross offered at the Playhouse a dramatization of the tales by Mr. Ross and their original authoress.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- From his fireside in the country, with the Queen and the two Princesses at his side, King George VI today broadcast his annual message of hope and confidence to his subjects scattered over the surface of the globe, here at home and in the Empire, who have been disturbed by the recent trend of military and political events.

Thirty-one chairmen of committees which will supervise and run the affairs of the Amateur Athletic Union during 1945 have been appointed by President Willard N. Greim of Denver, it was announced yesterday. Nine of the chairmen are new to the job.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, in Belgium, Dec. 25 -- A bright sun shone through a clear, cold sky today on one of the ugliest Christmases since the Prince of Peace came to this earth to bring good-will to men.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 25 -- Only a few days ago the temperature here reached 101 degrees, while in extreme northern Argentina it went as high as 117 degrees.

A movement is developing among business women's groups in the city to enable them to work more effectively for their mutual interests. WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- January allocations of tires for civilian passenger cars and for small buses and trucks were announced by the Office of Price Administration today and showed sharp reductions compared with December. The allocations fixed a quota for passenger car tires at 200,000 below the December level and for small buses and trucks at 64,000 below the December allotment.

U.S. 21ST BOMBER COMMAND, Saipan, Dec. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- A Superfortress was lost over Tokyo today, carrying two colonels, a major and nine others to almost certain death.

ROME Dec. 25 -- Because no Rome papers were published today, the ordinary Roman will have to wait until tomorrow to see how the Pope's message yesterday struck the editors of his particular party -- the press here being strictly political.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 26 -- The Red Army drove around to the western city limits of Budapest yesterday and in a fifteen-mile advance cut the last railway escape routes for the Nazis westward from the Hungarian capital, which was within nine miles of complete encirclement.
RYE, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- Thirty-four debutantes from communities in Westchester were feted tonight at the annual Westchester Cotillion held at the Apawamis Club here.

One hundred thousand "unusual" Christmas gifts were made by service men for their wives at club-houses of the United Service Organizations throughout the country, Mrs. Mary Tobias Dean, USO program specialist in arts and crafts, reported yesterday.

W.F. McGuinness, vice president and treasurer of the Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, announced last night that the company would make a payment of $500,000 today to the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, reducing its "V" loan obligations to $2,500,000.

The consensus of opinion among retailers in the New York area is that they must adopt a bold course in their buying plans, according to a survey by the United States Department of Commerce Field Service, released yesterday. In the study, "Retailers' Current Buying Policies in the New York Region," the department states that many retailers are following a wide-open buying policy and are making commitments whenever they can find a source to accept them.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- On the northern bank of the Danube River, Soviet troops of Marshal Malinovsky's Second Ukrainian Army in Czechoslovakia, which drove to within five miles of Parkan, opposite Esztergom, three days ago, were meeting violent counter-attacks by Nazi forces, evidently attempting to keep open the Esztergom highway bridge, Moscow reported last night.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP) -- There were no long faces among the wounded today at the United States Naval Hospital as they celebrated Christmas in the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Allied fliers rocked the Germans with a lightning one-two punch today as Britain-based heavy bombers and fighters lashed out at vital enemy supply lines and swarms of fighter-bombers and fighters based in France, Belgium and the Netherlands poured bombs and rockets on Nazi troops and armored vehicles in the third straight day of clear weather.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- House Republicans renewed today their suggestion that a food "czar" be appointed with almost unlimited authority over pricing and distribution.

Advertising allowances by manufacturers to department stores often make more enemies than friends in the long run, according to J.A. Spooner, vice president of Textron, Inc., manufacturers of apparel and accessories. When such allowances are made, he asserts, goods that should be bought primarily on their merit are taken too often because of the advertising allowance.

In a telegram from London, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 18, Mr. Kosanovich excepts to my letter of Dec. 9 by accusing me of misstatement and mystification concerning the radio broadcast attributed to him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A Pan-American Foreign Ministers' conference to discuss hemisphere problems may be held either immediately before or after a United Nations meeting, probably in March or April.

Financially "ruined" by the pilferings of his bookkeeper, awaiting trial as a "Lady Robin Hood," Oscar H. Gropper, head of a luggage goods concern at 695 Fifth Avenue, jumped to his death at 1:05 A.M. today from the bedroom of his suite on the ninth floor of the Hotel Blackstone, 50 East Fifty-eighth Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Because of an "urgent need" for hospital technicians, as well as specialists in many other fields, the Army will continue to recruit for the Women's Army Corps in 1945, the War Department said today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 25 -- A manhunt was under way today in central Arizona's Salt River valley and cactus-studded desert for nineteen German prisoners of war who were still at large after twenty-five of them, mostly officers, staged a mass break during a rainstorm yesterday.

One hundred years ago plus a few months Ralph Waldo Emerson addressed a public meeting in Concord in commemoration of what might well have been called a notable victory for the common man. It was the tenth anniversary of the emancipation of the Negroes in the British West Indies.

If you're planning to entertain over the new year week-end and are wondering how to cope with a party in the face of food and servant shortages, you might like to enlist the services of Daniel the Caterer, 223 East Fiftieth Street (PLaza 9-5941).

Total paper and paperboard production in this country in the second year following V-E Day will amount to 20,070,000 tons, an increase of 2,200,000 tons above the peak year of 1941, it is estimated by the paper division of the War Production Board.

Charles A. The annual Eastern junior and boys' indoor tennis championships got under way yesterday at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, with only one casualty among the seeded players in both groups.

HEADQUARTERS of 21ST BOMBER COMMAND, on Saipan, Marianas, Wednesday, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Superfortresses in their first month of operations against Japan from the Marianas Islands have dropped more than 3,000,000 pounds of bombs on Honshu, principal Japanese island, Brig. Gen. Haywood Hansell Jr. disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A meeting of Foreign Ministers of the American republics, except Argentina, to consider post-war problems is expected to be called within a few days. The announcement, it was authoritatively indicated today, will set the time and place.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Miss Noreen Haney of Greenwich, Conn., top-seeded when Miss Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, decided to abdicate her girls' national indoor tennis throne, today led a field of twelve competitors into the third round of the title play on Longwood's indoor courts.
Real estate bonds and savings and loan association deposits continued their upward trends in November, with each reaching a new peak.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The black market in meat arises from the fact that consumers, retailers and packers seem to want to confine their operations to the prime and choice cuts that constitute only a small fraction of the available supply, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, contended today.

Sixty-seven days after the first troops of the Sixth Army fought their way ashore at three places on Leyte Island, General MacArthur announces that, except for mopping up, the campaign for the island is ended successfully. The first phase of the battle for the Philippines is over.

Friends of the Neediest Cases Fund in distant lands and in communities and States far from New York -- Maine, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Tennessee, Florida, Alabama, Arkansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Texas and California -- sent contributions that were among 558 received yesterday.

Emperor Hirohito and the Premer, Gen. Kuniaki Koiso, joined yesterday in warning the Japanese people that the war situation was becoming more critical, according to Japanese domestic broadcasts recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- Allied warplanes, flying about 4,000 sorties with good weather over the Western Front again yesterday in the fight to break the backbone of the German counter-offensive, blasted Nazi communication lines, troops and tanks and ran their toll of destruction for four days to 598 German planes and 4,092 enemy vehicles, including 571 tanks and armored cars, and 785 railway cars.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- College athletics as well as professional sports will be hit by James F. Byrnes' crackdown on 4-F athletes.
PARIS, Dec. 26 -- It is generally agreed that the food situation in France has improved very little since the liberation, and the French want to know why.

The rallying power evident in the stock market before the holiday proved short-lived, as the list was buffeted about yesterday by a general wave of selling. Though the pressure was not severe, the market failed to attract sufficient support to overcome the effect of the liquidation.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 26 -- By unanimous vote, the Westchester Country Board of Supervisors awarded today to the North American Airport Corporation, affiliate of the Gulf Oil Company, a lease to operate the new $4,000,000 defense airport in Purchase until fifteen years after the war.

In keeping with its policy of sponsoring special courses when wartime food crises arise, the New York State Emergency Food Commission will hold on Jan. 4 two sessions for housewives on the preparation of plentiful types of fish and another pair of meetings on Jan. 11 on cooking without sugar, Mrs. Roger W. Straus, metropolitan area chairman, announced yesterday.

THERE is no substitute for literary talent, although numerous untalented writers seem to think so. Such qualities as good intentions, laborious industry, evangelical zeal and pugnacious convictions born of inadequate, information are of little use in the making of books. They do not make books important and neither do they make them interesting.

Holders of all outstanding dollar bonds of the United States of Brazil have been notified that the period for exercising the option of retaining their bonds, with reduced interest rates, or of accepting new 3 3/4 per cent external dollar bonds of 1944 of reduced principal amount, but with varying cash payments, has been extended from Dec. 31, 1944, through June 30, 1945.

Net earnings of the Burlington Mills Corporation for the fiscal year ended with September amounted to $3,934,939 after all charges and taxes, according to the annual report mailed yesterday to stockholders.

The ground black-pepper situation is the tightest it has been in years and present supplies will probably last only through 1945, according to trade interests yesterday. Grinders are operating with only 40 per cent of the pepper used in the corresponding quarter of 1941 to conserve the supplies.

ROME, Dec. 26 (AP) - Canadian, British and New Zealand troops moved forward toward the Senio River line on the Adriatic end of the Italian front today after Canadian troops had captured hotly contested Rossetta, ten miles northwest of Ravenna.

"Here Come the Waves," a comedy with music starring Bing Crosby, Betty Hutton and Sonny Tufts, which arrives at the Paramount, is this morning's film newcomer. The Paramount picture, which was produced and directed by Mark Sandrich, includes Ann Doran, Gwen Crawford, Catherine Craig and Noel Neill among its featured players.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Among 2,403 casualties announced today by the War Department, all based upon prior notification to next of kin, were the following in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

CINCINNATI, Dec. 26 (AP) -- William Grant Still of Los Angeles, Negro composer, won the $1,000 war bond offered in nation-wide competition for writing a jubilee overture celebrating the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra's fiftieth anniversary, was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 20: Increases of $235,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $873,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and decreases of $763,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 27 -- Paris, which had thought itself secure after years of terror, was bombed by German planes late last night in a brief raid that, it was announced, caused slight casualties and damage.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 26 -- The enemy has now committed to battle the German Fifth Panzer Army, including both the First and the Twelfth SS Panzer Divisions, the German Seventh Army, which is operating on the southern flank of the offensive, and possibly a second Panzer army.

The Army and Navy have issued imperative calls for more nurses -- 12,000 are needed; 2,000 of these should come from New York City. Where are these needed nurses? Are young women skilled and equipped, under 45 years of age, clinging to peacetime ways for one reason or another while their sister nurses have gone overseas or have accepted assignments in Army and Navy hospitals at home?

Plans for new public housing here to cost $260,000,000, designed to clear away vast areas of New York's slums and provide modern living quarters for at least 36,753 additional low-income families in the first three years after the war, have been drawn up by the New York City Housing Authority, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Rumors that the Navy is concealing losses sustained in the great battle of the Philippine Sea from Oct. 23 to 25 were sharply contradicted today by Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal, who asserted that all ship and plane combat losses had been announced, and that the defeat inflicted on the Japanese Navy had been indeed devastating, both physically and strategically.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 26 -- Jules Levey has signed Randolph-Scott to be starred in "The Homesteaders," one of the two pictures the producer will make for United Artists during 1945. The film, for which a screen play is being written by Tom Reed, is to be based on the Ernest Haycox novel "Trail Town."

ROME, Dec. 26 -- All signs point to some form of rapprochement between France and Italy, which still are technically at war and, save for the presence here of Maurice Couve de Murville as French member of the Allied Advisory Council for Italy, are not represented in each other's capitals.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Payments made by the Tennessee Valley Authority to State and local taxing bodies in lieu of taxes, from which this Federal agency is exempt, represent "a reasonable cost of the power program" and should be continued, the TVA said in a report to Congress today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today the American Power and Light Company's request for an order declaring its sale of the Nebraska Power Company's common stock to be a step in compliance with provisions of the Holding Company Act.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES on Western Front, 7:50 P.M., Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Giant fleets of C-47 cargo planes skimmed over the snowy Ardennes hills today to drop supplies to American troops still fighting inside the Bastogne pocket in eastern Belgium.

The mighty battle in Belgium and Luxembourg is rapidly approaching its climax, and the next few days must show whether a great victory can still be gained or whether we have suffered a grievous defeat. This climactic phase of the battle, it now appears, will be fought out along the Meuse, that river of destiny whose murky waters have been tinged with the blood of many conflicts.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

KANDY, Ceylon, Wednesday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- British planes, operating from aircraft carriers, attacked Japanese objectives in Sumatra on the morning of Dec. 20, scoring direct hits on jetties, warehouses and railyards, a special Southeast Asia Command Headquarters communique said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Present ration values for canned fruits will remain in effect until 12:01 A.M. Sunday, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 -J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, declared here today that it was now operating on the theory that the war would go on indefinitely and that industry must find the men to increase present war production of $5,500,000,000 a month.

TORONTO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Dominion officials said today they would study the United States order directing horse and dog tracks to close by Jan. 3, but disclosed that provincial authorities and racing associations would be involved in any decision.
Increased tightness in knitting yarns for hosiery will force many manufacturers to resort to black-market purchases in the first quarter of 1945, it was predicted yesterday in the trade.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- Andre Diethelm, French Minister of War, gave the Consultative Assembly, at a secret session this afternoon, frank information, which, it is understood, was calculated to dampen the ardor of delegates who have been demanding immediate mobilization of the nation's manpower, armament for additional units of the French Forces of the Interior to reinforce the French First Army, and a dynamic expansion of French production of arms.
More than 360 persons met violent death, chiefly accidental, throughout the nation over the Christmas week-end, surveys by The Associated Press and United Press showed last night.

The commonest complaint about the average bathroom is that it is not equipped to handle morning rush hour traffic when every one in the family is trying to get up and off to school or work at once, Egmont Arens, industrial designer, said in an interview yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 26 -- Bomb-carrying P-51's of the United States Fourteenth Air Force attacked the Tsinan airfield in Shantung Province Christmas Eve and destroyed thirty-seven Japanese fighters on the ground and one in air combat, a communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The War Production Board placed additional restrictions today over the use of cotton yarns in another move to increase production of cotton tentage to the level required by the armed services.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Kentucky's unbeaten basketball team scored its sixth victory tonight, outlasting Wyoming, 50 -- 46, at Memorial Auditorium. In the second game of the twin bill Puerto Rico beat Canisius, 40 to 37, after leading at the half, 24 -- 13.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A strike of all members of the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes union in Montgomery Ward's retail stores and mail order houses in this city has been called for tomorrow, Edward Chevlin, international representative of the CIO union announced tonight.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- The County Trust Company of this city, which has assets of $40,000,000 and offices in six Westchester communities, announced details today of a plan reported last week for transferring control of the institution from the Bank of the Manhattan Company, owner of 23,600 of its 30,000 shares of stock.

To help meet an increased consumer demand for fish expected to develop as a result of the city's meat situation, wholesale fish dealers advised Mayor La Guardia at a conference in City Hall yesterday that they were assigning ten vessels to off-shore fishing in Chesapeake Bay.

The 131 member banks of the Savings Banks Association of New York State have increased their deposits by a total of $1,348,212,283 and their accounts by a total of 413,000 through a two and one-half year advertising campaign based on the anti-inflationary themes, "In time of war... save for peace," and "Buy war bonds from income instead of savings," it was revealed yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Steel plants in the United States have broken all records for steel output in each of the five years since World War II began, producing an estimated 89,400,000 tons in 1944, Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, reported yesterday. This output was 80 per cent above the maximum output in World War I, he said.

While textile exporters deprecated an announcement by the Foreign Economic Administration that applications for priority ratings by exporters will receive the same treatment as those submitted by foreign purchasing missions, "general line" exporters endorsed yesterday the statement of policy as one which will "encourage the return of trading to private channels."
WITH THE UNITED STATES FIRST ARMY, Dec. 26 -- A special German task force infiltrated behind the American lines in an attempt to kill the American First Army leaders, it now can be disclosed.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 26 -- German armored spearheads have smashed deeper into Belgium reaching on Christmas morning the village of Celles, four miles to the southeast, and Ciney, eight miles northeast of Dinant, on the Meuse River.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. has presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art an outstanding series of ten eighteenth century Gobelin tapestries, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board has joined the fight, to overcome the manpower shortage and increase arms production by stating that it would approve or order up to 10 cents an hour wage increases above minimum bracket rates in foundries certified as requiring such action.

A people who govern themselves are soon steeped in the tradition of the precious value of self-government. They would never seek to impose on others that which they would violently resist themselves. Hence, they would never tolerate a decision by their leaders to become aggressors against another people.

Allied headquarters announced yesterday that the German offensive, still rolling into Belgium on its eleventh day, had forged a solid salient thirty-five miles wide and fifty miles deep, the tip of which had reached within some four miles of the Meuse, near Dinant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Declaring the cattle industry "thumbs its nose" at Government food control. Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, said today he would ask the new Congress to impose price ceilings on live cattle.

Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College, made a strong point in his recent letter on peacetime compulsory universal military training when he stated that before Congress adopts such a measure the proposal "deserves considerably more study than it has yet received."

MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 26 -- President Leonard Carmichael of Tufts College announced today the appointment of Dr. Robert B. Stewart of the State Department, Washington, as dean of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy. He will assume his duties in March.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Butler Brothers announced today that they had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Philadelphia an amendment to their registration statement listing thirty-one underwriters of their proposed issue of 100,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock, 4 1/2 per cent series.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Docdonough, an almost overlooked gelding from the Christopher T. Chenery barn, provided a big thrill for a comparative few in the crowd of 5,543 at Tropical Park today when he took the Black River Purse and paid $219.20 for $2, longest price of the Florida winter season.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the Consolidated Electric and Gas Company's sale of its holdings in two subsidiaries, the Bangor (Pa.) Gas Company and the Citizens Gas Company, Stroudsburg, Pa., for $250,000 to John H. Ware 3d, Oxford, Pa.

Women blood donors should include in their diets larger quantities of meat, milk and other foods rich in animal protein than they generally do, according to three research specialists at the University of Nebraska.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- When Red Cross Christmas packages failed to reach one front-line hospital in Alsace, France, on time, Army nurses and Red Cross workers supplied a present wrapped in Christmas paper to each patient, Dorothy Sutherland, Nurse Corps correspondent, reported in a dispatch to the Army Nurse Corps headquarters here.

While profit limitation, through measures of taxation and regulation of maximum earnings, plus added production costs and rigid sales prices, will reduce profits next year as against 1944, the rate of earnings generally will be satisfactory, Harry H. Heimann said yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 26 -- Conversations going on during the past fortnight between the Bonomi Government and Comte de Murville, French representative on the Allied Advisory Commission for Italy, have advanced to a point where it is expected that diplomatic relations between the two countries will be resumed shortly after the first of the year.

The Harriet Monroe Poetry Prize of $500 awarded by the University of Chicago has been won by Marianne Moore. Miss Moore's latest book of poetry, "Nevertheless," was recently published by Macmillan. The only other American to receive the prize is Muriel Rukeyser.

Further cuts in the allocation of new tires for civilian passenger cars and small trucks for February and March were forecast yesterday by Harry M. Williams, president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York. He did not believe there would be new tires for A gasoline book holders until October or November of 1945, at the earliest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- As the nursing shortage on the European battlefront grows, Gertrude Banfield, American Red Cross recruiting officer, asked civilians at home today to boycott nurses who are classified as "available" for military service but refuse to volunteer.

The official okay was placed upon Morris Reif, East Side welterweight, and Danny Bartfield, Brooklyn, yesterday by the State Athletic Commission. All that remains now for the ring rivals who are to meet Friday night in the ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden is to maintain the physical peak they have attained through intensive training.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 -- Failure to collect enough signatures blocked a plan of The Women of the Pacific, a group of Southern California women, to obtain legislative action early next year on an initiative measure outlawing the closed shop and regulating labor unions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- President Roosevelt has accepted the recommendation of the Armed Forces Committee on Post-War Educational Opportunities for service personnel that it be discharged, as the basic legislative framework to govern this program for returning veterans was completed by the enactment of the "GI Bill of Rights."
LONDON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- A German communique, as broadcast from, Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Katherine Dunham brought her company back to town last night for a three-week engagement at the Century Theatre in her so-called "Tropical Revue." As that part of the public knows which kept her playing it here for some three months last season, it consists almost entirely of dancing with a bit of singing and drumming thrown in for good measure.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 27 -- Superfortresses of the Twenty-first Bomber Command, flying from bases on Saipan Island, bombed industrial targets at Tokyo in a daylight attack today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- For the month ended Nov. 30 the War Department 1,476 conreleased tracts from one type of production and settled 1,623 accumulated contracts for types of production no longer needed, it announced today.

The New Jersey Fish and Game Commission appears ready to tackle the predator problem in a big way. Its program includes the hiring of professional hunters and trappers to devote their entire time to destroying foxes, weasels, skunks and other creatures considered harmful to game.
ROME, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

Post-war building projects in the nation for which plans are drawn, financing arranged and all details completed in preparation for bids amout to $452,938,000, according to figures supplied to the committee on post-war construction of the American Society of Civil Engineers by Engineering News-Record.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A peppery exchange of correspondence between William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Harry A. Millis, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, was disclosed today, revealing a deep split over issues decided by the board in the Western Union-Postal Telegraph Company cases.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 26 -- American Red Cross officials and United States Army spokesmen say that wives and children of American service men here awaiting transportation to the United States are not suffering great hardship.

The Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices advanced fractionally last week to a new high level of 114.24. Rather pronounced activity in agricultural raw materials was solely responsible for the rise.

Fifteen million dollars' worth of miscellaneous apparel for use by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration will be purchased by the Treasury Department, Procurement Division, it was announced yesterday.

Preliminary statistics for the current year reveal that New York Central stock, with a gain of 7 1/8 points on a turnover of 3,439,600 shares up until yesterday, topped all other issues on the Stock Exchange by a sizable margin as the most active security.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- The success or failure of Prime Minister Churchill's journey to Athens may have a considerable effect on the trend of domestic politics as well as on Britain's relations with her Allies, especially Russia.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 132 against 522 last week and 271 in the similar period of 1943, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were fourteen arrivals yesterday compared with 131 last Tuesday.

PASSAIC, N. J., Dec. 26 -- Michael Slavik, 23 years old, of 296 Gregory Avenue, an Army veteran who served with distinction overseas, holder of the Purple Heart, Silver Star and a Presidential citation, was arrested in Passaic Street early today for a New York City hold-up.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Nazi prisoners worked many months boring through rock a 200-foot tunnel through which twenty-five Germans escaped from the Papago Park Camp this week-end, Col. William A. Holden, commandant, said today.

A syndicate represented by Herbert A. Cone has resold the four-story business building at 567 Seventh Avenue, near Fortieth Street to a client of Carstens Linnekin, through Rossbach Associates, brokers. A five-year extension of a first mortgage of $62,500 was arranged in connection with the resale.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES IN BELGIUM, Dec. 26 (AP) -- In general, the northern Allied flank is being held, forcing the German commander even farther west in his efforts to turn north against Liege and Antwerp, while in the south American armor and infantry made steady progress toward Bastogne.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (Canadian press) -- Arsenal had an open date in today's Boxing Day football schedule but its players took the field as guests with other elevens and helped to win three games in the League South.

No true democrat doubts ultimate victory over the most formidable enemy of freedom that ever attempted to dominate the world, but only the continuous united efforts of all the peoples who really care to insure a brighter future for their descendants are likely to make this victory an overwhelming one.
A second communique, as transmitted Monday in Serbo-Croat by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Agency and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed unchanged to 3 points lower than on Friday.

Directors of the National City Bank of New York voted yesterday to increase the dividend with the declaration of 65 cents a share, payable on Feb. 1. Previously stockholders received semi-annual payments of 50 cents in February and August.

Direct radio voice transmission from Leyte, Philippine Islands, through the 400-watt Press Wireless Station there has been started for the American networks, E. N. Dotson, manager of the Pacific Division of the company, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- If war comes again, modern science may cause events to move so swiftly that we will not have time to train an army and navy, James Forrestal, Secretary of the Navy, declared today in reiterating his approval for universal military training of young American men.

The Atlas Corporation announced yesterday the acquisition of the principal interest in a syndicate which owns shares in a radio station in the international zone of Tangier, North Africa, and in a company which plans to install and operate other stations in many parts of the French colonial empire.

An official license to shiver was issued to New Yorkers by the Weather Bureau yesterday in the form of a forecast that a cold wave moving from the Middle West might depress temperatures during the night to 15 degrees in the city and to 5 above zero in the suburbs.

The resumption of rationing for several major foods has followed closely upon the unfavorable news from the Western Front. Tighter rationing was made necessary by several developments: (1) Military demands have increased both in Europe and in the Pacific.

One of the big thrills of the early basketball season was provided at Madison Square Garden, where, on opening night, Larry Pearlstein, Brooklyn College substitute, heaved a fifty-five-foot field goal for the Kingsmen, the ball swishing through the net simultaneously with the half-time buzzer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Secretary Stettinius said today that the United States is working on a new lend-lease protocol with Russia and that war supplies have continued to move meanwhile.

Warning that unless consumer and investor safeguards are substantially strengthened now, the American public will be vulnerable to an "avalanche" of rackets and frauds after the war, H.J. Kenner, general manager of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, announced yesterday the bureau plans to expands its facilities during the next year to cope with the situation.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A communique:

EL CENTRO, Calif., Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Barbara Frankish was notified today that her husband, United Press War Correspondent Jack Frankish, had been killed Saturday on the Western Front. He was 30 years old.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- An immediate Allied invasion of Norway from the west as a means of breaking Adolf Hitler's power in the north and saving the country from total destruction was urged tonight by Johann Nygaardsvold, Norwegian Prime Minister.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Crisp weather today gave Blue and Gray football coaches a respite from wilting temperatures of the past week and speeded training preparations for the Saturday's North-South game. Both squads concentrated on light running and passing plays.

Our cultural relations with Japan seem almost as bad as our military ones. Here comes the Japanese Publicity Association, for example, with a song for mass singing entitled, "A Tune for Throwing Out the Anglo-Americans." The idea is understandable, but such a title wouldn't get to first base in this country, even if it were changed to "A Tune for Throwing Out the Japanese."

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- A dispatch from London on Sunday, saying that Ambassador Rene Massigli had arrived there from Paris, bearing a French proposal for a defensive alliance with Britain, was denied in authorized quarters here today and by a statement circulated by the French news agency.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP) -The Elastic Stop Nut Corporation of America, Union, N.J., disclosed today in amendments to its registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a net loss of about $3,166,000 in liquidation of inventories in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Alied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Communique 262:

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Wednesday, Dec. 27 -- The Japanese are making an all-out but fruitless effort to protect the key Manila airports from daily American bombings. In a Christmas battle thirty-nine of fifty enemy fighters were shot down by Lightnings with four more probably downed.

Miami, Fla., will be in the market on Jan. 10 with $10,000,000 of new bonds for which bidders are to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent. The offering will consist of $7,500,000 of water revenue refunding bonds and $2,500,000 of water revenue bonds. Dated Dec. 1, 1944, the bonds will mature on Dec. 1, 1945 to 1974.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Two current events connected with the war against the Axis nations serve to illustrate two facts that have heavily burdened the American civil and military machinery.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 26 -- A force of enemy aircraft, presumably based on battered Iwo in the Volcano Islands, attacked the big Superfortress base on Saipan Sunday night and did some damage before the planes were dispersed and driven off.

IN THE STAVELOT SECTOR, Belgium, Dec. 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- There is a feeling that the tide of battle has turned in this sector after eight days of desperate fighting. The Allied Air Forces delivered a stupendous attack today that left the roads strewn with wrecked German tanks.

The Rangers, who in three attempts this season have failed to bring down the Maple Leafs, will make another try tonight at Madison Square Garden, when the rival sextets clash in a National Hockey League encounter.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Aggressive buying of rye futures headed by a house with Eastern connections and followed by professional traders and commission houses lifted prices around 2 1/2 cents a bushel at one time today on the Board of Trade to the highest level since late in October.

NEAR STAVELOT, Belgium, Dec. 25 (AP) (Delayed) -- A 30-year-old major who spent more than seventy-two hours as a prisoner of a trapped German armored force told today how 800 Nazi survivors sneaked out of an American encirclement after abandoning and blowing up more than 100 of their own tanks and vehicles.

Everybody agrees that the German counter-offensive owes its big initial gains to the element of surprise. Normally, that should mean only one thing. The German High Command hit our invading armies at an unexpected point in an unexpected moment and with unexpected force.

Nearly everything about the feats of the Tiger pitching twins, Paul (Dizzy) Trout and Hal Newhouser, became known to fans during the stretch drive for the pennant, but only now is it revealed, with release of official figures, that Dizzy topped the American League with the low earned run average of 2.12, which also was lowest in the majors.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- An agent of the Polish Lublin Committee is coming to France, while an "observer" of the French Government is going to Lublin, it was learned today. The belief in informed quarters here is that the British have asked Moscow to postpone until after the next meeting of the Big Three its contemplated recognition of the Lublin Committee as the Provisional Government of Poland.

Stabilization of employment in the furniture industry during the past several months has resulted in manufacturers being able to maintain production thus far this year at a rate only 4 per cent under that of 1943, it was declared yesterday by Seidman Seidman, accountants.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Great Britain informed this Government in advance of the trip of Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to Greece, Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr. said today.

The "business holiday" that kept from 35 to 75 per cent of the retail meat shops in this city closed yesterday will be over in a few days, Mayor La Guardia said last night, promising that increased shipments of meat, at ceiling prices, would arrive here today.

"Sing Out, Sweet Land!" the Theatre Guild's second presentation of the season, will have its premiere tonight at the International. First-nighters are warned that the curtain will go up at 8:15 on the button. Woven into the fabric of the show, written by Walter Kerr and first tested at the Catholic University, Washington, D.C., are representative songs which have emerged since the Colonial period.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Holiday lethargy still overhung the stock markets here today and trading was listless. However, the general tone of the market was steady to better, although the lack of interest was reflected in a slight decline in gilt-edge securities.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES Dee. 27 -- Jack Frankish of The United Press, one of the ablest and best liked war correspondents in this theatre, was killed in an attack by German planes on a village near the front where correspondents stayed overnight.

The one-story "taxpayer" at 1127-1129 De Kalk Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Ferdinand Harms, Joseph J. Struhart and David A. Davis to Rose Grabino. Sale was subject to a mortgage of $14,625. The property is assessed at $28,000. J.D.H. Bergen Son and Jack Riker were the brokers. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Opening the public schools for the first time to all-day nurseries for the children of working mothers, the Board of Education yesterday approved a resolution permitting the establishment of a nursery in an annex of the Newtown High School by the Mayor's Committee on the Wartime Care of Children.

ATHENS, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- The conference had been on the verge of collapsing because three parties' representatives had rejected settlement terms submitted by the Left Wing Eam [National Liberation Front]. Then it agreed unanimously on forming a regency, though a small minority had favored postponing immediate action.

The New York City Housing Authority has just opened up another vista into the post-war period. Plans are being made for sixteen new Federally-aided projects, for eleven other projects to be financed through State housing loan funds and for some additions to existing projects.

The City Council adopted yesterday, by a vote of 12 to 2 with two members not voting, the capital budget of $196,181,844, recently approved by the Board of Estimate. The vote followed three hours of debate during which charges of illegality, deceit and "politics" were hurled at Mayor La Guardia and the City Planning Commission.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey made public today an exchange of letters with Herbert Bayard Swope in which the latter submitted his resignation as chairman of the State Racing Commission and the Governor accepted, with regret.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- Red Army troops, battling through Budapest's streets in house-to-house fighting with crack Nazi forces who were under orders to make a "Stalingrad" stand, yesterday smashed to within two miles of the city's center and split its fanatical defenders into two groups.

It is the right time of the year to quote Charles Dickens. That is why the new Selective Service ruling on 4-F athletes, professional and amateur, sends the mind back to Capt. Ned Cuttle in "Dombey and Son."

LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Aerial photos taken in the last four days show that the northern German rail system has been disrupted by Allied strategic bombings and the southern routes are packed with shunted rolling stock in quantities never before equaled, the United States Strategic Air Force in Europe announced today.

Officials of several city departments have begun a study of the effect of the new and stricter zoning regulations on municipal postwar projects, with the prospect that "quite a few" plans in some important structural classifications under New York's $933,000,000 program will have to be revised to comply with the amended restrictions, it was learned yesterday.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, Dec. 27 -- The pretty village of Pafenondroy, five miles southwest of Malmedy, which with its straggling gray houses and snow-covered fir trees must have looked like a Christmas card before the Nazis struck it, has provided one of the grisliest atrocity incidents of this war -- if one can call mass murder an incident.

A truce until Jan. 10 was declared last night in the "business holiday" of New York City's meat retailers after a day of bitter complaints by dealers and housewives that the extra meat that Mayor La Guardia had promised would be shipped here had not arrived.

WITH AMERICAN TROOPS ON THE SIEGFRIED LINE, Dec. 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Thirty American Medical Corps men, caught in a street battle for a small town, said today that they had hidden for twelve hours in a church and listened to German E'ite Guard and armored troops outside shoot captured American drivers of trucks and jeeps.

Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, who resigned last week as a leader of the American Zionist Emergency Council, said last night that although his decision on this point was irrevocable, he would remain as a member of the council and would devote himself even more fully to the cause for which he has been working.

An increase of eighty-seven tons over last week in yesterday's collection of waste paper by Department of Sanitation trucks was not good enough, in the opinion of Deputy Commissioner William J. Powell, who complimented those New Yorkers who saved and baled wrappings from all their Christmas presents but insisted that "if everybody had done his or her wartime duty, we should have salvaged at least 600 tons of paper this week."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Estimates of election officials put the service vote in the recent Presidential race at 2,800,000.

New York City's Department of Parks opened its 491st playground late yesterday afternoon in a densely populated part of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, at Monroe Street and Sumner Avenue. Both Mayor La Guardia and Borough President John Cashmore emphasized that the playground was a vital need of the neighborhood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The United Fruit Company, steamship operators, has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to withdraw its application for air routes between New Orleans and Caribbean places.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Vice President Wallace called for a national job budget tonight along the lines recommended in the Murray Full-Employment Bill. He spoke before the American Statistical Association.

CORAL GABLES Fla., Dec 27 (AP) -- Racing fans who had seen three jockeys figure in a recent spectacular spill at Gulfstream Park witnessed a similar sight at Tropical Park today when another trio of riders went down during a jam just before the big field rounded into the stretch in the fourth race.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A bondholders' committee submitted today to the Interstate Commerce Commission a reorganization plan for the Wisconsin Central Railway Company calling for a reduction in capitalization of $37,305,880. The committee represents holders of the carrier's first general mortgage fifty-year 4 per cent bonds, due July 1, 1949.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The successes gained by the Germans in their winter offensive on the Western Front were due to complete failure of the Allied military intelligence, Gen. Peyton C. March, United States Army Chief of Staff during World War I, said today.

Horsemen who will be stranded in distant parts of the country as a result of the shutdown of race tracks next week will be aided by the thirty-three member tracks of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, according to a statement from that body yesterday.

Thirty-two members of the Republican State Committee to represent the sixteen Assembly Districts in New York County established by reapportionment were elected last night at meetings of county committee members. The list follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The need for Army nurses, critical since September, was put in strongest terms today by Basil O'Connor, chairman of the American Red Cross, in telegrams to all chapters asking their help in enlisting public cooperation in recruiting 10,000 military nurses.
ROME, Dec. 27 -- The Serchio quiescent of the Italian front, has flared up as the Germans have taken the initiative, according to today's headquarters analysis.

Cotton flannel producers will be permitted to raise prices 6 1/2 per cent under an order to be issued probably within a week by the Office of Price Administration, but with no provision made as yet for the increase to be "passed along" by work-shirt manufacturers, it was learned yesterday.

As I read your pessimistic editorial "Poland's Frontier," I feel low in spirits. It is a sad day for Americans when we have come via Britain to the point where we are ready to counsel another free people to submit to tyranny as their only choice. Shades of our forefathers, will they ever forgive us? I fear not.

Notwithstanding the grim business of war, boxing promoters throughout the country had more talent from which to draw this year than had been at their disposal in more than a decade. To the number of 4,382, boxers were active.

The invasion of Luzon, which now seems to be impending, will represent the accomplishment of one of our war objectives in the Pacific, but it should not blind us to the fact that it will bring us only slightly closer to Japan.

Holders of first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1965, of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company have been notified that $10,000 of these bonds has been drawn for redemption on Feb. 1 at 101 at the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustee.

Deploring the present attempts of Great Britain and Russia to play "power politics" and develop "spheres of influence" in Europe as jeopardizing post-war organization of a peaceful world, John L. Childs, State chairman of the Liberal party, and Alex Rose, chairman of its administrative committee, made public yesterday a statement of the party on the international situation.

Brooklyn College triumphed twice yesterday as the Intercollegiate Chess League tournament for the Harold M. Phillips Trophy opened at the Manhattan Chess Club. Both Columbia and Cooper Union were defeated, 2 -- 1, by the Brooklynites.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Use of lead in civilian production in 1945 was ordered reduced by the War Production Board today an estimated 15 to 20 per cent below current usage in a move reflecting a combination of critically short supplies and mounting demands by the armed services.

Mayor La Guardia made a fifteen-minute tour of the Fulton Fish Market yesterday and then urged New Yorkers to eat more frozen fish, which, he said, was plentiful, cheap, and "just as fresh as any fish can be."

ROME, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The American air command in Italy, seeking close liaison with Russian military forces that would enable hundreds of Fifteenth Air Force heavy bombers to be employed with maximum effectiveness against the common enemy, has apparently achieved no tangible results thus far in its overtures.

Since numerous butcher shops in the metropolitan area are closed, and may remain so for at least the rest of the week, meatless dinners are apparently in store for many of us. In view of that fact, suggestions for substitutes seem indicated once more, and so we present the following recipes, all but one of which are entirely meatless.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- The State Senate Committee on Taxation, headed by Senator William Bewley, is making a study of the State tax system with a view to changes in fiscal policy.

Sale of the entire common stock of the Nebraska Power Company by its parent, the American Power and Light Company, to a Nebraska nonprofit corporation was completed yesterday at the agreed purchase price of $14,421,000. Financing of the transaction was arranged by a group of investment bankers headed by John Nuveen Co. of Chicago and B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., of this city.

New York City was pictured yesterday in a report prepared by the regional office of the War Relocation Authority as an area in which 60,000 Japanese being resettled nationally could find excellent jobs and business opportunities and a not unfriendly population.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Harry Bridges, Pacific coast labor leader, carried to the Supreme Court today his long fight for revocation of an order to deport him to his native Australia.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- With clear weather today all Allied Air Forces in Western Europe joined again in a full-scale attack on von Rundstedt's assault armies and their rearward communications, sending more than 3,000 planes across the front lines to bomb and strafe everything from farmhouses to rail centers.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 27 -- Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla told the writer today that a special meeting of foreign ministers of all the American Republics that are "united or associated" in the war against the Axis was scheduled for February.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- A new committee will meet here on Friday for the first time. Its duty will be to recommend to the French Government how to fit the alliance with Russia into the security scheme outlined at Dumbarton Oaks.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Grain markets were firm early today on the Board of Trade, but there was a lack of outside interest and wheat, oats and rye declined around 1 cent a bushel from the top on local pressure. A rally late in the session on short covering wiped out much of the loss.

RUSSELL BRINES of The Associated Press is a young man, reckoned in years. He was born in Denver in 1911. But not much of his carefree youth has withstood his contact with Asia. He went through the fall of Manila.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Allied Supreme Headquarters in Paris confirmed Brussels and Luxembourg radio flashes that the American garrison of the Belgian town of Bastogne, which had been encircled and under attack since Dec. 20, had been relieved and the siege raised.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Dr. Neston Evans testified today in the Charles Chaplain paternity trial that from blood-grouping tests he concluded that the actor could not be the father of Joan Berry's baby.

A pair of tall basketball teams will be seen at Madison Square Garden tonight, although not against each other. Hamline University and the University of Wyoming are the towering quintets that have come to town to do battle against a pair of normal sized local aggregations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The President last week angrily and scornfully denounced "columnists" as a group, excluding Mrs. Roosevelt, however -- when a reporter (the occasion was a White House press conference) reminded him that she writes a press "column," too -- by saying she is only a diarist.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- Replying in the Consultative Assembly today to an attack on a member of his Cabinet, Gen. Charles de Gaulle deprecated the tendency to rake up the errors committed by members of Parliament in Vichy in 1940. He also, in effect, denied the Assembly's the right to challenge the composition of his Cabinet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The United States and Great Britain have asked Russia to explain the removal of a certain amount of equipment from the Rumanian oil fields to Russia, it was learned today.

ABOARD THE SEVENTH FLEET FLAGSHIP, Thursday, Dec. 28 -- Without interference by the United States Third Fleet or Seventh Fleet, but constantly attacked by land-based American bombers, a Japanese naval task force attacked our Mindoro positions Tuesday night but withdrew before dawn yesterday with some loss and considerable damage.

Early in 1942, while the wreckage of the battleships in Pearl Harbor still was being cleared away, Lieut. Bill Ewing of the Fourteenth Naval District Staff in Honolulu gathered some information on a newly authorized naval construction corps which he gave to the correspondents covering naval operations.

Declaring that the Army had no "excess" stocks of food, Maj. Gen. Carl A. Hardigg, chief of the subsistence department, Office of the Quartermaster General, warned last night that end of the war in Europe would not diminish Army purchases of fresh provisions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Navy communique 562:

Two dealers in cotton cloth, accused of evading Office of Price Administration regulations, were fined and sentenced to jail terms yesterday by Judge Edward A. Conger in Federal court. Both had pleaded guilty to charges in criminal informations filed by United States Attorney John E.X. McGohey on Oct. 31.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today a request by the Kansas Power and Light Company, Topeka, for an order declaring its sale of the water plant and distribution system serving Hutchinson, Kan., a necessary step in the integration or simplification of a holding company system.

Having contributed to the nation some potentially lasting songs of its own -- cf. "Oklahoma!" -- the Theatre Guild now has set out to look at the earlier record. From the songs of America, those rising from the people as well as those handed down by Tin Pan Alley, it has fashioned a cavalcade of the country's tunes called "Sing Out, Sweet Land."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Authorization to the Maritime Commission to proceed immediately with the construction of 166 dry-cargo ships and twenty tankers for delivery during the last half of next year was granted today by James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization and Reconversion, after conferences with Vice Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator and chairman of the commission.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- David Lloyd George, who led Britain's victorious fight against the Kaiser's Germany a generation ago and instituted a bold program of domestic reform afterward, has decided to yield the seat he has held continuously in the House of Commons for fifty-four years to a younger man who, he hopes, will be a member of the Liberal party, like himself.

GRAND VIEW, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Five white swans, which have made friends with the residents of the Westchester and Rockland County villages along the Tappan Zee, refused to be lured into traps today and are passing the night in a blinding snowstorm.
ATHENS, Dec. 27 -- The Greek political leaders' conference agreed unanimously tonight on the establishment of a regency under Archbishop Damaskinos Of Greece.

Two five-story apartment houses on a plot 50 by 102 feet at 114-16 West Eighty-fourth Street was sold by an estate to Jourmire Silverman, operator. Assessed at $54,000, the property contains seventeen apartments and was sold through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.

American textile products will comprise after the war a greater part of Sweden's imports than ever before, Goran Holmquist, general manager of Nordiska Kompaniet, one of Stockholm's largest department stores, declared yesterday. American men's wear and women's apparel, he explained, have gained positions formerly held by London and Continental exporters.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Communique 263:

A heavy snowfall that started out to blanket the city and its environs last evening was being washed away well before midnight, as rain, which had been predicted for later, began pouring down ahead of schedule.

After holding within a 3-point range all day, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with net gains of 2 to 5 points. Steadiness prevailed throughout the day. A few fixations against sales of spot cotton to Spain were reported, offset in part by small liquidating orders.

Thomas M. Cook Co. of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Churchill, Sims Co. of this city received yesterday the award of $1,000,000 of construction bonds of the Port of West Palm Beach, Fla., on a bid of 100.03 for 2 3/4s. The bonds will mature on July 1, 1959 to 1966.

A surge of giving in the Christmas spirit of sharing with those who are less fortunate brought 722 gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to help lighten the burdens of the most distressed families and individuals in the city known to seven leading private charity organizations.
" Going My Way," Paramount production co-starring Bing Crosby and Barry Fitzgerald, is the New York Film Critics' selection as the year's best picture, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A United Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

Lippincott announces a sixth printing of Gwethalyn Graham's "Earth and High Heaven," still high on fiction best-seller lists. The new printing brings the total number of copies printed to 540,000, including those distributed by the Literary Guild.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The National Football League studied the rosters of its players tonight and pondered the possibility Government "work or fight" orders and Selective Service directives might force suspension of activities next year.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 27 -- For the third time this month Pacific Fleet warships yesterday bombarded Iwo Island, Japanese air base in the Volcano Island group, which has been under air attack almost daily for more than a month.

In a statement on operations of the American Distilling Company for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, Russell R. Brown, president, informed stockholders yesterday that the net income from operations amounted to $1,981,797 and earnings after all charges but before taxes were $2,048,582.

According to your correspondent Joseph M. Levy, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 25, Nikolai Mushanoff and two other outstanding Bulgarian democrats, Athanase Buroff and Dimitri Ghitcheff, are now being tried by Bulgarian courts as "war criminals."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A leveling off of the country's economic activity during 1944 was indicated today by the Department of Commerce in its preliminary estimates that national income and national product for this year would reach $159,000,000,000 and $197,000,000,000 respectively, an increase of only 5 per cent over 1943, compared with a rise of 23 per cent from 1942 to 1943.

Educational, benevolent and social institutions share largely in the estate of Sherman Day, retired lawyer, who died on Dec. 18, it was learned yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

ROME, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The American infantryman on the Fifth Army front is "both the proudest and bitterest man in the Army," Representative Clare Boothe Luce said tonight in a broadcast to the United States after her return from a Christmas visit to the Italian war zone.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The State Street Investment Corporation, Boston, a management type trust, petitioned the Securities and Exchange Commission today to order the New England Public Service Company to integrate its public utility system before proceeding with its reorganization.

SOMETHING new has been added for tonight's basketball show at Madison Square Garden. And it isn't apple honey, either, as the advertising folk would have us believe. It is Howie Schultz who is currently operating as the center for the Hamline quintet. If that name doesn't register immediately on your consciousness, just think back a couple of months and recall the identity of the lad who played first base for our Brooklyn Dodgers.

Sidney Schwartz, Erasmus Hall, who enjoys top seeding in this year's boys' Eastern indoor tennis championship, now in full swing at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, as a result of his 1943 title triumph, has yet to find a competitor worthy of his talent.
