Twenty-six years ago the eyes of America were fixed on Major Whittlesey's Lost Battalion surrounded by the Germans in the Argonne Forest. Those boys of the old Seventy-seventh held fast. Today we watch with equal anxiety dozens of Lost Battalions caught in the dark German flood that rolled through the Ardennes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King, Commander in Chief of the United States Navy and Chief of Naval Operations, declared today that the United States Navy "will continue to speak for itself" through deeds of action during the next few months.

Capt. Bruce Barr of Plainfield, N.J., who once was an important big-game fisherman and held a place on the American team in the international tuna tournament at Nova Scotia in 1935, still finds time to fish, but the locale is different.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Cattlemen and meat processors gloomily predicted a drastic cut in future Corn Belt cattle feeding and heavy liquidation of animals already on feed after listening today to a five-point plan proposed by the Office of Price Administration to establish ceiling prices on live cattle.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Ruses being used by some Westchester County motorists to obtain extra gasoline illegally, now that the black market conducted by service stations has been reduced by the arrest of twenty-six dealers in the last month and warnings to many others, were discussed here today by enforcement agents of the Office of Price Administration and the Sheriff's Bureau of Criminal Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Roosevelt has directed the War Department to take over the headquarters of Montgomery Ward Co. in Chicago and probably seven plants of the retail and mail order house in other cities for refusing to obey directives of the National War Labor Board.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted in English by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

" On the Town," a musical comedy, makes its bow tonight at the Adelphi under the auspices of Oliver Smith and Paul Feigay, a new producing combination. Sufficiently impressed with its prospects are Metro and RKO, two of the backers. Metro has a stake of $62,500 in the show and has already paid a deposit of $100,000 toward the screen rights, the ceiling price of which is $250,000, while RKO's investment amounts to $31,500.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Minister of Information Wang Shih-chieh said today the Chinese considered it their duty to supply "by far the largest land forces" in the forthcoming campaign to drive the Japanese out of China.
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Thursday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

Altman's College Shop exhibition yesterday showed a spring forecast in which capes and checks played a prominent part. The college crowd was on hand to watch a show that also included clothes for immediate wear.

A sight for sore eyes, a GI's sore eyes, was prepared in the fashion show that Saks-Thirty-fourth Street arranged yesterday afternoon. The cream of New York's models tripped down the runway in styles grouped in four classifications selected to please homecoming men.

Although the pennant went elsewhere the Yankees and Indians were the best fielding teams in the American League in 1944, official averages reveal. These two teams tied with a percentage of .974, two points under Boston's leading mark last year.

" National Velvet" today begins a third week at the Radio City Music Hall. . . . "Music for Millions" starts a second week today at the Capitol. . . . "Can't Help Singing," the Deanna Durbin musical at Loew's Criterion, played to a total of 15,000 paid admissions over Christmas Day and Tuesday thereby "breaking all records" for the house, it was announced by the management. . . .

AIR TRANSPORT COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, in China, Dec. 26 (Delayed) -- Self-contained mobile air-transport "task forces" capable of shifting operations rapidly from one base to another are providing one of the solutions for the problem of transporting troops and materials quickly from one place to another across the vast, rugged expanses of the China and India war theatres.

ROME, Dec. 27 -- The Government held the first of a series of press conferences at the Palazzo del Viminale today and at least three important matters were officially put on the record for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Federal departments here have begun to receive back part of the valuable and virtually irreplaceable scientific equipment left behind when the Richard E. Byrd Antarctic expedition was forced to to evacuate its Palmer Peninsula base by air in March, 1941, under conditions of extreme emergency.

The former residence of the late Jules S. Bache at 814 Fifth Avenue, between Sixty-second and Sixty-third Streets, has been sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to Serge Rubinstein, president of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company.

Although some spokesmen for the carpet industry declare they are "awaiting further clarification" of the order freezing cotton yarn, the consensus is that the $20,000,000 a year cotton rug industry will be put "practically out of business," a check-up revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The House Military Affairs Committee, which has been investigating eighty-nine Army hospitals, reported today that conditions in general were favorable but cited some cases where the situation was not so good.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A United States Fourteenth Air Force communique:

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES in Belgium, Dec. 24 (Delayed) -- An error in the Allied intelligence service must share a large part of the blame for Field Marshal Karl yon Runstedt's break-through on the Western Front.

MATTITUCK, L.I., Dec. 27 -- At least seven Army fliers lost their lives this evening when a four-motored bomber, evidently lost in a heavy snowstorm, crashed on a farm on the western outskirts of this village, according to the police, who said seven bodies had been recovered and a search was being conducted for others of the eleven-man crew.

Aircraft in process of development and in production will give us planes with a higher speed than a bullet from a service revolver, Robert A. Lovett, Assistant Secretary of War for Air, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Bond Club of New York at the Bankers Club.

In the current discussion concerning the western frontiers of our Soviet ally I think it might be helpful to recall American policy in the years immediately subsequent to the first World War. During that period the American Government took a positive stand against the dismemberment of Russia.

DETROIT, Dec. 27 -- The Montgomery Ward Co. labor controversy was heightened here today when fifty unidentified rioters wrecked the company's Dearborn store, causing an estimated $10,000 damage. Police Chief Irving Nielsen said two men charged with malicious destruction of property were being held.

Raul Spivak, Argentine pianist, who has had an extensive career in South America and in Europe, made his first American appearance last night at Town Hall, impressing his listeners as a musician of intelligence and a pianist of considerable talent.

Go out in a snowstorm clad in a dark coat and you can have a whole museum full of snow crystals to study simply by standing and watching the flakes as they fall on your sleeve. The variety is literally endless, but until one has tried to pair off the crystals, it is hard to believe that a hexagon can have so many variations.

The proposal put forward a few days ago by a Senate subcommittee for a Federal "job budget" bears a striking resemblance in some respects to the British Government's White Paper on Employment Policy. If the American proposal was not directly derived from the British plan, they are at least both children of the same ideology.

Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" received its first presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Erich Leinsdorf conducting the work for the first time in this city. Mr. Leinsdorf directed the score with the light hand it demands, in a reading that had Mozartean forcefulness and sparkle.

The great battle in Belgium and Luxembourg, which may decide the duration of the European war, is still raging with what Berlin describes as increasing violence. Both sides are still throwing additional forces into the conflict; both sides appear to be taking terrific punishment.
ATHENS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The peace terms offered today by the Eam were:

LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The German radio said tonight that Allied troops were striking violently at both the northern and southern flanks of Field Marshal Karl von Rundstedt's offensive and that at some places near the frontier of Luxembourg German troops had withdrawn to outposts of the Siegfried Line.

No easing in the corset and brassiere supply situation is expected when the new lines open here in the week of Jan. 15, it was reported yesterday in the industry. Allotments of merchandise will continue on the 1941 basis. Retailers' stocks at the end of this month were believed at the lowest point in several years.
ROME, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A communique:

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Coast Guardsman Gus Lesnevich, world light heavyweight boxing champion, was forbidden by the Coast Guard today to fight in an eight-round non-title bout in Memorial Auditorium tonight against Phil Muscato of Buffalo.

Jail terms of two to eight months each were meted out by Federal Judge Edward E. Conger yesterday to four members of a conspiracy that effected the theft of half a million ration points from the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company's branch at 181st Street and Broadway.

EAST OF MARCHE, Belgium, Dec. 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- Their faces blacked, their helmets and armored vehicles left behind, the fighting 400 of "Hogan's task force" came out of the woods through ten miles of enemy lines this morning.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A communique:

ROME, Dec. 27 -- While most of Rome's papers -- with the notable exception of the Communist Unita -- devoted much space today to the Pope's Christmas message and comment, the Pope himself added a brief postscript in a Vatican ceremony at which he received the Ecuadorean Ambassador, Manuel Sotomayor Luna.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The British public was warned today by Jacob Crane, deputy director of the United States National Housing Agency, not to expect the shipment of large numbers of American prefabricated houses to Britain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- The Seabees, who fight with one hand and build with the other, will celebrate their third anniversary tomorrow after taking part in every major amphibious invasion in the war.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 -- "The Third Eye," an English mystery novel by Ethel Lina White, has been bought by Universal for production by Joan Harrison. Miss Harrison will supervise the production as her second picture in 1945, following "Uncle Harry," the Thomas Job play.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Temple University's quintet chalked up its fourth straight victory tonight when it defeated the Tennessee Volunteers, 33 -- 31.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Pressure against the stock market was intensified yesterday although a slight recovery, which coincided with the report of the first serious set-back to the German counter-offensive, helped to reduce extreme losses. Declines which ranged to 3 points in the morning were cut about in half in the afternoon when the selling subsided Liquidation centered mainly in the rails, which sustained the most serious reversals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Navy identified today the modern 2,200-ton destroyer Cooper as the previously unidentified vessel announced by Gen. Douglas MacArthur as lost off Ormoc on Leyte. A medium-sized landing ship, the LSM-20, also was lost in the same waters, the Navy announced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -Twenty-seven more Japanese vessels, including a large aircraft carrier and six other combatant ships, have been sunk by United States submarines, Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- Fires were started among war industry targets in the Tokyo area, including the great Nakajima aircraft factory in the western suburb of Musashino by a Superfortress fleet that made the fifth attack in force on the enemy capital today.

Pressure against the stock market was intensified yesterday although a slight recovery, which coincided with the report of the first serious set-back to the German counter-offensive, helped to reduce extreme losses. Declines which ranged to 3 points in the morning were cut about in half in the afternoon when the selling subsided Liquidation centered mainly in the rails, which sustained the most serious reversals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Navy identified today the modern 2,200-ton destroyer Cooper as the previously unidentified vessel announced by Gen. Douglas MacArthur as lost off Ormoc on Leyte. A medium-sized landing ship, the LSM-20, also was lost in the same waters, the Navy announced.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Temple University's quintet chalked up its fourth straight victory tonight when it defeated the Tennessee Volunteers, 33 -- 31.

The Board of Estimate will consider at a special meeting next Wednesday a recommendation by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick that the city sell from $30,000,000 to $60,000,000 of serial bonds to finance construction of important projects deferred or interrupted because of the war.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Business in today's stock markets again was quiet but the general tone was good.

Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler denied yesterday a motion by Leblang-Gray's, Inc., theatre ticket brokers, to compel License Commissioner Paul Moss to rescind his suspension of its license.

The New Year's holiday period will be ushered in with superb snow conditions throughout the Northeastern sector, thanks to the Weatherman, who has covered most of the areas with a thick white blanket that in many places reaches a powdery depth of fourteen inches.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Governor Dewey, in a move to insure party harmony at the next session of the Legislature, has invited the 129 Republican Senators and Assemblymen to meet with him at the Executive Mansion on Tuesday, the eve of the opening of the 1945 session.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- The National Safety Council stated today that the country was entering the closing days of the year with the traffic toll for 1944 running a neck-and-neck race with the 1943 toll of 23,400.

A stampede of several hundred retail butchers occurred at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in the wholesale meat store of Charles A. Beekman in the Fort Greene meat market, Brooklyn, when a representative of the Department of Markets is alleged to have stood in front of Mr. Beekman's market and called to retail butchers milling around outside to "come and get it."

Although Yale's chess players made a stout stand against Harvard, they were unable to recover the Belden-Stephens Trophy in the annual match contested yesterday at the Marshall Chess Club. The result was a 2-2 tie, each side winning a game, while two were drawn.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week were 83,365,000 barrels, of which 42,135,000 were civilian-grade automotive, 12,918,000 unfinished and 28,312,000 aviation, military and blending stock indeterminate as to ultimate use, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:

Two new films will have premieres in midtown theatres this morning. At the Rivoli, the attraction will be Twentieth Century-Fox's "The Keys of the Kingdom," starring Gregory Peck. The adaptation of the A.J. Cronin novel was directed by John Stahl and produced by Joseph L. Mankiewicz.

Morris Reif and Danny Bartfield, principals in tonight's feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden, spent yesterday in comparative idleness, both men going through light, loosening up exercises at Stillman's Gymnasium.

What Clayton B. Seagears calls "silly but fascinating fun" is in order now with the new snowfall. If you don't mind being regarded as slightly "touched," you might try it. It's called belling the fox and is described in Seagears' new book, "The Fox in New York," obtainable free from the Conservation Department in Albany.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- American Superfortresses scored at least twelve direct hits on Tokyo's Musashino aircraft factory in their attack yesterday, reports from Saipan said today, and enemy broadcasts said that Superfortresses had attacked the capital area again today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- An air force spokesman said today that no considerations other than the weather and the military situation were involved in the suspension of shuttle bombing of Germany through the use of Russian bases.

Gifts for the homeless little children of the Neediest Cases, the most helpless among all the Neediest -- the widowed, ill mothers, the fathers of motherless homes, the aged who are ill, the frustrated individuals - were numerous among the 388 contributions that came to the Fund yesterday.

As a result of a decline in lend-lease shipments and an increase in permissible import recommendations, commercial shipments to the Middle East at the end of the year were treble those at the start of the year, John P. Dawson, chief of the Middle East section of the Foreign Economic Administration, disclosed yesterday.

Year-end cash demands imposed, during the week ended on Wednesday, a renewed strain on the money market in New York City with the outflow of funds estimated at $275,000,000. Figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which covered the operations of the sixteen reporting member banks in this city for the period ended Dec. 28, revealed that the outflow of funds in the past month had reached $1, 000,000,000.

There can be no mistake about it: "On the Town" is the freshest and most engaging musical show to come this way since the golden day of "Oklahoma!" Everything about it is right. It is fast and it is gay, it takes neither itself nor the world too seriously, it has wit.

Your editorial on Burma in THE TIMES of Dec. 14 was not only friendly and timely but suggests a historic fact which has so far been overlooked. Burma was acquired as part of the British Empire under Lord Randolph Churchill, the father of the present Prime Minister of England. This was in 1885 when Lord Randolph Churchill was Secretary of State for India.

The appointment of the first all-woman panel of the Regional War Labor Board was announced yesterday by Thomas L. Norton, chairman of the board. The three women will hear a case involving a labor dispute between Helena Rubinstein, Inc., and employes of the cosmetics manufacturer's plant in Long Island City.

Barred by Lee Shubert from any of his local houses because of the play's subject matter, "Trio" will have its delayed premiere tonight at the independently operated Belasco. That's definite. Produced by Lee Sabinson, the Dorothy and Howard Baker play, adapted from Mrs. Baker's novel, was slated to open at the Cort on Nov 8.

The first results of studies to be conducted by the Architectural Advisory Committee recently formed to assist the Federal Public Housing Authority will be available within six months, through local housing authorities, to anyone interested in low-cost housing, public or private, Howard Myers, publisher of Architectural Forum, who heads the committee, said yesterday.
To judge from a report issued yesterday by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, many foods, at least in the first half of 1945, will be the scarcest they have been since the start of the war.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The Assembly closed its session tonight after a weary five-hour discussion that left resistance groups somewhat on the defensive and conscious of a loss of prestige in the country as the parties prepare for local elections at the end of April, while awaiting indications of the Government's economic program which, despite expectations, did not come today.

The American Labor party announced yesterday a seventeen-point program for constructive legislation it will present to the Legislature when it convenes in Albany next Wednesday. Hyman Blumberg. State secretary, also announced that for the first time since its organization the Labor party would open a legislative office at 125 State Street in Albany.
WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The siege of the gallant Bastogne garrison has been broken, and part of its story can be told today.

PARIS, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The first loads of heroic wounded have been moved down a mile-wide corridor from "bloody Bastogne," and Allied headquarters announced today that American relief armor and infantry of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's Third Army had held firm against German counter-attacks on the flanks of the wedge up to midday yesterday.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Communique 264:

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, in Belgium, Dec. 28 -- Conditions have improved so radically in the past few days around the area of the German break-through that it's a little alarming. The area of German penetration has now been nearly enough sealed off, and the German units operating in it are being so mauled, that it can now be said that it is no longer a break-through.

Fifteen graduate nurses were sworn in yesterday as members of the Army Nurse Corps at a ceremony at the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross, 57 Willoughby Street. Capt. James W. Cowden of the Army Medical Corps administered the oath to the young women, who will report for active duty on New Year's Day.

The year 1944 has seen the air transportation lines of the United States reach a new peak of usefulness both directly to the war effort and to the swift movement of civilians and goods in support of that effort. In cold figures, the airlines have shown a gain of 22 per cent in revenue passenger-miles, 24 per cent in mail pound-miles and 7 per cent in express pound-miles flown, as compared with the preceding year.

The youngest person to be arraigned in War Emergency Court, 16-year-old Thomas Ungano, of 45 Catharine Street, escaped being sent to jail yesterday when he pleaded with Magistrate Leonard McGee "please don't send me to jail because it will give me a record."

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- Japanese planes raided the American Superfortress base on Saipan and installations on Tinian Island in the Marianas but inflicted only minor damage, Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today.

In the greatest output year in its history the automotive industry has produced almost $10,500,000,000 worth of materials for 1944, or twice that of any comparative peacetime period, according to reports received yesterday by the Automobile Merchants Association of New York.

Until 2:30 P.M. yesterday there was a possibility that C.C.N.Y. would pull out of its game with Hemline last night at Madison Square Garden. At that hour, however, word was received from Dan Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, that special permission had been granted to City College to play a team using an "ineligible" player, namely Howie (Stretch) Schultz.
The Autonomous Institute for the Amortization of the Public Debt of Chile reported yesterday that total receipts of the institute in 1943 available for debt service were $6,624,758.

ROME, Dec. 28 -- Count Carlo Sfcrza today explained his resignation as head of the High Commission for the Punishment of Fascist Crimes as based on his conviction that the body must be headed by an influential member of the Government or otherwise risk becoming an oppositional unit at a time when the nation needs above all "authority and prestige in the Government."

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 29 -- Russian tanks and cavalry swung toward Vienna on a ninety-mile front across the plains of western Hungary on both sides of the Danube River yesterday while two Soviet armies slashed deeper into Budapest's burning streets and captured twelve of its eastern suburbs.

An enormously expanded program for the teaching of foreign languages was forecast by members of the American Association of Teachers of Slavonic and East European Languages at the first of the association's annual meetings yesterday at Philosophy Hall, Columbia University.

All eleven members of the crew of the Army bomber that crashed Wednesday night at Mattatuck, L. I., were killed, according to an announcement last night by Lieut. Col. George Logan, commander of the Suffolk County Army air field.

NOVELISTS are persistent seekers after novelty. "What can I write about," many of them seem to ask themselves, "that no one has ever written about before?" Such a question can have no absolute answer, since human experience has a way of repeating itself in perennial patterns, even though strange and remote corners of the world are explored as backgrounds for fiction, and even though exotically unfamiliar aspects of life are carefully annotated.

The Scientific American is about to celebrate its centenary, and well it may. Its history is largely the history of American science and invention. For years it was the only American periodical dedicated exclusively to the task of reporting the news of technology, with the result that its pages reflect the changes that have occurred in the American scene.

The factional conflict in the American Zionist Emergency Council, arising out of differences over tactics and procedure between its two co-chairmen, Rabbi Stephen S. Wise and Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, culminated last night in the re-election by the council of Dr. Wise to the chairmanship and the elimination of Dr. Silver, who previously had submitted his resignation "irrevocably."
MONTREAL, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Five goals by Maurice Richard paced the Canadiens to a 9-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings at the Forum tonight and protected Montreal's National Hockey League lead.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Eddie Ryan and Jackie Paley have been chosen by Twentieth Century Fox for the romantic leads in the melodrama "The Caribbean Mystery." Also going into the cast of the picture, which will be started on Jan. 15, are Reed Hadley and Renee Carson.

LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended Dec. 27 reported a decrease of 3,393,000 in note circulation, the first decline in more than three months. Private deposits increased 61,143,000, Government securities were up 56,235,000 and other securities increased 1,562,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- For the second time in eight months and for the same reason, defiance of the National War Labor Board, the Government, acting this time through the Army, seized today the executive offices and other Chicago facilities of Montgomery Ward Co., the country's second largest mail order organization.

An old company yesterday joined the New York Stock Exchange family, for that market place admitted to listing but not to trading until further notice 750,000 shares of the Pennsylvania Salt Company, $10 par value. The company was founded in 1850 and now, in addition to salt, makes a wide range of industrial chemicals and chemical specialties.

Cabrettas will continue to be frozen for military purposes after the current direction expires on Sunday, it was learned in the leather industry yesterday. A new direction is expected momentarily to continue until June 30, 1945. Terms of the new direction are expected to be comparable to those of expiring direction No. 3.
Claude Leach Jr. has been appointed sales promotion manager for the forthcoming line of radios and radio-phonograph combinations of the Bendix Aviation Corporation.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt's check to Anglo-American hopes of the early defeat of Germany and the success of the Soviet offensive in Hungary have made it a foregone conclusion here that the Russians will be in a position to dominate the whole of southeastern Europe, militarily and politically, for a considerable period before their Allies join them there.
The war situation and the weather on Sunday, hotel and night club men of the city decided yesterday, will determine the character of the celebration on New Year's Eve.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Dr. George Gallup told House investigators today that he reported less Roosevelt strength early in the 1944 campaign than his own figures showed, because he underestimated the total vote.

Contingency funds of the Bendix Aviation Corporation have been reduced by $2,499,065 as a result of action taken by the Price Adjustment Board to complete renegotiation of the company's war contracts for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, 1943, according to a letter sent yesterday to stockholders by Ernest R. Breech, president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today broadening of its leather pricing regulation in an action expected to reduce prices charged for leather at producer and wholesaler levels and to "pave the way" for possible reductions in the retail prices of shoes and other leather products.

Under the impetus of war, radio and electronic techniques performed services in the last year that were deemed impossible in 1940, Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, declared here yesterday in a statement reviewing radio's progress in 1944.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -Seeking more than the $22,104,515 judgment awarded them in the Federal District Court here nearly a year ago in their contest with the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, two groups of stockholders of the Pennroad Corporation were rebuffed today by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals which set aside the decision of the lower court and ordered Judge George A. Welsh to enter a judgment in favor of the railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- Although at an appreciably slower rate, 1,271 registered American corporations added $803,000,000 to their aggregate net working capital during the first six months of this year, it was disclosed today in a report made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (AP) - Durez Plastics Chemicals, Inc., North Tonawanda, N.Y., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the proposed issuance and sale of 73,208 shares of $5 par value common stock.

Directors of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., have adopted a retirement pension plan for its employes and those of its subsidiaries, including L. Bamberger Co., Newark; Davison-Paxon Company, Atlanta, Augusta and Macon, Ga.; the Lasalle Koch Co., Toledo; Bamberger Broadcasting Service, Inc., and Supremacy Products, Inc., Jack I. Straus, president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Women's Army Corps Training Centers, which once numbered five, will be reduced to one at Fort Des Moines by April 1, with the discontinuance of training at Fort Oglethorpe, Ga.

Surplus war housing and many new structural units to be prepared by prefabricators in this region and other parts of the Eastern Seaboard will be speeded to French ports to provide shelter for at least 150,000 dock workers and dock repairers there, as a means of expanding facilities to handle the increasing flow of war supplies to American forces.

In his communication favoring the use of Government credit to stimulate purchasing power, Donald B. Marsh compares the proponents of orthodox fiscal procedures to an army fighting a rear-guard action and describes this action as "hopeless." May I point out that hopeless rear-guard actions are signalized by desperate tactics, and that on this basis the shoe would be on the other foot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The supply of food in this country next year is expected to continue at about the same level as this year, with the prospect of some surpluses if the European war comes to an end, the War Food Administration indicated today.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Proposed changes in the price ceiling program on live cattle would deal a "body blow to the illicit trade in meat," John J. Madigan, assistant director of food prices for the Office of Price Administration, said today.

Artur Rodzinski rendered the notable service of a performance of Ernest Bloch's "Israel" symphony at the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall. The orchestra was assisted in this performance by the choral ensemble from Temple Emanu-El, which is under the directorship of Lazare Saminsky.

Plumbing new depths of good-natured diatribe in their induction ceremonies of Ed McKeever at the Waldorf-Astoria ballroom yesterday the Circus Saints and Sinners gave a thorough "going over" to the Notre Dame football coach.

PARIS, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Corp. Billy Conn, cool as an iceberg when he faced the fearsome fists of heavyweight champion Joe Louis, said today he had had two close calls in one day -- a plane mishap and German bombing -- which "scared me half to death."

WITH THE SEVENTH ARMY IN EASTERN FRANCE, Dec. 28 -- French pilots, who are flying British-built Spitfires, have little regard for the skill of the Luftwaffe pilots, with whom they have been in combat along this front since the invasion of southern France.

The season's first performance of Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" last night at the Metropolitan Opera House was one of the company's most consistently well-sung presentations of the winter to date. All of the roles were in capable hands and there was a grateful absence of tiny voices in the personnel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Cocoa importers and chocolate manufacturers of the United States are awaiting word from the State Department on their demands for a brisk United States attitude toward official British proposals which would set up a new system for control of West African cocoa production and pricing starting in October.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities and note circulation for the system as a whole to have increased $55,398,000 and $50,665, 000, respectively, during the week. The ratio of reserve recovered to 48.9.

Herbert Brownell Jr., Republican National Chairman, sent invitations yesterday to all Republican members of Congress to attend a dinner to be held next Thursday at the Hotel Statler in Washington. The dinner will be in honor of the newly elected Republican members of the Senate and House of Representatives.

Carnarvon Borough in Wales will soon have a new representative in the House of Commons. He will take the place of the sitting member, who is retiring on the advice of his physicians after a continuous service of fifty-four years and just before his eighty-second birthday, which falls on Jan. 17. His name is David Lloyd George.

Pleas of not guilty were entered in Federal court yesterday by Carl L. Norden, Inc., and other defendants named in two indictments returned last week. Judge Edward A. Conger ordered the four individual defendants photographed and fingerprinted, but released them without bail.
Only about half as many butcher shops were closed yesterday as the day before, but the city remained in the grip of a meat famine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson reiterated today his confidence in the outcome of the situation on the western European front, basing his attitude on the following three points:

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The Metro, which is the Parisian version of subway, is about to increase fares once more. This likelihood loomed today as a species of news more important even than events at the front. For, apart from a few antediluvian hackneys or "cycle-taxis" -- trailers attached to push bikes -- the subway remains the only means of locomotion in the capital.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- T. Henry Foster, chairman of the board of American Meat Institute, reported today that United States meat production in 1944 set a new world's record of 25,000,000,000 pounds and predicted a nine-pound increase in beef supplies per person in 1945.

ROME, Dec. 28 (AP) -- -Gen. Arnaldo Azzi, who wrote a newspaper article calling for reorganization of the Italian Army, has been relieved of his command in the Lazio-Umbria-Abruzzi region, the War Ministry announced today.
Yesterday's communique, as transmitted by the New Yugoslav Telegraph Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

ATHENS, Dec. 28 -- Before Mr. Churchill and Mr. Eden left Athens the former announced that he would undertake to notify King George that Archbishop Damaskinos had informed him "that the overwhelming will of the Greek people favored a regency as the essential prelude to a solution of other problems."
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Friday, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

The first test sales of dehydrated vegetables to civilians will be made by grocery stores in Grand Rapids, Mich., beginning Jan. 25 and continuing for a six months' period, the National Dehydrators Association announced yesterday. The sale will be under the auspices of the Farm Credit Administration in cooperation with the association.

City College's basketball team, after a gallant uphill struggle that had a crowd of 17,853 persons rooting hard for the underdog, bowed to Hamline, 47 -- 42, and Long Island University conquered Wyoming, 46 -- 40, in the college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Goalie Paul Bibeault, on lend-lease from the Canadiens, held the Chicago Black Hawks in check while his new Bruin team-mates were gaining a 2-1 victory before 12,500 fans at the Boston Garden. It was Bibeault's first National Hockey League start of the season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Changes in personnel of important committees of the next Senate as the result of death, retirement or defeat, focus attention especially upon two -- the Foreign Relations and the Naval Affairs groups, each of which has lost five members.

Reading your editorial "Tighter Rationing" I was somewhat exercised by the last sentence: "For perishable products such as meat and butter -- which should be rationed separately -- coupons should be canceled at frequent intervals, probably each month, because of the importance of bringing supply and demand into balance within relatively short periods of time."

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- The grain market fluctuated in an erratic manner today on the Board of Trade, breaking early in sympathy with corn, which was depressed by hedging sales, only to rally later upon the leadership of rye. The latter gained 1/4 to 1/8 cents net a bushel, with May leading and reaching the highest price since last July.

SOMEWHERE IN THE MARIANAS (via Navy Radio), Dec. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- In the second coordinated Army and Navy assault upon Iwo today, Seventh Air Force Lightnings and Liberators strafed and bombed that Japanese base for staging raids against Saipan, then withdrew to permit naval units bombard the enemy installations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Representative August H. Andresen, Republican, of Minnesota, accused Fred Vinson, Economic Stabilizer, and Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, of swindling millions of "thrifty American housewives" when they "conspired to issue the new ration order which canceled unused red and blue stamps."
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

An investigation of the meat ration accounts of the Harvard and Union clubs and of four hotels was begun yesterday by the Office of Price Administration after testimony was offered by several wholesalers that they had violated rationing regulations in their dealings with those users of meat.

Chicken-hungry New Yorkers welcomed the arrival here yesterday of 15,000 pounds of turkeys, chickens, ducks, geese and pheasants -- but none of them for eating purposes. All of the birds were placed on display at the Madison Square Garden Poultry Show.

Directors of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company yesterday voted to split the company's common stock on a four-for-one basis. Stockholders will be asked to vote on the proposed change in the capital structure at their annual meeting in Pittsburgh on April 11, next.

News from the Western Front continues to be favorable. All reports agree that American heroism, already tested on many battlefronts, has risen to new heights on the bloody fields of Belgium and Luxembourg. Our troops have stopped, at least for the present, and turned back in part, the greatest German offensive undertaken against the western Allies since 1940, and the greatest offensive ever made against American armies in their history.

The operation of a monopolistic conspiracy restricting trucking services in the garment industry in the metropolitan area to members of a group of trade associations was alleged yesterday in two criminal informations filed in Federal court by the Department of Justice.

Third-round play yesterday in the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships on the Bassford- Wood courts in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, resulted in several hard-fought matches, although the top-seeded racquet wielders all came through for the semi-finals today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Spangled Game, fast-stepping 3-year-old gelding from the Bermar and Metcalf Stable, whipped over a mile and seventy yards in 1 minute 40 2/5 seconds at Tropical Park today to set a new American record.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- The American retreat before the German offensive was plain hell.

The danger of a wave of super-isolationism among returning American soldiers and the responsibility of American educational institutions in contributing to the welfare of civilization were emphasized by Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker and Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, respectively, at the thirty-sixth annual holiday luncheon of the Columbia Alumni Federation yesterday at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Jean Monnet, who recently arrived here on a supply mission for the French Government, announced at a press conference today that his program
ROME, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The texts of President Roosevelt's statement explaining his action in ordering seizure today of Montgomery Ward facilities and of the executive order were as follows:

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Lupe Velez, the vivacious movie star, was buried today in this city mid disorders and stampedes reminiscent of those at the Rudolph Valentino funeral in New York nearly two decades ago.

W. Ray Johnston, president of Monogram Pictures Corporation, announced yesterday that the corporation had filed with the Securities Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement listing seventeen underwriters of their proposed issue of 100,000 shares of 5 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock.

Warning that opposition to a world security organization is growing already, John W. Davis, Democratic Presidential nominee in 1924 and Ambassador to the Court of St. James in the Wilson Administration, predicted yesterday that the combined efforts of everyone who believes in international order will be required if present attempts for establishment of a global peace body are to be successful.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- President Roosevelt's order directing the War Department to seize eleven properties of Montgomery Ward Co. in seven cities was based on the charge that the company had "failed" to assume its "obligation" and "responsibility to our fighting men" to see that "nothing interferes with the continuity of our war production."

Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., in its annual statement for the twelve months ended with September, going to stockholders today, reports the largest volume of sales and deliveries in its thirty-eight-year history. Deliveries of war products were about $236,700,000, an increase of 32 per cent over the total of the previous fiscal year, according to the report, signed by Ward M. Canaday, chairman, and Charles E. Sorenson, president.
The Russian capture of Budapest, now impending, will open one gateway up the valley of the Danube to Vienna and Bratislava.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Western Pacific Railroad elected today nine new directors to serve on a board of eleven members that will take over direction of the company next Monday.

Very few proposed contract termination loans have been coming to the banks in recent weeks. While bankers tend to view this as one of the "signs of the times," they comment that there are plenty of unused credits on Regulation V and VT loans previously outstanding.

IN less than a week the only running any horses will do will be just for the exercise. The ban on horse racing goes into effect on Jan. 3 and the betting gentry will be extremely disconsolate, since it no longer will be able to wager a few bob on the bangtails. Money burns holes in the pockets of the dyed-in-the-wool gambler.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- War casualties of the armed forces reached 628,441 on December 14, two days before the big German offensive in Western Europe.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co. filed a $50,000 suit today against a CIO union, whose members were involved in a strike at four of the company's stores in the Detroit area, as Army officers took over the stores. Roy Scoggins, union spokesman, declared the strike was over and promised that all union workers would be back at their jobs tomorrow.

The stock market responded yesterday to the more cheering war news from Europe sector and regained the ground lost during the preceding session. Best gains were selective and although the average additions held to a point there were numerous increases of much more in some popular sections.

Pafenondroy, five miles southwest of Malmedy in Belgium, once had a population of about 150. It was a pretty little village, as Harold Denny reported to this newspaper. As Christmas came near, it was decorated with holly, tinsel and colored paper. Then some of Hitler's SS troopers came back.

License Commissioner Paul Moss announced yesterday that in the near future he would order theatres housing hit stage attractions to stop selling tickets to brokers. The Commissioner explained that he has adopted this rule "because of the many complaints that have been pouring into the department from many people who cannot buy tickets at the box office for the hits in New York theatres."

Declaring that shortages of certain war items and a need for about 300,000 additional war plant workers "have been takled about for six months and still nothing has been done," Charles E. Wilson, president of General Electric, yesterday recommended that the Government "cut into other kinds of work to release people for war jobs in which critical bottlenecks are appearing."
The Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation yesterday announced that preliminary auditions for its twenty-first annual series for pianists, violinists, 'cellists and singers will be held next March.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The Germans admitted tonight that fierce resistance by heavily armed and armored Anglo-American reinforcements had halted Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt's offensive "at the very point where it could have become most threatening" and had forced the withdrawal of his spearheads both on the southern flank and west of the break-through area.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Liberalization of New York State tax policy affecting renegotiated war contracts to provide "adequate relief" to corporation franchise taxpayers is under consideration, Rollin Browne, president of the State Tax Commission, said today.

R.A. Stewart Co., Inc., manufacturers of marking devices, to Rill Associates, effective Jan. 1, Irwin Wayburn is the account executive. Plans for consumer advertising are being completed in addition to trade copy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Pan American Airways asserted in a final brief filed today with the Civil Aeronautics Board that unless "the chosen instrument" airline policy was continued in Latin America after the war, neither the goal of low-cost, mass air transportation nor of adequate air competition with foreign operators in Latin America could be achieved.

Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in German to the Western Hemisphere and Asio from Berlin and transmitted in English to East Asia by the Nazi DNB Agency as recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

All that we at home have to do when we give up a little blood is to go from our warm, comfortable homes or offices to warm, comfortable blood banks every two or three months and lie, not in mud or ice, but in warm, clean, sanitary rooms, attended by nurses, who take a measly pint of blood from our well-fed bodies.

Although the going is likely to get tougher and there even may be some tall scratching to find the players, major league baseball is certain to operate in 1945, in the opinion of Bill McKechnie, manager of the Reds.

Mr. Churchill and Mr. Eden are on their way home from Athens with a plan for a regency in Greece which they will submit, with due regard to the proprieties of the situation, to the Greek King, who is in London. This plan is reported to have the unanimous approval of all the factions whose representatives attended the conferences in Athens.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- After Brig. Gen. Charles E. Walsh, Republican, and Dr. Clarence E. Mullens, Democrat, resigned today as members of the Albany County Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, George P. Monaghan, special prosecutor in the Albany County investigation, disclosed that the board's affairs had long been under scrutiny.

GENEVA, Dec. 28 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) -- How tens of thousands of Hungarian Jews perished last month in an epic "march of death" from Budapest to the Austrian frontier has been revealed here by one of the "marchers," who escaped to Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The President's labor policy has been largely superstructure without much base or balance, and that superstructure has been built from blueprints furnished exclusively by organized labor. But one pier of the incomplete foundation has been firmly and solidly established: the maintenance-of-membership plan for unions which have won employes' elections to decide how they shall be represented in negotiations with management.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Here is the statement that Sewell Avery issued after Government seizure of the Montgomery Ward properties:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Reaction to the Government's order closing race tracks has reached the Treasury in the form of renewed proposals for a national lottery, but the Treasury is not interested.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 28 -- British troops, driving southward in Burma, have gained up to twenty miles against light Japanese resistance and have advance elements within approximately ninety-five miles of the big enemy supply base of Mandalay, Allied Headquarters announced today.

As to the ration point changes I have no complaint. That should be the plain duty of those who should know of the supply and demand. But when ration stamps that were officially listed as "good indefinitely" are canceled suddenly, I rebel.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- The Japanese fleet probably will be liquidated within a year if "the present rate of attrition is maintained,'' Vice Admiral Marc A. Mitscher, veteran leader of fast carrier task force operations, said today on his return to the Pacific.

A group of Indianapolis banks received yesterday the award of $1,090,000 of city of Indianapolis temporary-loan notes at 0.75 per cent, plus a premium of $61.80. The obligations will become payable on May 15, 1945.

The Beech Aircraft Corporation will submit to stockholders at their adjourned annual meeting on Jan. 25 a proposal to increase the concern's authorized common stock from 500,000 to 1,500,000 shares in order to place the company in a position "to take quick and decisive action, if and when conditions render such action advisable" after the termination of the war emergency, according to the company's announcement.

Expansion of the 50-year-old Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound from supervision alone of championship competitions during the summer to recognition of distant events as well was announced yesterday. It was the first break in the original policy of the organization which, in reality, has not even scheduled the so-called "special" regattas that have been held on Saturdays preceding the titular events.

The Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday decided to continue in office all except one of the men it had this year and also to carry on the same tourneys, unless, of course, events in the next three or four months warrant a change in plans.

From Paris comes the statement, in an Associated Press dispatch, that since D-day "not a single American soldier in France has been executed for cowardice, desertion in the face of the enemy or any other military offense for which death is mandatory." Our soldiers are not angels. Out of hundreds of thousands of men four have been executed for murder, twelve for rape.

WITH UNITED STATES THIRD ARMY, Dec. 28 -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton has hurled his Third Army infantry and tanks fat German break-through forces in what may well be the war's decisive battle. Three days after Field Marshal Gen. Karl von ...

Sixteen months after they shook hands and parted company in an Italian prison hospital outside Naples, two wounded veterans of the bitter fighting in Sicily looked up yesterday from opposite beds at the blood donor center of the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, then made for each other with shouts of recognition.

Calling attention to the increased needs of our invasion forces in Europe for supplies and equipment, the United States Civil Service Commission announced yesterday that 1,500 civilian workers, skilled and unskilled, were urgently needed for duty at the Army's New York Port of Embarkation.

ROME, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- The German surprise offensive in the Ligurian coastal sector of Italy against Fifth Army troops has driven more than three miles through American lines, communiques disclosed today, and fighting on the "forgotten front" reached a greater intensity than had been seen in this theatre since the assault on the Gothic Line.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- An appeal to workers to stay on the job on New Year's Day to help meet the production strain imposed by "the fiercest fighting of the war" was made jointly today by Secretary Forrestal, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board.

In compliance with President Roosevelt's executive order, the War Department took over yesterday the Montgomery Ward Co. store at 15-18 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, through Capt. P. A. Carson and five other Army officers.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 -- Declaring that judges of the Municipal Court and Police Departments were not qualified to pass on the literary value of books, Judge Elijah Adlow dismissed today a charge of selling an obscene book lodged against Miss E. Margaret Anderson, a clerk at the Dartmouth Book Stall, Inc.

Winning in both the third and fourth rounds, each time by 2 -- 1, Columbia's trio moved into first place yesterday in the Intercollegiate Chess League title play for the Harold M. Phillips Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 28 -- Its western spearhead blunted and its southern flank falling back under a series of savage attacks by the American Third Army, the great German offensive in Belgium has ground to a halt.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The newspaper Combat, which published Tuesday a bitter attack on American policy toward France and other liberated countries, published today an article by another contributor who complains that many Frenchmen already are forgetting that they owe to Americans "a debt of gratitude that all the money in the world would not suffice to pay."
After a quiet opening, cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned steady yesterday, closing virtually at the best levels of the day or at net gains of 5 to 10 points.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
Little, Brown announces it will discontinue publication of school and college textbooks, including Atlantic Monthly Press textbooks, and has sold to D.C. Heath Co. of Boston its active textbook list.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration said today that it was considering putting the 1945 crops of fire-cured and dark air-cured tobacco under price control.

Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, announced yesterday that the Authority had filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board a brief asking the approval of one-carrier direct air routes between the New Jersey-New York port district and various points in Latin America in the interest of greater transportation efficiency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Inter-American Coffee Board today substantially raised coffee quotas above basic quotas to encourage importation of coffee.

Top-ranking performer in the all-important department of driving in runs and runner-up for home-run honors, Vern Stephens, shortstop of the Browns, established himself as the American League's No. 1 power house player for 1944, according to the official records announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- The Government's seizure of the properties of Montgomery Ward Co. in Chicago appeared today to have struck a phase of passive resistance, with the question of who is in control not decided after more than twenty-four hours.

Staff depletions are common in hospitals these days, but Grasslands Hospital at Eastview, owned and operated by Westchester County, finds the condition exceptionally vexatious. It has already been forced to cut its bed capacity from 830 to 500, is releasing some tubercular patients and refusing admittance to scores of other persons.

Royal Leo Gaynor, a self-styled scientist and educator, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Special Sessions to being the "dean" of the so-called New York College of Psychiatry, formerly at 103 Park Avenue, where untutored grocery clerks and others, it was alleged, received diplomas as "psychiatrists'' and "psychologists."

The Rev. Dr. Franklin Clark Fry, 44 years old, for the last fifteen years pastor of Trinity Lutheran Church, Akron, Ohio, on Monday will become the second president of the United Lutheran Church in America. The presidency is a full-time salaried office, with headquarters at the Lutheran Church House, 231 Madison Avenue, formerly the J.P. Morgan residence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Increased military activity in all theatres of operation, particularly in Europe, has caused the Treasury's Office of Surplus Property to withdraw from sale 8,053,599 flashlight batteries from the 22,000,000 which it has been releasing through regular trade channels, it was announced today.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast in Serbo-Croat by the Free Yugoslav Radio and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:
Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer approved yesterday a compromise agreement which set up a plan that would result in a saving of $50,000 a year to the United States Rubber Company.

State excise taxes, license fees and State liquor store profits accounted for more than 25 per cent, or $511,362,796, of the record total of $2,000,000,000 collected in liquor revenues in 1943 by Federal, State and local governments, according to a study released yesterday by the research and statistical bureau of Allied Liquor Industries.
Year-end covering by trade houses gave the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange a very steady tone yesterday and final prices showed net gains of 4 to 10 points.

Because of what he termed "misstatements of fact arising from my appearance in Washington," Dr. George Gallup issued an explanatory statement from his New York office yesterday on the workings of the Gallup polls conducted by his American Institute of Public Opinion.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Prime Minister Churchill returned from Athens today, and without pausing a moment immediately conferred with his War Cabinet and called King George II of Greece to 10 Downing Street. Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden returned with the Prime Minister and attended the evening Cabinet session.
Corp. George D'Elena of Brooklyn, now with the Army in the Southwest Pacific, presents some observations on sharks in Australia:
Security and commodity markets throughout the world will be closed on Monday in observance of New Year's Day.

Light snow early today, changing after a few hours to a drizzle, with hazardous highways, was predicted by the Weather Bureau last night for the New York area. The rain is expected to end about noon and a chance was seen for fair weather tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The War Department has recalled several general officers from overseas commands within recent months, demoting some of them, it was learned tonight.

Retail trade here was spotty this week, chiefly because of adverse weather conditions. Volume followed no particular pattern and sales comparison with a year ago was affected by changes in the number of days which department stores were open.

MYITKYINA, Burma, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops of the northern Burma combat command have crossed the Burma border into China and captured Loiwing, by-passing a strong Japanese defensive position five miles to the southeast at Namhkam, it was announced today.

QUITO, Equador, Jan. 29 (AP) -- The Ecuadorean Assembly has opposed proposals that the United States be granted air and naval bases in Ecuadorean territory after the war, it was disclosed today. The United States now has use of bases it constructed at Salinas and in the Galapagos Islands as a war-time measure in agreement with the Ecuadorean Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The United States Antarctic explorers left two clocks ticking behind them when their time finally ran out in Palmar Land in March, 1941, one to break the endless polar stillness with a man-made sound for thirty days or more and the other to equalize the few hours of life remaining to their faithful sled dogs.

As the church bells toll out the old year and ring in the new year tomorrow thousands of the devout in New York City will attend watch night or holy hour services in hundreds of sanctuaries and pray as the fourth year of war dies that the new-born year will see the dawn of peace.
Admissions to member firms of the New York Stock Exchange include John A. Stevenson to Alfred L. Baker Co. on Monday, it was announced yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- The infantry held Bastogne and tanks broke through the encircling German lines to relieve it, but the weatherman, the Allied First Airborne Army and the United States Ninth Air Force had their shares in its successful defense.

Manhattan officially went over the top in E-Bond sales on figures tabulated for Thursday, with sales recorded that day of $3,335,570 and cumulative sales of $108,515,053, or 100.2 per cent, Frederick W. Gehle, State chairman of the War Finance Committee, announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat, Wyoming, expressed belief tonight that the solution to the problem of getting more meat into butcher shops lay in better administration of the food subsidy program.

HAVANA, Cuba, Dec. 29 -- President Ramon Grau San Martin relieved Brig. Gen. Francisco Tabernilla, chief of Havana's Cabana fortress, and four of his subordinates of their commands today and ordered their retirement as Gen. Manuel Lopez Migoya, Chief of Staff of the army, issued a statement declaring that the army was loyal to the present Government.

The wounded and the sick, the doctors, nurses, orderlies and other personnel in an American Army hospital somewhere in England have sent $373.69 to the Neediest Cases Fund -- "a small gift," they said, which betokens their "concern and love for those at home."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The United States Navy, largest in the world, will start the new year with 61,045 vessels, including 1,167 warships and 54,206 landing craft, with which "to meet and defeat the enemy," the Navy Department stated today in a production report.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- A chilliness has begun to show itself in Anglo-American relations. It is not merely that there is a note of strain in official exchanges between the two Governments. It is reflected in countless little ways.

Sidney Schwartz, Erasmus Hall, who is defending his boys' Eastern indoor tennis title at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, defeated Marvin Mantin of DeWitt Clinton, 6-2, 6-0, yesterday in the semi-final round.

FOURTEENTH AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, in China. Dec. 28 (Delayed) -- The Japanese land campaign in the last six months in the South China theatre has had two major objectives. One was to clip the wings of the Fourteenth Air Force by occupying its forward bases, the other was to open a corridor of land communications spanning the gap between Changsha and Indo-China, needed to establish a through overland transport route from northern Manchuria to Singapore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A bronze bust of Cordell Hull by George Conlon was presented to Secretary Stettinius today by the personnel of the State Department and the foreign service to stand in the Secretary's reception room as a mark of honor and esteem for the man who was Secretary nearly twelve years.

Sixty thousand gifts from Junior Red Cross members, representing hours of work in classrooms and workshops, as well as their own contributions, brightened Christmas for wounded veterans in hospitals here and for poor children in homes and institutions.

All civil claims against nine corporations and a group of their officers, arising out of alleged agreements among them in connection with the submission of bids for the manufacture of cable, were renounced by the Government yesterday.

With their faith in one branch of Government slightly shaken but with an increased respect for another, two Port Richmond, S.I., youngsters resignedly were waiting in Washington last night for their parents to take them home after twenty-four exciting hours of adventure and misadventure.

PANAMA, Dec. 29 -- The Cabinet resigned today to permit of its reorganization by President Ricardo Adolfo de la Guardia, who was said to be conferring with leaders of the political parties at the Presidential Palace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Department store sales increased 34 per cent for the week ended Dec. 23 compared to the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, adding that the week of Dec. 23 had six business days, in contrast to the five marking the like period a year ago.

The New Year's week-end will be meatless for thousands of New York families, butchers' spokesmen said yesterday. Although many more shops had reopened for "business," they had little meat to sell. Spokesmen for dealers' organizations pointed out that even if meat should reach the city today or tomorrow it could not be distributed till next week.

The ranks of women pipe smokers have risen during the last two months because of the gloomy cigarette outlook and the usual mushrooming of new fads at Christmas time, a survey of tobacconists and leading pipe retailers revealed yesterday.

Recent changes in rationing have caused confusion, judging from the number of telephone calls received by this department during the week. There seems to be so much uncertainty, in fact, that we are prompted to reproduce here some of the questions most commonly asked, together with the answers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Reports that the Government might buy 50,000,000 bushels of cash corn as a reserve for essential industries in case of a small crop next year brought in today fairly active buying of futures on the Board of Trade.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- The situation being created for Gen. Charles de Gaulle by the prosecution of the purge of so-called collaborators was exemplified by two events today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- American and British as well as Russian forces will participate in the liberation of Austria from seven years of Nazi tyranny, it was reported tonight.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 29 -- "Luxury" nursing service demanded by wealthy private patients and overstaffed nursing services maintained by some war plants were listed today as two principal causes for the current shortage of nurses in the armed services by Dr. Charles H. Schlichter, head of the committee on procurement and assignment of the War Manpower Commission in New Jersey.

A memorial to former Gov. Alfred E. Smith is being planned by a committee of ninety-five prominent New Yorkers, which made public yesterday an invitation to friends and admirers of the former Governor to join in contributing to a fund for the purpose. Today would have been Mr. Smith's seventy-first birthday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 -- A compulsory health insurance plan which would provide hospitalization and medical care for several million Californians through equal contributions from employers and employes is being prepared, with Governor Earl Warren's approval, for action by the Legislature next month.

Although the cotton freeze order issued by the War Production Board last week, to be effective Jan. 15, extends at present until March 31 only, Government officials have made no promise that restrictions will be lifted on that date, and the order was interpreted by some textile experts yesterday as putting the production of decorative fabrics under practically the same ban as horse racing.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- Yielding in part to the flare-up of public opinion since the Germans showed that they were capable of a serious counter-offensive, Gen. Charles de Gaulle's Cabinet this morning decided to mobilize the military class of 1943 at the end of next January. The class consists of about 200,000 in the 21-year-old category.

When Lucille Lamb, 19 years old, who gave her address as 270 Amsterdam Avenue, was arraigned before Magistrate Charles E. Hirsimaki in Flatbush Avenue Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, the charge of endangering the life and health of a child, which previously had been made against her, was dismissed upon the recommendation of Assistant District Attorney Charles Mayo.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The text of a statement by Herbert H. Lehman, Director General of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, on relief problems:
PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 29 (AP) - A communique:

The newspapers have told New York the debt it owes to I. N. Phelps Stokes for what he did for the city as architect, planner, drafter of the Tenement law and historian. He loved New York and knew every inch of it. As a member and president of the Municipal Art Commission he gave himself completely to the betterment of the city, seeking with knowledge and tolerance to establish and maintain the highest esthetic standards.

With a graceful bow, quite in the thoroughbred tradition, racing has promised full compliance with the Byrnes order requesting the closing of the nation's race tracks. At approximately the same time Herbert Bayard Swope bowed out as member and Chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, after ten years of unsalaried activity in the service of the sport and the State.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 29. (U.P.) -- In central and western Burma the Allies made further advances toward major Japanese centers as double British pincer drives closed in on the communications center of Ye-u and the western Burma port of Akyab.

ROME, Dec. 29 -- Baron Gabriele Apor, former Deputy Foreign Minister of Hungary and for six years Hungarian Minister to the Vatican, has forwarded a message of loyalty to the Provisional Government at Debrecsen through M.A. Kostileff, Soviet Ambassador to Rome, it was learned today.

A new system of handling the 250,000 or more carloads of produce received at North River piers here each year, which would eliminate monopolistic practices characteristic of the present twenty-year-old methods, has been worked out, it was learned yesterday.

ATHENS, Dec. 29 -- Dissensions over political creeds went into the background today when, just at dawn, guns went into action, roaring with greater fury than ever in this civil war. Tanks, machine guns, mortars and Infantry went forward in a three-pronged British attack upon Elas-held areas adjoining the capital.

The New York State Department of Commerce hopes to increase its advertising appropriation slightly next year although the tendency, as in the past, will be to keep such appropriations and the department as small as possible, it was learned yesterday.

New Year's Eve will carry a special meaning for a Chinese doctor and his fiancee, for it will be their first opportunity since 1937 to welcome a new year together, it was disclosed yesterday. The next chapter in their story-book romance will be written next week when they marry.

The nine-story building at 374- 82 Fifth Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-fifth Street, has been sold by James R. Roosevelt and Helen Roosevelt Robinson to a syndicate of investors headed by Louis Kramer. It is under lease to Best Co., who recently announced plans for a new store building to occupy the site of the old Union Club and adjoining houses at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Pravda said today that steady American victories in the Pacific had "sharply worsened economic, especially food, conditions inside Japan," and also declared that the frequent Superfortress raids on Tokyo were affecting the general Japanese internal and political situation.
KANDY, Ceylon, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Undersecretary of War Robert P. Patterson warned today that Japan has a "formidable" war machine and said he has "found nothing to support the notion that we can dispose of Japan in short order, once Germany is finally beaten."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The increasingly critical tire shortage has caused the Office of Defense Transportation to abandon all thought of relaxing the thirty-five-mile-an-hour speed limit for highway travel.

Excepting for the usual defections and other hazards of theatrical producing, the month of January will bring to Broadway at least nine attractions. Nine other shows are ready but are marking time because of the lack of housing facilities.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- A communique, as broadcast from Berlin:
MADRID, Dec. 29 -- One of the strongest anti-Communist editorials yet to appear in the Spanish press, one that expressed alarm, appeared in yesterday's issue of the newspaper Ya.

At the end of a long road paved with vicissitudes, "Trio" finally reached New York, and the Belasco Theatre, last evening. For his persistence in trying to find a house for the Dorothy and Howard Baker play, Lee Sabinson, its producer, deserves the praise of the theatre.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Miss Anne Kathleen Cullen, 26 years old, a Red Cross staff assistant, was killed Dec. 20 in a bombing of a hospital in Belgium, her parents were notified yesterday by the Red Cross.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- The Army has made a frontal attack on this pioneer mountain community and today the service men have complete control of the situation.

Holding that the 20 per cent Federal excise tax on handbags is discriminatory against women, the National Authority for the Ladies' Handbag Industry will seek removal of the levy when the new Congress meets after the turn of the year, it was stated yesterday by Abraham Mittenthal, who, with Max Berkowitz, is co-director of the Authority.

No memorial would be necessary to keep the memory of Alfred E. Smith in the minds and hearts of his old neighbors of the lower East Side. They will remember him to the end of their lives as a friend who stayed with them in the spirit long after the exigencies of a great career had taken him away from the house on Oliver Street.
St. John's undefeated Redmen, with a skein of six straight triumphs, will tangle with Dartmouth's White Mountain Indians in the feature game of tonight's cage double-header at Madison Square Garden.

An organized advertising campaign in support of British leather goods is being conducted in South American newspapers, it was learned yesterday. The advertisements principally are along institutional lines, but at the same time fair-sized quantities of newly imported British leather goods are being offered for sale by retail establishments, particularly in Argentina and Brazil, according to industry interests here.

The Army-Navy E award was presented yesterday to Times Telephoto Equipment, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and its men and women employes at a special ceremony in THE TIMES club room, 229 West Forty-third Street, before company workers and military and management representatives.

Through transcontinental passenger train service, without changing cars en route, may become a post-war reality, C. E. Newton, president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, said yesterday in Cleveland. He maintained that such steps by the railroads were necessary to meet competition from other forms of transport, and revealed that studies were under way looking toward the elimination of wait-over of passengers at Chicago and St. Louis, the breaking points of cross-country train travel.

Horace C. Stoneham, president of the Giants, received two letters yesterday to which he pointed with pardonable pride. One was from Maj. Paul J. Hanna, attached to headquarters of the airborne division now battling in Belgium, hanking the Giant organization for the part Manager Mel Ott was playing with the USO outfit now engaged in entertaining troops behind the combat lines.

Lee S. Buckingham, former State director of the Office of Price Administration, will be the next president of the New York Athletic Club, according to the slate recently announced by the nominating committee. Buckingham will succeed Gilbert B.J. Frawley, who has served as head of the club for two years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A slight amount of Allied shipping, now burdened to the maximum with military transport, has been promised to aid in sending relief to the liberated peoples of Europe, Herbert H. Lehman, director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, told a press conference today on his return from a six weeks' visit to England and France.

Plans for a series of projects, including a school in this city for sub-normal children and a training center for social workers and nurses, were disclosed yesterday by Dr. Ernest Harms, executive director of the Foundation for Child Care and Nervous Child Help.

Two-way trade with the United States, involving the products of cooperative factories in Scotland and increased purchases of goods here, will be sought by the Scottish Cooperative Wholesale Society of Glasgow, according to William Hewitt, a director of the society.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Jeff Donnell has been assigned by Columbia to the second feminine lead in "Over 21," the Ruth Gordon play which will be put into production Wednesday with Irene Dunne in the starring part. Miss Donnell is to have the role of Jan Lupton, which was portrayed by Beatrice Pearson in the Music Box presentation of the piece.
