WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Several flights of American planes, presumably all Superfortresses, were reported by the Tokyo radio to be over the Japanese homeland in the twenty-four-hour period ending at 9 P.M. (Japanese time) today.

A suit to test the legality of the new zoning amendments recently adopted by the Board of Estimate over the protests of many real estate and civic organizations was filed yesterday in Supreme Court by the 431 Fifth Avenue Corporation, a realty company, against the City of New York, with the Citizens Zoning Committee joining in the suit.

BASTOGNE, Belgium, Dec. 29 -- The commander of Bastogne's valorous 10,000 who made history with a single word -- "nuts" -- was 46-year-old Brig. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe. He was acting commander of the 101st Airborne Division and odds and ends of the United States Third Army's Ninth and Tenth Armored Divisions that had been thrown in hurriedly to stem the German rush toward Sedan.

Old-time telegraphers not only had a keen ear for Morse code but possessed a fine, Spencerian style of handwriting that is now apparently a forgotten art, William J. (Billy) Brooks, 64 years old, recalled yesterday as he looked to his retirement on Jan. 1 after fifty -one years of service with Western Union.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 29 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's divisions, now embarked on an ambitious counter-offensive, are pounding the nose and sides of the salient won by the German onslaught into Belgium.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

History never repeats itself, but strong family resemblances do occur from time to time. Many of us are now hoping that the story of Ludendorff's 1918 "victory" drives may be repeated, with a swift Nazi collapse following upon von Rundstedt's unsuccessful gamble.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 29 -- The Mexican Senate today authorized President Manuel Avila Camacho to send troops abroad whenever it is deemed necessary with a view to "collaborating in the victory of the United Nations."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Although 60 per cent of social security beneficiaries, estimated to total 1,115,000 at the end of 1944, are women and children, a large number of women do not know their rights under the social security system and so are in danger of losing their benefits, according to the Social Security Board.

In the absence of further clarification by License Commissioner Paul Moss of his announcement on Wednesday that he would prohibit the sale of theatre tickets to hit shows through brokers, theatre owners, managers, operators, producers and brokers decided yesterday on a general policy of "wait and see."
ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Saturday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A communique:
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Whatever else might happen in tomorrow's renewal of the Blue-Gray football classic, it's safe to say they'll throw more passes than a fellow with loaded dice.

PARIS, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Two hundred enlisted men and two officer, who were arrested by the Army's criminal investigation department in late November and early December, have confessed receiving more than $200,000 from the sale of stolen American cigarettes in the black market, the Army disclosed today.
ROME, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

The promotion of 211 firemen to the rank of lieutenant was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh in a special departmental order that disclosed that the men would, despite their advance in grade, continue in their present assignments.

Defeating New York University 2-1, in the fifth and final round of the annual Intercollegiate Chess League championship tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday, Brooklyn College annexed the Harold M. Phillips Trophy with a record of four straight successes, each by 2-1, for a game score of 8-4.

The stock market gave yesterday further recognition to the turn in the tide of battle on the western front in Europe with one of the strongest advances of the year Gains of 1 to 2 points were scattered liberally throughout the list, while some individual issues such as Chrysler pushed ahead 4 to 5 points.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 29 -- Ending five years of litigation over oil royalties in the Kettleman Hills oil fields, Federal Judge Campbell E. Beaumont ruled today that more than $1,500,000 in royalties on crude oil, gasoline and gas are due the Government from most of California's major oil companies.

Supreme Court Justice Frank E. Johnson refused yesterday in Brooklyn to vacate a habeas corpus order permitting the release of an alleged "Peeping Tom" and refused also to expunge the court record severely criticizing the city magistrate for holding the defendant without bail in the Brooklyn City Prison.

With dozens of poultry classes still awaiting consideration for awards at the Madison Square Garden Poultry show, harried judges turned their attention from pigeons to chickens yesterday. The show, in which 3,000 chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese and pheasants and 1,500 pigeons are entered, will continue through New Year's night.
The major leagues are going ahead with plans to operate in 1945 with 530 players, 223 of them 4-F's, on their rosters, a United Press survey of baseball manpower revealed yesterday.

A new issue of $1,500,000 water system bonds of Lebanon, Pa., will be offered for sale on Jan. 15. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 2 per cent. Dated Feb. 1, 1945, the bonds will mature serially on Feb. 1, 1946 to 1975.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Japanese broadcasts said today that a fifty-vessel American convoy, thirty transports and twenty escorting cruisers and destroyers, had been sighted heading westward from Surigao Strait through the Mindanao Sea, which washes the northern coast of Mindanao Island in the Philippines, and that the convoy had come under Japanese air attack.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 29 -- As the population of the Holy Land approaches 1945 it is evident that increasing attention is being turned by both Jews and Arabs toward those political issues that under the pressure of war events have receded in the past few years.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

IN THE MONSCHAU SECTOR, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Field Marshal Karl von Rundstedt used Hitler's favorite troops to spearhead the German drive into Belgium -- the First Adolf Hitler SS Division and the Twelfth Hitler Jugen SS Division, it was revealed today.
Holiday absenteeism affecting vital war production in the New York Ordnance District threw a shadow yesterday over the impending New Year's Eve celebration in New York City.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES in Belgium, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- German raiders who missed the target on their first two tries blasted an advanced field hospital to bits with two 500-pound bombs Wednesday, killing fifteen persons and injuring more than fifty, it can be revealed today.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Governor Dewey will recommend to the Legislature an $800,000,000 highway construction program, the largest ever proposed in the history of the State.

" Going My Way," the New York Film Critics' selection as the year's outstanding film, will be continued through New Year's Day at the Thalia Theatre. . . . "Laura" will be the feature, today through Jan. 6, at the Sixty-eighth Street Playhouse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Government will move promptly, Attorney General Biddle indicated today, for a permanent injunction against Montgomery Ward Co. after the end of next week of arguments over the request for a restraining order.

In the current discussion of a constitutional amendment to make the ratification of treaties depend upon a simple majority of the Senate and the House instead of the present two-thirds majority of the Senate alone, opponents of amendment sometimes assert that treaty-making must be done with greater caution, because treaties, once made, are more binding than ordinary laws and cannot be repealed like statutes.

ROME, Dec. 29 -- Although the authoritative Pucci agency noted yesterday that the external tone of the Pope's New Year's audiences with diplomats yesterday was scrupulously alike, it was learned today that Baron Ernst von Weiszaecker, the German Ambassador, had overstayed twenty minutes, thus upsetting the entire schedule.

Fighting under the handicap of a left eye that was closed after the first round, Morris Reif, slugging Brownsville welterweight, made a gallant but losing stand last night against trim Danny Bartfield of the East Side.

The trustees of Columbia University sold the two loft buildings at 19-21 West Thirty-sixth Street and 40-42 West Thirty-seventh Street to a syndicate represented by Glekel Drimmer, attorneys, which immediately resold the properties to two groups of tenants occupying space in the buildings.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The best claimed for Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt's offensive today by the German communique was that after heavy fighting in all sectors the situation remained materially unaltered.

The so-called "Arab menace," so often put forward to justify a policy of appeasing the Arabs in Palestine and elsewhere, has never been so fallacious as it is now, when the Arabs are more in need than ever before of the sympathy, money and political support of the Allies, especially after the "neutral" role their leaders and rulers have played in Great Britain's direst need.

PEARL HARBOR, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Liberators of the Pacific Strategic Air Force have bombed Iwo Island in the Volcanos for the twenty-first consecutive day of a sustained campaign to knock out Japan's sole airblock on the route from Saipan to Tokyo, a Pacific Fleet headquarters announcement reported today.

TASTE is incalculable. Some men choose to be coal miners, others to be dramatic critics. Like the miners, the critics have to forsake daylight, to drudge in the dark, to light the scene from their own heads and to take the run of the mine. Once, in the crusading days of Bernard Shaw, it was like gold mining. In these sober days, with the theatre encroached upon, it seems decidedly coal.

WITH THE SEVENTH UNITED STATES ARMY, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- A number of patients, including soldiers awaiting surgery, were injured Tuesday night when two low-flying German planes bombed and strafed in bright moonlight the American Twenty-third General Hospital at Mirecourt, a Sixth Army Group communique disclosed today.

SPAGHETTI BOWL HEAD-QUARTERS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A football coach apparently is the same all over. The crying towel here is a piece torn off the tail of a G.I. shirt but Major George A. Miller, Indiana center of the Nineteen Thirties, who is bossing the Twelfth Air Force Bridgebusters for their New Year's Day game with the Fifth Army, is giving it the same old-fashioned workout it gets back home.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Saturday, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Twenty-three Japanese planes, eight of which were shot down, raided installations on Mindoro Island in the western Philippines Wednesday night and caused some damage, an Allied communique said today.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 29 -- The United States Patent Office wrote finis this week to what may prove to be one of its leanest years in recent times. Only 28,000 mechanical patents were granted in 1944, a drop of 10 per cent under the number granted in 1943.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 29 (AP) - Communique 265:
In her letter to THE TIMES which appeared on Dec. 21, Mrs. A. A. Ferrari calls attention to what she terms a definite inequality in electric rates by reason of bimonthly billing.

Broadway is to start the new year with one of its oldest troubles, that of theatre tickets. License Commissioner Paul Moss has just ruled that when the demand for tickets to certain shows far exceeds the supply -- the hits and smash hits -- he will ask the managers to sell all seats at the box office or by mail, cutting off allotments to the brokers.

LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Berlin military commentators focused the home front's attention tonight on the southern flank of Field Marshal Gen. Karl yon Runstedt's front, where Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's sledge-hammer blows sobered the hitherto optimistic broadcasts.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- Negotiations with Britain regarding the means of payment for raw materials that the French expect to import for industries -- negotiations paralleling those conducted by Jean Monnet in Washington -- have not been completed but are continuing optimistically, it was learned authoritatively today.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 30 -- Russian shock battalions smashed into new sections of encircled Budapest from the west yesterday and began slaughtering a trapped Axis garrison in hand-to-hand fighting raging through streets clogged with enemy dead and wrecked guns and tanks, the Soviet High Command announced at midnight.

LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The British Navy is assembling two mighty fleets with greatly reinforce carrier strength to help the Americans deal knockout blows to the Japanese in the Pacific in 1945, it was disclosed tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- A registration statement covering 199,847 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock and an equal number of subscription warrants was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., tobacco manufacturers.

The four-story business building at 363 East 149th Street, between Third and Courtlandt Avenues, the Bronx, has been sold by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company to the Schwamm Realty and Security Corporation. The property is assessed at $45,000 and was sold for cash.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP) - The National Cooperative Finance Association, Chicago, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the proposed issuance and sale of 2,500 shares of preferred capital stock at $100 a share.

ROME, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Swarms of Allied planes, coming to the defense of the Fifth Army on Italy's long-stalemated Ligurian coastal sector, have halted the three-day German drive, Allied headquarters announced today, as American troops, seizing the initiative, reoccupied high ground south of Gallicano.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 29 -- J.A. Krug, chairman of the War Production Board, indicated today that programs for expanding production of military tires and other essential rubber products will encounter serious shortages of raw materials before the desired output levels are reached.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 29 -- Negotiations between high American Army officials and Swiss bankers and industrialists for an equitable solution of the "blocked" dollar controversy for the delivery of industrial purchases direct to the American forces in France were reliably reported in Swiss circles here tonight to be on the point of successful conclusion.

Somber events of the past two weeks on the Western Front have cruelly belied the cheerful predictions of official and unofficial soothsayers regarding early victory. Surely, as the new year draws near and brings with it the custom of making New Year's resolutions, Allied statesmen, military commanders and civilian leaders could well ponder the advisability of jettisoning their habit of painting the war's end as just around the corner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Office of Price Administration announced changes in two rationing orders today that will enable retailers and wholesalers of meats and retailers of processed foods to adjust their ration-point inventories if they suffer hardship caused by restoration of points to formerly unrationed foods, and that will tighten sugar rationing regulations as they apply to wholesalers and retailers.

The consolidated report of the Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., for the quarter ended on Oct. 31, disclosed yesterday a net profit of $5,603,094 after all charges including $12,678,980 income and excess profits taxes.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The stock markets here are cheered today by the better war news and more activity was seen, especially in the home-rails section. Gains up to a half point were recorded on the plans for post-war development and the fairly high yields, and it is believed to be possible that this market will attract more of the surplus money available for investment in the immediate future.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Chairman John Letellier of the Fair Grounds Breeders and Racing Association today requested of War Mobilization Director James F. Byrnes that the deadline on horse racing be extended from Jan. 13 to Jan. 31 in order to avoid the "distress and hardship to the horsemen, their families and attendants that would be caused by an early shutdown at the New Orleans track."

ONE of the nicest things about the Christmas season is that it brings in a flood of mail. The recipients never utter one word of protest. Only the overworked and overburdened letter-carriers might be inclined to raise an objection or two, but Christmas only comes once a year anyway and so they generally suffer in silence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Roosevelt killed by "pocket veto" today the bill which would have abolished the 221,610-acre Jackson Hole Monument in Wyoming which he established by executive order on March 15, 1943. Congress had refused twice in ten years to approve this scenic acquisition as an extension to the Grand Teton National Park.

After next Wednesday those tried before Magistrate Ambrose J. Haddock and found guilty of book-making will be jailed instead of fined, even though they are first offenders, the Magistrate warned yesterday in the Jefferson Market Court, when he fined thirteen defendants a total of $1,100 for having accepted bets on horse races.
The projected visit to this country of Gunder Haegg and Haakon Lidman, Sweden's famous athletes, yesterday suffered a setback.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Invitations to participate in a national conference of white collar and professional organizations to be held here on Jan. 15 have been sent to educational, scientific, medical, cultural and related groups as well as to trade unions and other associations having professional workers in their membership.

ATHENS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- American and British correspondents today addressed appeals to both the Greek Government and the Left-Wing Elas forces, in which the newsmen asked for action in releasing Greek newspaper men of both sides "if they are being detained on account of their writings.''

Frank W. Kridel and associates in the hotel business, who bought the 600-room Hotel Martinique, at Broadway and Thirty-second Street two weeks ago, have added to their holdings by purchasing the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx for cash above a fifteen-year purchase-money mortgage of $1.087.500.

Thirteen months have passed since the historic Teheran meeting of Prime Minister Churchill, Marshal Stalin and President Roosevelt. The fact loomed large last week amid signs of differences among the "Big Three" Powers over post-war settlements and plans for world peace.

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS on Leyte, Dec. 30 -- The Japanese began to show increasing signs of desperation this week as land-based air power -- the spearhead of all Gen. Douglas MacArthur's advances up to the landing in the Philippines -- is finally coming into play again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Up in arms against proposed ceiling prices on live cattle, livestock men brought their protests to the capital today with one asserting an Office of Price Administration official has misrepresented the cattlemen's views.

Two philanthropic organizations will benefit from performances of "Seven Lively Arts" at the Ziegfeld Theatre early next month. The proceeds on Jan. 4 will augment the fund of the Juvenile Delinquency project of the Vocational Foundation, 122 East Twenty-second Street.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- The German offensive, with its implication that the war is not over and that patriots must remain vigilant, was advanced tonght by a spokesman for the Council of National Resistance as an explanation for the recrudescence of the revolutionary spirit.

OTTAWA, Dec. 30 -- In the same way that any private business concern follows, the departments of the Canadian Government have been issuing this week a year-end statement of their accomplishment, telling the people, as stockholders in the business of Canada, how their money has been earned and spent and what has been achieved.

Gold stars on the sports service flag for World War II represent more than 400 standout college varsity, professional and nationally ranked amateur athletes who have given their lives in the service of their country since Pearl Harbor.

IN his preface L.L. Bernard, Professor of Sociology at Washington University, St. Louis, explains that he wrote "War and Its Causes" in order "to put into a readable work" -- for the "intelligent general reader" as well as the "pupil and teacher" -- a "trustworthy analysis of war as a social institution and a dependable and documented exposition of the causes which lead governments and people to make war."

That part of America's western fringe which lies between Oregon and the Mexican line is reported by the California Taxpayers' Association to possess a population of 8,842,700, as compared with 8,373,800 a year ago and 6,907,367 in 1940. The county of Los Angeles -- a good deal larger than the city but tributary to it -- is estimated at about 3,441,000 citizens.

License Commissioner Paul Moss yesterday officially ordered theatres housing Broadway's outstanding show hits not to sell any tickets to brokers beginning Jan. 8. Letters containing the order and signed by Mr. Moss were delivered by messenger to the theatres shortly before noon.

Summing up the year's operation of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, P.J. Lahny, district manager for the agency, announced yesterday that 1,305 prime contracts totaling $98,511,000 were awarded during 1944 to small plants in the New York district with the assistance of SWPC.

WOULDN'T it be a fine thing if all the young actors, writers and directors who return from the war could come back to a ready-and-waiting Experimental Theatre? That long-awaited, greatly needed, shamefully neglected Experimental Theatre!
ROME, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A communique:

Exaggeration of differences among the United Nations was criticized yesterday afternoon by Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information. He spoke over the Blue Network from the Metropolitan Opera House at the fifth Opera Victory Rally under the auspices of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

THIS New Year's Eve carries a double significance for the radio world. It marks not only the completion of another year but the end of the industry's first twenty-five, Station KDKA in Pittsburgh having started the transmission of regular programs in 1920.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, declared today that the Government could not fairly have one policy for dealing with employers who defied War Labor Board decisions and another for unions, and said that if legislation were necessary to remedy that "fatal defect" the Administration should so report and he would be happy to sponsor it.

TO many people Frances Willard and the Women's Christian Temperance Union are inseparable. From her election as president of that organization, in 1879, until her death, in 1898, she dominated its development and the formulation of its policies.

The phenomenal increase in the value of stocks owned by Vicomte Gabriel de Fontarce, a French citizen, who died in London on June 11, 1941, was disclosed in papers on file in Surrogate's Court in an application made by Public Administrator James F. Egan, who petitioned Surrogate James A. Foley for advice and directions as to the propriety, price and manner of selling the securities.
Sidney Schwartz, Erasmus Hall racquet wielder, retained the boys' Eastern tennis title yesterday.

ON many a homemaker's New Year's resolution list will be -- or should be -- an unshakable memorandum to "do something about those closets." It's a good idea at any time of any year, and it's especially important right now when good clothes or anything wearable ought to be pampered like heirlooms.

THIS is a revealing book; more revealing even than the frank and loquacious Mr. Pepper intended it to be. It gives a more illuminating picture or Pennsylvania conservatism, with all its virtues and defects, than perhaps any other volume in print.

SO much publicity has recently been given the field of musical therapy or music in hospitals that I hope the following letter will be considered timely enough to be brought to your readers' attention.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Muhlenberg defeated Pennsylvania by, 42 -- 38 tonight to register its ninth straight victory of the basketball season before 9,000 at Convention Hall.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Probably more space was devoted to penicillin than to any other medical subject during the last year. That most miraculous germ-killer will probably prove to be effective in relapsing fever, secondary abscesses of the brain, anthrax, Haverhill fever, parrot fever, peritonitis, syphilis and sub-acute endocarditis.

PANAMA, Dec. 30 -- The political crisis, which began with the suspension of the Constitution of 1941 by Presidential decree yesterday, remained unsolved tonight. Acting President Ricardo Adolfo de la Guardia is still conferring with political leaders, apparently seeking a coalition Cabinet.

AS regards new recordings, we are now in that darkest moment just before dawn. Post-ban recordings are expected to make their appearance within the next few weeks, but meanwhile the flow of new albums has dwindled to a trickle, and not-too-refreshing trickle at that.

Surgeon General Norman T. Kirk of the Army, and Rear Admiral Edward U. Reed, chief medical officer, Third Naval District, are scheduled to speak at an emergency meeting Thursday at 8 P.M. in the Hotel Pierre, to arouse public assistance in providing enough nurses for the armed forces, it was announced yesterday.

Upward of $1,000,000,000 will be spent for store modernization and improvements shortly after the ending of the war by members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, according to a conservative projection based upon returns from the questionnaire on proposed post-war expenditures, issued by the post-war planning committee of the association.

What goes on in government and industrial laboratories and on the front these days is a military secret. Sometimes news trickles out that cannot be suppressed. It was thus that we learned of the advances made in jet-propulsion, winged rocket bombs, airplanes and DDT.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- In a royal proclamation here today, King George II of Greece virtually renounced his throne unless the people of Greece, in a free election, call him back to rule. He has appointed Archbishop Damaskinos as his Regent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, have called upon all labor in war plants to stay on the job New Year's Day.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 30 -- New Year's greetings to the German people from Nazi leaders on the home front asserted that, whatever course the war took in 1945, there would be no doubt it would end in German victory.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Seven of the nation's leading football coaches predicted today that, war or no war, 1945 would see an increase in the quantity if not the quality of college gridiron teams.

After a telephone conversation with Governor Dewey, Miss Jane Todd, acting Republican State chairman, issued yesterday a call for a meeting of the State committee to be held Wednesday afternoon, Jan. 10, in the Hotel Ten Eyck in Albany to elect a chairman to succeed Edwin F. Jaeckle, who resigned soon after the election.

TO their neighbors in the Lowlands the people of the Carolina Up-Country seemed in the generations which grew up before the Civil War a priggish lot. To the Up-Country folk the Lowlanders were very little better than the wicked, if any -- what with theatre going and balls and horse racing and the Charleston accent.

SINCE the start of rationing women have thought more about good food and talked more about it than they ever did when butter and steak and roquefort cheese all fitted into the accepted scheme of things. Forced by shortages to summon up their best efforts, they have prepared meals that have not infrequently been flavored with greater imagination than was ever displayed in the old days.
Yesterday's communique, as broadcast from Moscow to the Soviet Union and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

Nineteen-year-old Pfc. Howard Mofenson, convalescing somewhere in England from a foot amputation, took part in a special British Broadcasting Corporation program yesterday and spoke to his parents over a radio and telephone wire hook-up because they could not wait to hear him at the regular radio time today.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Hundreds of veteran American soldiers were indignant tonight over an item in the Army newspaper Stars and Stripes which said that the American Legion Post in Hood River Ore., had advised Americans of Japanese ancestry to sell any property they owned and leave town.
Avowing unshakable faith in Adolf Hitler, Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt, Commander in Chief of German forces on the Western Front, issued a new year's message to his troops.

Chairman George of the Senate Finance Committee holds forth the hope of a 10 per cent tax cut in 1945 if we should come within sight of the end of the war in Europe. Eager as we should all be to see such a tax cut if the Government could afford it, it still seems in the realm of pleasant fantasy.

Although not given to crystal-gazing, the season seems to call for some sort of forecast, so this department firmly and unequivocally predicts that there will be no Government ban on hunting and fishing during 1945.
A warning to all persons who sublet their apartments here for the winter to register with the nearest Office of Price Administration rent office was issued yesterday by the OPA.

" THE MAGIC YEAR" is a novel written by Joachim Maass, one of the most successful of the young German writers of the pre-Hitler era. This is the first of his works to be published in the United States and is the first volume of a trilogy which will bear the title "Astride the Times."
CHUNGKING, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Building in November was nearly $14,000,000 below the October total, Secretary Perkins reported today. The chief factor was a decline of 29 per cent in Federal building.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Machinery to handle disputes in the telephone industry was created today by the National War Labor Board with the appointment of Pearce Davis and Henry J. Meyer as chairman and vice chairman of a National Telephone Industry Panel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Army and Navy Journal, in an editorial today on the German counter-offensive in the west, asserted that "this is no time to cry about blunders and errors, to denounce the failure of American intelligence, as did General March, Chief of Staff in World War I."

Many persons of prominence have subscribed to the piano recital to be given by George Copeland on the night of Jan. 12 at Carnegie Hall. From the net proceeds of his recital Mr. Copeland will make a substantial contribution to the 1945 Red Cross War Fund.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Universal military training is a "necessity" but it "should be limited to training for national defense in an emergency and not become part of a Federal system for general education," Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, said today.

Mrs. Busch Greenough, executive chairman of the opera party to be given in the interests of the Grenfell Association of America, will hold a meeting and reception Friday in her apartment at the St. Regis for the sponsors, vice chairmen, patrons, patronesses and committee members.
MONTREAL, Dec. 30 -- The Montreal Canadiens lengthened their first-place margin in the National Hockey League tonight when they turned back the New York Rangers, 4 -- 1, before about 11,000 fans.

The second of the two Mayfair Assemblies arranged for this season took place last night on the St. Regis Roof, with a large attendance of debutantes of this winter and last, and young men in the armed forces who are stationed in this area or are in the city on leave.

Mrs. Elizabeth Lowe, 82-year-old recluse, was found dead of gas poisoning shortly before midnight on Friday in the two-and-one-half-room flat she occupied at 516 East Fourteenth Street. Police described her death as accidental, saying she had inadvertently turned on the jet of a one-burner gas range.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- James F. Byrnes, director of War Mobilization, refused today requests to modify his ban on horse and dog racing tracks, effective Jan. 3.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Communities scattered along the West Coast retained chips on their shoulders this week as the time drew near when all "loyal or harmless" persons of Japanese ancestry would be free to go and come in California, Oregon and Washington, a privilege denied them since the 1942 evacuation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Senator Wheeler, Democrat of Montana, proposed today that the Senate formally proclaim its own peace aims, "in the absence of the President's taking a stand."

EVER since Columbus discovered America on the basis of a grave misapprehension, literary explorers of this continent have tended to follow his example. Certainly we have been discovered in print more often and more inaccurately than any other country in the world.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Archbishop Damaskinos, who becomes the principal figure on the Greek political scene with his appointment as Regent, long has been considered an expert in matters of state.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 30 -- New Zealand will be able to provide four bases for use by the British Pacific Fleet, three of which have docks that accommodate cruisers, the Defense Ministry said today.

The Soviet-sponsored Hungarian Provisional Government has declared war on Germany and asked the Allies for the conclusion of an armistice, the Moscow radio announced last night in broadcasts reported by the Federal Communications Commission.

New York's millions, in common with others throughout the nation, prepared to welcome the New Year at midnight tonight with prayers that the "five" in 1945 would spell "V" for victory and an enduring peace. Watch night and holy hour services will be held at midnight in hundreds of churches, in addition to the regular services during the day, but the traditional festive greeting to the New Year also will be observed.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Has something gone askew with the coordination of military strategy as well as of political planning among the Big Three of the United Nations? That is a question that is troubling many persons who do not have access to the secrets of Teheran and Quebec.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Fred M. Vinson, Director of Stabilization, approved tonight wage adjustments ordered by the War labor Board in the basic steel case directly affecting 400,000 members of the CIO United Steel Workers employed by eighty-six companies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 -- College and university students of Japanese ancestry, in undetermined numbers, are expected to resume their studies in West Coast institutions with the lifting of restrictions by the Army next week.

The Neediest Cases Fund for 1944 has reached a total of $290,836.98 today, the final Sunday of the thirty-third annual Christmas appeal. Responding quickly and generously, 10,765 readers of this newspaper have contributed this splendid total to aid the families and individuals in greatest want in the city known to seven leading private charity organizations.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS ON LEYTE, Sunday, Dec. 31 -- Two of the Japanese divisions smashed to pieces on Leyte were veteran groups from Manchuria, Gen. Douglas MacArthur disclosed today. These were the First Infantry Division, which saw service in Manchuria as early as 1937 and came to Leyte directly from the Kwantung army, and the Eighth Division, which was stationed on Manchuria for "several years" before coming to Leyte.

ROME, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Germans have speeded the movement of troops and material in the western coastal sector of the Italian front, and the situation in this area, where the enemy has pressed a counter-attack all week, remains "fluid," the Allies' command announced today.

Recommendations that war veterans not be segregated from the regular student body and that dormitories for housing 1,600 additional students be constructed "as soon as possible" after the war, were contained in the University of Kentucky's post-war planning committee report, which has been completed after a year's study of all phases of the problem.

The Rev. George Merle Whitmore will preach at 5 P.M. today his final sermon as minister-in-charge of the John Hall Memorial Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 342 East Sixty-third Street. He submitted his resignation to the session of the Fifth Avenue Church last November, after serving for fourteen years, and that body acted on it at its December meeting.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 30 -- The appointment of Richard W. Colman Jr., line coach at Williams since 1939, and Judson A. Timm, backfield coach at Yale for three seasons, to the Princeton football staff was announced today by Dean Christian Gauss, chairman of the Princeton Council on Athletics.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- A brilliant array of men and women participated in the thrilling downhill races which launched the annual Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' college week ski games today at Mount Whitney. The Army Ground and Service Forces Redistribution Center authorities are cooperating in staging the three-day meet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, Norwegian Ambassador to the United States, in a statement today expressed confidence that Norway would be liberated in 1945.

NOT quite eighty years have passed since Baudelaire's death. During that time his reputation has risen surely and steadily. He seems today one of the two or three great French poets of his century, one of the few whose work has, in its logical content as distinct from its poetic texture, very much to say to the present age.

AS the year comes to an end an atmosphere of caution, governed to a great degree by the uncertainty of the post-war era, appears to pervade all studios. Production expenses continued to rise steadily during the year and, scene for scene, it cost more to make pictures in 1944 than in 1943.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Army and the Veterans Administration are beginning to put into operation probably the greatest mass, free educational program ever devised. However, some Educators question whether this program is being directed into channels of maximum benefit.

THE first semester of the Broadway season having passed -- counting from June 1 -- custom ordains that Tecumseh take inventory of sundry facts and figures, meaning, of course, those piles of scrap paper, old envelopes and menus that he has been so diligently accumulating.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- On high authority here it was said tonight that Premier Stalin counts upon the French Government's support for the Russian view that the Dumbarton Oaks security scheme must permit a great power, accused of aggression, to vote with the other powers as one of the judges in its own case.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- The gunnery secrets of the Northrop Black Widow fighter were revealed today by the General Electric Company with the permission of the War Department.
Whatever 1945 holds in store for football in a war-torn world, the new year will start tomorrow with the usual array of bowl attractions and the all-star Shrine game for charity at San Francisco.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 30 -- Brazil will enter 1945 leading all Latin-American nations industrially and planning greater agricultural development. Her finances are in better condition after the correction of ills that impaired trade growth and irked importers and exporters.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Federal Judge George H. Moore today overruled a motion of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation to reopen a plagiarism case involving the motion picture "Alexander's Ragtime Band," and issued an injunction to prevent further showing of the film.

THE year closing today has been philatelically another prolific period. To date 111 governments have reported the issuing of 1,765 major and minor varieties of stamps, including about 800 attributed to war conditions.

About 80 per cent of the men treated and cared for at the seven rest centers maintained jointly by United Seamen's Service and the War Shipping Administration have returned to active duty, a number sufficient to man 100 war-cargo ships with healthy, experienced personnel, Douglas P. Falconer, USS executive director, said here yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 -- Well-heeled bettors daring a final fling risked $752,200 at Tropical Park today to set a new track wagering record for the second time during this final full week of racing. With only two more days of the sport remaining before the Government ban becomes effective, the crowd of 8,954 bet an average of more than $85 per person, on a nine-race card.

ROME, Dec. 30 -- The Allies have not recognized the Committee of National Liberation as the organization representing all the anti-Fascist parties in north Italy, Premier Ivanoe Bonomi told the Cabinet today.

STOCKHOLM, Dec. 30 -- Reich newspapers contain many glowing accounts of the exploits of German saboteurs behind the Allied lines in France and Belgium, and some stories are even signed by German "PK men," combat reporters accompanying sabotage units.

As the merchandise availability picture becomes clearer it seems probable that more goods will be available for distribution on allotments for the time being than seemed possible when the new Government freeze was first announced, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

Although the caliber of play was admittedly below past standards, the American League saw 22 records broken or equaled during the 1944 baseball season, according to official statistics announced yesterday.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN BELGIUM, Sunday, Dec. 31 -- How and why did the Germans break through the Allied positions on the western front?

WITH AMERICAN FORCES, on the Western Front, Dec. 30 -- There is an old saying about the loss of a nail that caused the loss of a shoe that caused the loss of a horse and so on until this lost nail had lost a rider, a battle and a kingdom. A parallel to this, but in reverse, might be written out of the battle now raging on the American First front.

In the area of Budapest our troops waged battles aimed at the annihilation of the encircled enemy groupings. * * * The battlefields are littered with the corpses of Hitlerites, smashed arms and equipment of the enemy.

" THIS race and this country and this life produced me," declares Stephen Dedalus -- artistic image of James Joyce himself -- in "A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man." "A Portrait" is the story of how Stephen was produced, how he rejected that which produced him, how he discovered that his destiny was to become a lonely one of artistic creation.

RHIZOMATOUS begonias, many of them in bloom now are second only to wax begonias in suitability for house-plant use. All begonias with thick, creeping stems fall into the rhizomatous group. Best loved perhaps for their ornamental foliage, many are even more attractive as they come into flower on otherwise drab winter days.
Here are two episodes out of the experiences of an American soldier in France. They are from letters he wrote home.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The English translation of the royal decla ration by King George II of Greece providing for establishment of a Regency follows:
A communique, as transmitted Friday night by the New Yugoslav Telegraph, Service and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

The year ends, and crows spread their black wings and echo their black cries over the naked woodland. Jays jeer in the winter sun and the sweet chitter of the chickadee is scarcely heard. Time runs out on the calendar. Winter is upon us, ice on the stream, frost in the earth.

Victory No. 6 in the unblemished skein of the St. John's University basketball team was the most notable of the campaign for the Brooklyn Redmen. Last night at Madison Square Garden, the smartly drilled lads from over the river claimed as their latest victim a court-wise Dartmouth aggregation that was expected, at least, to give St. John's its toughest test.

THERE is no more difficult field of writing, none in which true excellence is less frequently achieved, than writing about nature. The Thoreaus and the Hudsons are the rarest of literary species, for beyond skill in language there is needed a combination of capacities that is seldom the possession of a single writer.

THE poetry of Keats is never dead. Yet for twenty years after his Roman death, in the deep nadir of his reputation, it seemed that his virtues as poet could not survive the slings and arrows of what might have been, very literally, an outrageous fortune.

Establishment of a State Economic Council and an Enterprise Finance Corporation to stimulate continuous full employment after the war is urged by the Liberal party in its program to be presented to the State Legislature, made public yesterday by John L. Childs, State Chairman, and Alex Rose, chairman of its administrative committee.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- United States Strategic Air Forces headquarters reported today that American bombs had done heavy damage to rail facilities at Frankfort and Bingen yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- On the third day after the Army's seizure of Montgomery Ward properties here and in six other cities under Presidential decree, the company's books remained in their regular places and the company insisted that the Army had no right to make use of them.

BALBOA, C.Z., Dec. 30 (AP) -- President Ricardo Adolfo de la Guardia of Panama declined tonight to resign, as demanded by a group of political leaders, lawyers and business men known as the Junta de Notables.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 31 -- Red Army tanks and infantry smashed into the streets of industrial Pest, eastern half of Budapest, yesterday for the first time after the Nazis had rejected a Red Army ultimatum by killing two Soviet emissaries carrying surrender terms under flags of truce.

EVERY day, on some country road, a mail carrier stops at an R.F.D. box and leaves a letter marked "War and Navy Departments' V-Mail Service," or an envelope stamped "U.S. Army Postal Service." From India, Australia and the islands of the South Pacific; from Africa, Italy and the cold reaches of the North Atlantic, the letters arrive.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Immediate action for the removal of Alexander T. Dolan, investigator for the Albany County Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, was recommended today by George P. Monaghan, special prosecutor in the grand jury investigation of Albany.

TO the public that tunes in when a great orchestra plays Beethoven or when the President gives a fireside chat, radio is linked primarily with Marconi and with Lee De Forest, the one because he put "wireless" on its commercial feet, the other because he invented the vacuum-tube without which it is doubtful if broadcasting would have become the powerful instrument of mass appeal that it is.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 30 -- Joltin' Joe DiMaggio, who gave up baseball for an Army Air Forces uniform two years ago, today answered cryptically fans who asked if he'd be back in center field for the New York Yankees next spring.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Army's Southern Defense Command will be absorbed by the Eastern Command, effective Monday, the War Department announced today.

A VILLAGE IN BELGIUM, Dec. 29 (Delayed) -- It would be easy to say that the morale of the people near the rear of the Western Front was "wonderful," for in many respects it is. Nevertheless they are suffering badly from the shock of having the Germans sweep back to within a few miles of their homes.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Berlin broadcasts today ranged from veiled threats of a new offensive by Field Marshal Gen. Karl yon Rundstedt to a negative claim that "we have at least foiled the enemy's plan for a winter offensive."

CAPT. JOHN PATRICK of the American Field Service, author of the new play, "The Hasty Heart," first began to write while going to boarding schools. The plural -- schools -- is correct. The captain, then plain John, of course, attended a great many boarding schools in the deep South and the far West for as long as each would have him, or he them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- With the arrival around New Year's Day of Jesus T. Pinero, new Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico, Washington, particularly the Capitol Hill segment, expects to be hearing a lot more about our largest island possession to the south.

Dr. Juan Negrin, Prime Minister of the last Republican Government of Spain, will not address a demonstration in Madison Square Garden Tuesday evening because the British Foreign Office has refused broadcasting facilities, it was announced last night by Miss Freda Kirchwey, president of the Nation Associates, sponsors of the meeting.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday within a 6-point range and closed 1 point higher to 3 points lower than on Friday. The opening was 2 points up to 1 point down. Year-end price fixing was small and offerings continued light. Most of the liquidation was in the distant months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Summing up the latest sports news breaks in the nation's capital -- and more optimistically:

More than 1,000 cases were handled by the Veterans Advisory and Rehabilitation Department of the National Catholic Community Service at its center at 17 East Fifty-first Street in 1944, its first year of operation, according to a report made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of commodity prices in primary markets again advanced slightly -- 0.2 per cent -- during the week ended on last Saturday and was at the highest level since the war began.

Women's Naval Uniforms, Inc., 521 West Fifty-seventh Street, which will be succeeded tomorrow by a new company, Women's Naval Service Corporation, received yesterday a Navy Department citation for eighteen months of service in the procurement and distribution of women's uniforms.

Stocks ended 1944 with prices close to the best levels of the year. On the final day movements were mixed, with gains moderately extended. For the third time this month sales for a two-hour session crossed the million-share mark, registering 1,016,440 shares, against 529,850 on the preceding Saturday and 1,021,340 on Dec. 16.
SCENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Owen D. Young and Gerard Swope announced today their resignations as directors of the General Electric Company, effective tomorrow.

Four directors are to be elected at the annual meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club the second Tuesday in March. Three directors automatically are retired and there is a vacancy to be filled in the present class of 1948 caused by the death of Adolph H. Kramer.

THE profile line will be the focus of interest in future hair styles, according to M. Louis, hair designer. In his three variations of the new line shown here the hair is divided into three sections. The section at the temple is waved slightly; the top of the head and the back are brushed together and lifted to the center of the back with a complete twist of the hand, then fastened.
A year ago the Axis held more than 20,000,000 square miles of the earth's land and sea areas. Today the Axis holds 13,581,000 square miles.

EVIDENCE that railroad employes are awake to the importance of keeping the good-will of the public is found in round-table conferences being held once a week by the New Haven and voluntarily attended by trainmen, ticket sellers, information clerks, station masters and other workers who meet the public.

The New Year ought to be a good time for the Government of the United States to set about clarification of its foreign policy. It is certainly no secret that there are doubts in other countries about our post-war role, as indeed there are doubts about our political war role. There is too much uncertainty about where we stand on various international problems which are claiming the attention of our Allies.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Reports that a reorganization of the Allies' command on the western front was imminent were prominently displayed today by the London press.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- French military quarters said today that the class of 1944, consisting of 20-year-olds, will be called upon to begin pre-military training about the same time the 21-year-olds start their regular military instruction at the end of January in accordance with the Cabinet's decision yesterday.

While praising the intent of the meeting of the Joint Maritime Commission of the International Labor Organization, opening on Jan. 8 in London, as "an important step toward the economic emancipation of merchant seamen," Dr. Alexander S. Lipsett, economist and maritime labor specialist, sounded a note of caution yesterday against excessive optimism on the conference's outcome.

The intensive development of the communications systems and guarantees to retain their use as mediums for the free flow of news, were advocated yesterday by speakers at a meeting of the Woman's Press Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 30 -- This section of the United States is not happy over our Government's role in world affairs, as 1944 draws to a close. The Upper South has been strongly in favor of a vigorously internationalist attitude in Washington, and the feeling prevails that opportunities have been over-looked there in recent months to make our influence felt in other capitals, notably London and Moscow, and to promote the building of world understanding.

Plans for the establishment of a "substantial number" of schools and colleges in Europe, to provide free educational facilities for American soldiers on an unprecedented scale, have been completed by the War Department. It is estimated that at a very minimum several hundred American-operated schools will rise in the European theatre soon after the end of active military operations.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The Court of Appeals unanimously ruled today that the State War Council acted constitutionally in April, 1943, when it adopted a resolution giving OPA rules and regulations the effect of State law and making violations thereof punishable in State courts.
A PAINTING by Charles Burchfield, "The Great Elm," has recently been presented to the Carnegie Institute for its permanent collection by Mrs. James H. Beal.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, ALLIED EXPEDITIONARY FORCE (Wireless). THE winds of the new year blowing across the wasted fields of Europe from the dark green and white of the German hills to the Normandy beaches bear the words of fighting men, messages they do not write home, messages they do not speak save in the still of night huddled over a tiny fire in an old bucket in the corner of a dugout.

The recent survey conducted by the Family Welfare Association among its 228 member agencies in the United States and Canada gives encouraging support to the recruitment program now under way to attract more students to enter the social-work field The study found that fifty family welfare agencies in twenty States made available $114.360 in scholarship grants to enable 140 students to enroll in professional schools of social work during 1944.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine appeared recently an article by Prof. Clair Wilcox entitled, "We Can't Live Alone and Really Live." The implication of the article is designed to impress the American public with the idea that the American tariff system has been one to repel exchange of goods between this country and other countries throughout the world.
The sharp dissensions and political difficulties among the Allies are aggravated by events in the international labor camp of which the American public seems scarcely aware.

IN fresh, clear colors Elizabeth Orton Jones has made engaging pictures of a little old man and a little old woman, a fluffy cat named Miranda, two babies who appeared on the kitchen hearth in a basket covered with a pink and white blanket and a troop of baby angels who luckily arrived at the same time to help the old people.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- In its second issue a newly founded weekly journal of the Polish Peasant party, Jutro Polski, which is said to reflect the views of former Premier Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, charged today that elements of the present Polish Government of Premier Tomasz Arciszewski have been gambling on a Soviet defeat and have been courting isolationist support in the United States of their claims for Poland.

CONTINUING its policy of giving young American singers a chance to display their talents, the Metropolitan Opera this week will present Mimi Benzell, an attractive young lyric-coloratura soprano, who will make her debut in Mozart's "The Magic Flute" Friday night.

While 1944 set new records in retailing, the year closes on the grim realization that a longer war remains to be fought, pushing re-conversion plans aside and emphasizing that trade in 1945 will be entirely dependent upon the ability of retailers to obtain badly needed merchandise, according to a telegraphic and local survey of merchants' opinions made by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Office of Price Administration stated tonight that present indications pointed to a delay in validating a new shoe ration stamp until "some time next summer." This means that all those who have used airplane shoe stamps Nos. 1, 2 and 3 in War Ration Book No. 3 will not be able to get new shoes until a new stamp is issued "some time next summer."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Tokyo said today that an American convoy had arrived at the United States base on Mindoro Island, 155 miles south of Manila, after a three-day battle in which the Japanese asserted they had sunk or damaged seventeen ships.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Heightened and critical interest in America's foreign policy was apparent this week among Central Westerners, who, at the same time, discovered that the isolationists in their midst were finding encouragement for their cause as a result of recent diplomatic and military developments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Christmas Day news that the Office of Price Administration, after a period of relaxed restrictions, was putting food rationing back on a virtual 1943 and early 1944 basis, served sharp notice that bountiful spreads are as premature as victory parties.

ON Page 22 of this pictorial history of aerial combat appears a photograph of a German aviator of World War I dropping a bomb by hand over the side of his open cockpit. On page 250 a rocket from an RAF Typhoon is shown scoring a direct hit on a railroad train behind the Nazi lines, while two more rocket missiles can be seen in midair plunging toward the target.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Many Nazi spies and saboteurs, some in American uniforms, have been trapped within and around Paris by American military authorities and French police, it was disclosed tonight. In one of a number of raids on spy hangouts thirty persons were arrested.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Seventy-ninth Congress is coming in Wednesday and the belief is that it will see the war through and do much of the planning for an enduring peace through international security.

The American spirit, built upon generations of expanding opportunity, upon pride of accomplishment, upon the assumption of success, is not easily dampened. Optimism is hardy pessimism grows poorly. Even in dark times the mood is one of "This won't last." Last week the American people had just been through a particularly dark time -- a Christmas which had brought the worst news from the battlefronts since the fall of Bataan and Corregidor.

DURING recent years the local theatre has offered almost as many plays about children as any normal city block can offer the children themselves. Their heroes and heroines have ranged in age between 5 years and 16, and they have ranged in personality between the angelic and the demoniac.

THOSE who familiar with are the earlier exploits of Bill Grady will remember him as a detective who seldom makes mistakes. But in the case with which this story deals Grady is just about to arrest, albeit reluctantly, the wrong person for the murder of Dr. Hunt.

Federal tax collections for the fiscal year ending next June 30, which had been expected to amount to $47,200,000,000, are exceeding estimates, according to the Tax Institute of 257 Fourth Avenue, a research organization in public finance.

The meat shortage, coupled with "exorbitant" labor costs for extra help, will close about 70 per cent of the member-restaurants of the Society of Restaurateurs, Inc., today, New Year's Eve, and 50 per cent on New Year's Day, Paul Henkel, president of the society, said last night.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Here's The Old Farmer's Almanac in its 153d year, on time as usual and ready with a preview of 1945. The rest of this winter will be turbulent. Late February will be a tough time for orphan coal consumers. Easter falls on April 1, the Glorious Fourth on a Wednesday, Labor Day Sept. 3, Thanksgiving Nov. 22, Christmas on a Tuesday.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS ON LEYTE (By Wireless). THE field commander of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Philippines campaign is a gray-haired, solidly built soldier with prominent black eyebrows, a slightly pointed chin, big ears, thin mouth and a deeply lined face which can expand into a kindly grin or attain a scowl so forbidding that it overawes veteran fighting men who both fear and admire him.

THE social event of the month in London was the premiere of Arthur Rank's and Laurence Olivier's (also, incidentally, Shakespeare's) "Henry V." There were, in point of fact, two premieres. The official public unspooling, in aid of the Airborne Forces' and Commandos' Benevolent Fund, was a class affair.

EDDIE BRACKEN, whose rise to Hollywood stardom in the past few years is on the spectacular side, has been signed to play the lead role in a comedy show over NBC on Sunday nights at 8:30 P.M., beginning Feb. 4.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Opening of the new year will find leaders of at least three major sports groups assembling for a possible tightening of belts pursuant to the recent Federal edict placing the finger on athletic manpower.

The recent splendid letter of Orville C. Sanborn describing in detail the political and military steps to be taken to insure for future generations surcease from wars and fears of wars by predatory nations such as Germany and Japan omits, in my judgment, certain additional steps that might be taken that are so obvious as to be reason enough for their omission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Mexico's contribution to the war was praised by the State Department tonight in a statement commenting upon the passage by the Congress in Mexico City of a bill to send an air squadron to the European war theatre.

IF you picked this book up without the author's name on the title page you might guess that it was by someone who had read '"Tortilla Flat" and had decided to write a Steinbeck novel. ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS ON LEYTE, Dec. 30 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today in a proclamation that he would hold in confinement for the remainder of the war all Filipinos who have voluntarily given air or comfort to the enemy, thereafter turning them over to the Philippine Government for legal action.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Communique 266:

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 30 -- Field Marshal Karl von Rundstedt has struck with three divisions at both sides of the Bastogne salient, pointed at the heart of his shrinking bulge in Belgium and Luxembourg, a late front dispatch said tonight.

American young men of today are, on an average, nearly an inch taller than were their fathers at the time of the first World War. At a time when tax plans are being formulated with a view to an expanding post-war economy it is not inappropriate that improvements in accounting procedure should also be proposed with particular reference to the proper statement in financial reports of items entering into tax computations.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Dec. 30 (AP) -- There were two lynchings in 1944, one less than in 1943, Dr. F.D. Patterson, president of Tuskegee Institute, said today in his annual report on the subject. The report recorded five lynchings in 1942, four in 1941, and five in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Thousands of men now serving in the Army have already made fairly definite plans to establish businesses of their own in the post-war period, according to returns from a sampling of 20,000 enlisted men, made by the Information and Education Division of the Army Service Forces.

BASTOGNE, Belgium, Dec. 30 (AP) -- "That's the 'Old Crock' for you," was the GI reaction to the "Nuts" reply handed the Germans by Brig. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe of the 101st Airborne Division to their demand for the surrender of Bastogne before the siege was broken.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The War Production Board announced today that its textile, clothing and leather bureau has developed a special program to obtain increased production of certain essential items of infants' and children's knit goods -- hosiery, underwear and outerwear -- and men's work socks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Mineral production in the United States made a new record during 1944 with an output valued at $8,543,000,000, or nearly a billion dollars more than in 1943.
Led by Paul Schmones' 14 points, City College edged out an alert Panzer five, 41 -- 38, last night at the Beavers' gym. At half-time the score was 21 to 19 in favor of C.C.N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Four of the country's principal airlines were ordered by the Civil Aeronautics Board today to show cause why their mail rates should not be reduced.

SPARKILL, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Leo M. Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America and the author of several books on economics, was arrested today by State police on a charge of leaving the scene of an automobile accident near here last night.
The crisis was passed in the great battle in the west last week but the fighting was fierce at the week-end and the balance sheet was still to be added up.

NOT all visitors to Mexico concentrate exclusively on the capital's attractions, varied and interesting though they are. Many seek outlying hideaways known to initiates, but less familiar to the outlander One of these is the tropical mountain resort called Fortin de las Flores or Fort of Flowers.

WITH THE AMERICAN THIRD ARMY on the Western Front, Dec. 30 -- High praise for the Fourth Infantry Division for saving Luxembourg was expressed by Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. in a letter today to the division's commander, Maj. Gen. Raymond O. Barton of Ada, Okla.

" THE Schillinger System of Musical Composition," by the late Joseph Schillinger, is announced for publication later this year by Carl Fischer, Inc. WITH the German counter-offensive abruptly halted and thrown back almost one-third of the ground it gained, the year ends less grimly than prospects pointed just two weeks ago. WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation obtained 13,108 convictions during 1944, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the FBI, stated today in a review. He asserted that there had not been one act of foreign-directed sabotage in this country and that espionage efforts by the enemy had been kept under control.

NOW is the time for exercising the most pleasant of all critical jobs -- and that is the one of estimating the outstanding film accomplishments of the year. Custom decrees that this corner shall name, on this final Sabbath morn, the films which, in our cool opinion, have been most worthy of exceptional regard -- a practice which is more popularly labeled the selection of the year's "ten best."

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Chinese units in Hunan Province have killed scores of Japanese soldiers in an attack by mobile columns near Hengyang as Allied planes ranged over the China theatre to carry out successful blows at enemy road, rail and shipping installations, Chinese dispatches said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Latin-American nations want wider, and even direct, representation in the top policy-making body of the proposed international security organization.

CAIRO, Dec. 30 -- Germany's stubborn insistence on fighting to the last ditch is giving the Allies the paradoxical task of being forced to face some of their toughest post-war problems in Europe before the conflict's end.

With public understanding the 1945 rationing program can meet those scarcities and effect a fair distribution of the scarce foodstuffs among all the people, he said.

Terming the manpower situation in New York State "the worst it has been for the past six months," Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, called yesterday for volunteer workers from non-essential fields of employment to fill the gaps in essential industry.

While 1944 was the wettest year since 1890, it also had one of the driest periods, Benjamin Parry, meterologist in charge of the New York Weather Bureau, reported yesterday in a year's-end weather round-up.

FORT LEE, N.J., Dec. 30 -- An automobile with an unconscious man at the wheel ran away on the westbound lane leading from George Washington Bridge Plaza this afternoon, hurtling through an iron picket fence into the eastbound lane and careening for 500 feet until it hit a concrete railing on the south side of the road and crashed through the barrier to fall twenty-five feet to the tracks of an abandoned trolley line.

A CHILD said, "My teacher laughs, nobody in our house laughs," and someone quoted it, to make the point that laughter (with not at a child) is a great solvent of family problems. There wasn't space for the comment here, but it stuck in this reporter's mind, as did many another comment heard in the reporting of 1944.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 30 -- With the shores banked in crusted snow, but the bay clear of ice, the first session of the fourteenth annual Frostbite Regatta was held today off the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. Sixteen of the small Class B craft took part and the winner was Ed Raymond of the Larchmont fleet, sailing the Zotom.

Sixty-five per cent of the 175 returned veterans now studying at Northwestern University favor the plan of allowing a defeated Germany to have an industrial economy carefully regulated to reduce its potentialities for war. Only 22 per cent favor the plan of dividing Germany into small states too small to conduct large-scale war; less than 13 per cent favor the Morgenthau plan of converting Germany into an agricultural economy.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Sunday, Dec. 31 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur announced today that eight Japanese planes were shot down while attacking American shipping in the Sulu Sea off the island of Panay, and that enemy losses in the Battle of Leyte reached 116,770.

THE war itself has shocked people into facing the grimmest of realities, but it is not in itself sufficient to promote an understanding of the forces that have prompted this world catastrophe. In its later phases the war has caused people to accept unthinkable sacrifices, but they have yet to accept the hardest sacrifice of all, and that is, to give up their illusions about this civilization.

EVEN if there hadn't been a single request to reprint at this time the famous letter Major Frank W. Cavanaugh wrote from a French battlefield more than a quarter of a century ago, this reporter would have felt compelled to use it anyway. It still is a most touching and inspiring letter, one that loses nothing of its heart-catching appeal in the re-reading.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The abandonment of important sectors of northern Burma by the Japanese continued today with mounting evidence that the enemy does not plan to make a major stand north of Mandalay.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, called today for "the drastic reorganization of the whole life of the church to make it truly the means of humanity's salvation."

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- The positive conviction that the United States should assume a more firm stand in international affairs has been clearly established in New England. The Greek and Italian problems, the setbacks experienced by Allied forces in Europe within recent weeks and the tensions built up by prolongation of the war have not lessened that conviction to any noticeable degree.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Competition in the hunter division featured the first day of the horse show at the Secor Farms Riding Club. One of the most successful competitors today was the Virginia-bred thoroughbred Mathematician, a 6-year-old bay gelding, who came out at Boulder Brook a year ago and is owned by Mrs. Elizabeth Correll of Scarsdale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The State Department, after one of its most extensive reorganizations, is now prepared to function in accordance with plans and purposes outlined by Secretary Edward R. Stettinius Jr.
LONDON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- A United States Strategic Air Forces in Europe communique:
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The constitutionality of the Mortgage Moratorium Law, first enacted in 1933, and extended annually since, was upheld today by the Court of Appeals in a six-to-one decision.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- American GI's who are thousands of miles from the contagion of United States football bowl fever will stage their own gridiron spectacle with all the traditional color tomorrow when the Eighth Air Force Shuttle-Raiders meet the Air Service Command Warriors for the United Kingdom championship in the second annual Tea Bowl game.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 30 -- Sgt. Charley Trippi, the former Georgia star and current pride of the Third Air Force eleven, was the chief contributor today in a 24-to-7 victory of the South's All-Stars over their Northern opponents in the annual Blue-Gray contest before 16,000.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Dec. 30 -- Striking north on a fifty-two mile front from south of St. Hubert to the German frontier, tanks and infantry of General Patton's Third Army have smashed into the southern flank of the enemy salient, cutting its width by four to six miles.
