WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)-- The Office of War Utilities appealed tonight to all residential users of natural gas in New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania and West Virginia to cut their consumption as much as possible.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--President Roosevelt included in his first batch of nominations to the new Congress today reappointments to the Interstate Commerce Commission of J. Haden Alldredge of Alabama and Charles D. Mahaffie of the District of Columbia.

The second anniversary of the American Theatre Wing Club for Merchant Seamen, 109 West Fortythird Street, will be celebrated today at the club's headquarters with the "unveiling" of a giant cake presented by the Upgrading School for Cooks and Pastry Cooks, it was announced ...

HEADQUARTERS OF 21ST BOMBER COMMAND, on Guam, Jan. 3 (AP)--America's aerial invasion of the Japanese homeland, designed to knock out Japan's war industries, entered a new phase today with a Superfortress attack directed for the first time from the new Twenty-first Bomber Command Headquarters on Guam Island.

While 100 principals, witnesses, spectators and attendants sat bundled in overcoats, and the official stenographer interrupted testimony to jump up and down and blow on his chilled fingers, Magistrate William Hoppin in Yorkville Court adjourned yesterday until Jan. 10 a complaint of insufficient heat provided for factory tenants in an East Side loft building.

ALBANY, Jan. 3--Addressing the opening session of the State Legislature of 1945 today, Governor Dewey outlined a huge program of State public works, to be undertaken in the post-war period at a cost that might exceed $1,000,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP)-- The Phillies announced yesterday that Roger Hornsby McKee, lefthanded pitcher of Shelby, N.C., is in the Navy. McKee joined the Phils two years ago and last season served with the Wilmington Farm Club of the Interstate League. Traveling Secretary Jimmy Hagan said to replace McKee the Phils signed Tommy Lasorda, 17, of Norristown, Pa.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 3 (AP) --The Brown basketball team used substitutes for almost half of the game tonight while romping to a 70-41 victory over Harvard.

Abbey Simon, pianist, was heard in his fourth New York recital last night in Carnegie Hall. His program contained as its chief offerings the Bach-Busoni "Toccata, Adagio and Fugue" in C major; Mendelssohn's "Variations serieuses"; Chopin's sonata in B minor, ...
A banking group headed by Shields Co., received yesterday the award of $1,585,000 of City of Roanoke, Va., water system bonds on a bid of 100.016 for $245,000 ...
WASHINGTON Jan. 3 (AP)--Senator Carter Glass, oldest member of the Senate, will observe his eighty-seventh birthday tomorrow in his hotel suite. He insists that "no fuss" be made over it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The temporary promotion to colonel of these lieutenant colonels was announced today by the War Department: Campbell D. Garrett of 44 Burnham Place, New York; George R. Hoffman of Mount Vernon; Fred T. Wilson of Mamaroneck and Frederic F. Drury Jr. of Gouverneur, N.Y.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 3--Pacific Fleet carrier planes made simultaneous strikes yesterday at Formosa and Okinawa. The latter base is in the Ryukyu Islands, only 310 nautical miles from the southern tip of Japan proper.
Edwin L. Herbach of Hopkins, Herbach Co. was elected yesterday to associate membership on the New York Curb Exchange.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 3 (AP)-- Leading hitter in Mexican major league baseball: Rogers Hornsby. He had a perfect 1.000. The famed Rajah, according to official averages released yesterday, went into two games as a pinch hitter. He walked once, and the second time banged out a double.

With a new American transmitter on Saipan taking over Japan's medium air waves as soon as the Japanese network goes off the air, the Tokyo radio has called on all its domestic listeners to turn off their receiving sets and go to bed at the end of the regular broadcasting schedule the Office of War Information reported last night.

Grover A. Whalen, chairmandirector of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office at City Hall, announced yesterday that at least 16,000 more volunteers were needed from New York City in ten fields in which the CDVO offers war service opportunities.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3-- RKO-Radio has bought the screen rights to "Anything Can Happen," the book by George and Helen Papashvily, which was published today. It is the story of a Russian immigrant's life in America.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Jan. 3 --Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower dealt the shrewdest blow of his counteroffensive today, when, with Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton's tanks and ...

LONDON, Jan. 3--Twelve regional controllers for Britain are to be appointed by the Board of Trade to insure that British industry, when reconversion is undertaken, is more evenly distributed than in the past, Hugh Dalton, president of the Board of Trade, announced today.
ROME, Jan. 3.--The Christian party of the Left, which was condemned by the Vatican yesterday for its Communist principles, prepared today to carry on despite this rebuff.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 3 (AP)-- Continued improvement was reported today in the condition of Susan Peters, 23, film actress, who was wounded in an accidental shooting Monday near Cuyamaca Lake.
The body of a man who jumped or fell from the 135th Street Viaduct on Riverside Drive on Monday was identified yesterday at the Bellevue Morgue as that of Dr. Edwin Mims Jr. of 80 Bruce Avenue, ...
The battle on the Western Front yesterday was slowing to a series of fierce separate actions for limited gains.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 3 (U.P.)-- After deliberating for four hours and forty minutes, jurors hearing Joan Barry's charges that Charlie Chaplin was the father of her baby girl told Superior Judge Henry M. Willis that they had not yet been able to reach a verdict and were excused for the night.
SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Jan. 3 (AP) --Communique 270:

LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP)--A broad policy for dealing with the Germans after the war--one under which war criminals would be punished but others would get a chance to be "treated as brothers" --was offered today by Sir Stafford Cripps, Minister of Aircraft Production in the British War Cabinet.
Surrogate James A. Foley completed yesterday twenty-five years of service in the same court room where his oath of office was administered to him by the late Justice Victor J. Dowling.

Paula Stone, radio star and actress, appealed yesterday afternoon for the return of her wedding ring, described as her "only memento" of her late husband, RAF Pilot Officer Linwood A. Dingley, which was lost or stolen from her apartment in the Navarre Hotel, 112 Central Park South.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3--Miss Edith L. Swift, co-founder and executive director for more than twenty years of the Chicago Lighthouse for the Blind, died here yesterday in her home.
LONDON, Jan. 3--Increased dividend payments were reflected in today's stock markets, when a demand developed for gilt-edge issues, industrials and gold shares.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--It was inadvertently reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning that information was not available as to whether Lieut. Percy Wallace Rairden Jr., skipper of the LSM 318, had survived when his vessel was lost near the Philippines.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Victor J. Thill of 35 East Sixtyseventh Street and Lakeville, Conn., on Saturday in the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Mrs. Thill is the former Miss Carmelita Gomez of Venezuela. The child will be named John Frederic.
PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Jan. 3-- The addition of two vice presidents to the staff of the First Bank and Trust Company of this community has been announced by James C. Wilson, president.

The appointment of Mrs. Lewis W. Douglas as vice chairman of the Red Cross 1945 War Fund of Greater New York was announced yesterday by Jarvis Cromwell, chairman of the fund-raising division of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)--The United Mine Workers Journal suggested today that drafting of coal miners should be halted immediately if 1944's record output is to be maintained.
LONDON, Jan. 3--Field Marshal Sir Bernard L. Montgomery told Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower in a New Year's message that he and the troops under his command would "follow you anywhere."

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 3 (AP)-- Capt. Alfred H. Miles, who served more than thirty-two years in the Navy, is in the Army now. The author of "Anchors Aweigh," which he wrote as a midshipman at the Naval Academy, left last night to report for duty at Charleston, S.C., with the Army Transportation Corps.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The Maritime Commission's 1945 program calls for the construction of 13,000,000 deadweight tons of shipping, with 9,000,000 tons of the total scheduled for completion in the first six months of the year, Vice Admiral Emery S. Land (retired), ...
The annual report of the Lee Rubber and Tire Corporation and its subsidiary disclosed yesterday a net income of $1,299,849 for the year ended with October.

John W. Riedell, formerly on the staff of the American Management Association, has been appointed field secretary of the American Fair Trade Council, it was announced yesterday by John W. Anderson, president. Prior to his association with A.M.A., Mr. Riedell was connected with the Compensation Insurance Rating Board.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 3 (AP)--The University of Mexico basketball team will play twenty games in the United States, starting in Waco, Tex., Jan. 8, Coach Roberto Sanchez Lima said today.
The New York State Conservation Department hailed two auguries in the fishing field yesterday, one concerning lake trout production and the other pollution prevention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--Vice President Henry Wallace has written to President Roosevelt, expressing his preference to become Secretary of Commerce, if that post should be open, it was stated in Administration circles today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 3 (U.P.)--Horse racing in Russia is a business, pure and simple, shorn of the splendor accorded to it in the United States and Great Britain, and it plays only an inconspicuous part in the normal amusement of Russians.
ALBANY, Jan. 3--Following is the text of Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature:
The Board of Estimate set up yesterday, by authorizing serial bond issues totaling $33,750,000, a priority list for construction work on city projects interrupted by the war.
OLD FORGE, N.Y., Jan. 3-- Lyon De Camp, president of the Gawanka Realty Company of Thendara and a widely known lumberman and sportsman, died here today at the age of 67.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 3--To help increase the supply of nurses available for military service, the board of managers of St. Elizabeth's Hospital here today restricted the employment of private nurses. The board's action followed a Red Cross appeal for more nurses.

PARIS, Jan. 3--After the revelation today that Paris was fast running short of flour and deliveries were thirteen days behind schedule, the press demanded the requisition of trucks, since the railroads are still unable to cope with traffic needs.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Jan. 3-- Members of the United States armed forces now are permitted to enter the Republic of Panama following the completion of a tactical exercise that began last Friday and involved all military personnel of the Panama Canal Department.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3-- A heavy and a light cruiser will be commissioned and a "landing ship dock," the first built on the Delaware River, will be launched at the Philadelphia Navy Yard within the next week, the Fourth Naval District announced today. The cruisers are the Chicago and the Dayton.

CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, Jan. 4--The Chinese High Command announced today the recapture of Wanting, Burma Road town on the Chinese-Burma border, in a smashing climax to China's first real offensive of the war.

Nazi spies may eventually learn that their melodramatic attempts to land on American shores in little rubber boats launched from submarines are quite likely to wind up in front page stories featuring the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Paperboard production last week was 9.5 per cent below a year ago, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. New orders decreased 13.4 per cent and unfilled orders were up 24.2 per cent. Mills operated at 57 per cent capacity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--Echoes of the opening prayer had scarcely died away in the House today when Administration forces received a severe jolt through a roll-call vote which gave permanent tenure as a standing committee in the lower house to the Dies committee.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 3-- Ward C. McCroskey, former supervising principal of Hasbrouck Heights public schools, died this morning at Englewood Hospital of injuries suffered shortly before last midnight when the automobile he was driving crashed into a telephone pole on River Edge Road, Tenafly. He was 72 years old.

Two young Negro boys, cousins, and their pet dog were burned to death yesterday morning when fire swept the two-story frame building in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn where they had been left alone.
L.A. Petersen, executive vice president of the Otis Elevator Company, has been elected president to succeed the late Jesse H. Van Alstyne, it was announced yesterday.
Two German aliens, Max Paul Seeliger of 64-13 Sixty-eighth Avenue, Glendale, Queens, and Adelbert Demmel of 763 Seneca Avenue, Brooklyn; pleaded guilty yesterday ...

WESTWOOD, N.J., Jan. 3--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Cornely of this place of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Cecile Miriam Russell, to Yeoman Third Class Albert W. Murray Jr., USCG, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray of Montclair, N.J.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 3--The Board of Supervisors established today a Nassau County Planning Commission and confirmed the eight non-salaried appointees named to the commission by County Executive J. Russel Sprague.

HEADQUARTERS OF 21ST ARMY GROUP, Jan. 3 (AP)--The British Army, in its first official account of German atrocities, published today a document disclosing that Belgian civilians had been subjected to tortures rivaling those of the Spanish Inquisition.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3--As the Army completed its first week's operation of sixteen seized Montgomery Ward Co. properties today, the top-ranking officers charged with running the large mail-order business began to take account of the complexity of their task.

Directors of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., at their regular monthly meeting here yesterday, elected Gustav Metzman as a member of the board. Mr. Metzman has been president of the New York Central Railroad Company since Sept. 1, 1944.

The nightly blackout hours for all German territory have been fixed uniformly from sunset to sunrise under a new order, effective tomorrow, by Reich Marshal Hermann Goering, the Nazi DNB agency said yesterday in a dispatch to the German press reported by the Federal Communications Commission.

Joseph G. Gage, vice president of the Hickey-Freeman Company, men's clothing manufacturers, died after a heart attack Tuesday night at his home, 300 Park Avenue. His age was 72.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 4-- Strong German counter-attacks northwest of Budapest, which the Russians said were aimed at relieving the trapped Nazi garrison, in the embattled Hungarian capital, have overrun several towns on the south bank of the Danube, Moscow announced last night.
The "sidewalks of New York," so beloved by the late Alfred E. Smith, are going to sea in the Liberty ship that is to be named in honor of the former Governor.
Miss Marie Louise Aigeltinger, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Aigeltinger of 33 Sutton Place, will be married on Saturday to Lieut. George Frederick Wilson, AUS, who returned recently from overseas.

Joint action within thirty days by the War Production Board and the Office of Price Administration on a new program designed "to put an end to price increases in the clothing field" was promised yesterday by Price Administrator Chester Bowles.

LONDON, Jan. 3--For the twelfth straight day of what has become the longest sustained winter air offensive of the war, heavy bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force attacked German communications today.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Thursday, Jan. 4-- American forces, putting increasing pressure on the northern Philippines, sank or set afire twentyfive Japanese ships along the west coast of Luzon New Year's Day while American troops made two additional unopposed landings on the east and west coasts of Mindoro.

Robert Howard Blake of 800 Park Avenue, general manager in the United States for the Cunard White Star Line, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center at the age of 58.

Samuel Lewis, president of Lewis Apparel Stores, Inc., which operates a chain of thirty shops throughout the country, with headquarters at 275 Seventh Avenue, died yesterday in his home at 115 Central Park West, after a brief illness. His age was 78.

Life insurance companies of the country, in cooperation with the Veterans Administration in Washington, have embarked on a campaign to dissuade holders of the 16,000,000 National Service life insurance policies from giving them up or converting them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The Seventy-ninth Congress convened today in an atmosphere denoting determination to see the war through as quickly as possible, but marked by expressions of uncertainty as to the courses its legislative programs will take.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 3-- The third inauguration of Gov. Raymond E. Baldwin, scheduled for 2 o'clock, was delayed nearly three hours today by a partisan dispute on joint rules between the Democratic controlled Senate and the Republican controlled House of the General Assembly.

Fritzie Zivic, former world welterweight champion, and Billy Arnold, hard-hitting Philadelphian, yesterday completed hard training for the ten-round bout in which they are to meet tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

Frederick C. Crawford, president of Thompson Products, Inc., and a former president of the National Association of Manufacturers, will speak at the first 1945 meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at noon today about his recent trip to the battlefronts at the request of the War Department.

Overcome by ammonia fumes in the hold of a freighter at Pier 9, Carlisle Street and the North River, twenty workmen were taken to Downtown Hospital early last night after they had been brought from the ship by mask-equipped members of the Fire Department's rescue squad.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3--John Lansing Beven, president of the Illinois Central Railroad, died unexpectedly of a heart attack tonight in his office car at Clinton, Ill. He was preparing to go to the Clinton Hospital for the night when stricken. He would have been 58 years old on Feb. 17.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 3 (U.P.)--Betty Grable and Bing Crosby shared top honors today in the showmen's trade review's seventh annual poll of exhibitors, which named Miss Grable the top film star of 1944 and voted Crosby the year's leading male actor.

Broadway was back to normal yesterday, the only new development in the ticket controversy being the disclosure that The Playbill, the theatre program, would print a message by Mayor La Guardia urging theatre patrons to cooperate with the authorities in the enforcement of his new policy concerning the service charge on theatre tickets by brokers.

Dr. John F. Condon, who died Tuesday at the age of 84, had a long and distinguished career as an educator, and it is his fate to be remembered as the man who helped bring to justice the kidnapper and murderer of the Lindbergh baby.

A program of music by Jewish composers of four centuries was presented at Town Hall last night by Ruth Kisch-Arndt, contralto, assisted by the Kinor Sinfonietta of the Hebrew Arts Committee, directed by Siegfried Landau, and Otto Janowitz, pianist.
HAVANA, Jan. 3 (AP)--Havana racing is getting a shot in the arm from renewed Cuban interest in horse breeding that has brought big money men into the game.

James S. Schoff, president and managing director of Bloomingdale Brothers, has been elected a director of Abraham Straus, Inc., it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board. Mr. Schoff is also a director of Federated Department Stores, Inc.
Harvard M. Hodgkins, 17 years old, a tousle-haired Boy Scout, who played an important role in the recent capture of two Nazi saboteurs, was welcomed last night on his arrival at La Guardia.

ATHENS, Jan. 3 (AP)--Gen. Nicholas Plastiras, the new Greek Premier, organized a Cabinet tonight in which he retained four important posts himself and left room for inclusion of left-wing Elas forces still battling the British in the Greek capital.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)--Two half-brothers today were sworn in as members of the House of Representatives. They were Representative Max Schwabe of Columbia, Mo., re-elected to a second term, and Representative George Schwabe of Tulsa, former speaker of the Oklahoma House. Both are Republicans.
The reorganization committee of the Seaboard Air Line Railway yesterday declared operative the railway's plan of reorganization.
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 3--Henry Haddock Holmes, retired banker and general contractor, died here yesterday in his home, 280 Garfield Avenue. His age was 89.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)--A new warning to householders to go easy on the fuel oil came today from OPA, which said no extra rations will be available later on this winter.

ROME, Jan. 3 (AP)--Fifth Army patrols have pushed out in the direction of Massa, the strongest German position in the Tyrrhenian area, as the Allies' and the Germans' raiding parties stabbed into the opposing lines virtually all along the Italian front, Allied Headquarters said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3-- Only a few Japanese-Americans left the relocation centers of the West Coast today to return to their old homes in the Pacific Coast States.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (U.P.)--Rumors that George Bernard Shaw was dead went around London last night and a call was made today to Mr. Shaw to check up. "It's the first I've heard about it," he said.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (U.P.)-- Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, assured the country tonight that there is "not a chance in a million" that any outstanding shoe stamps will be canceled.

James A. McLain, president of the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America, will complete on next Monday his twenty-fifth year with the company. He started his sixth year as president on New Year's Day. The anniversary will be celebrated with a dinner in this city.
The old "gas house district" of the lower East Side, famed in song and story and known two generations ago as one of the "toughest" neighborhoods in New York, soon will be little more than a memory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--An assertion that some employers are exaggerating their manpower needs in their demands on the War Department, was made today by Lewis G. Hines, national legislative representative of the American Federation of Labor.

Tonight's events: Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski conducting, with Fritz Kreisler, violinist, as assisting artist, Brahms program, at Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)-- Democratic and Republican National Committees spent $4,884,773.14 in the 1944 campaign.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The United States Fourteenth Air Force in China is not using bases in areas controlled by the Chinese Communists, an AAF spokesman said today in response to a query.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3--The retreating Germans in Lithuania massacred 10,000 Jews in a Ghetto slaughter during one night and then burned the entire quarter before abandoning Kaunas, Colonel Pouyade, commander of the French Normandie air squadron that has been fighting Russia, said here today.

LONDON, Jan. 3--Like King George II of Greece, who ceded his powers to a regency only under direct pressure from Prime Minister Churchill, King Peter of Yugoslavia is waging a stiff rear-guard action against the acceptance of a ready-made regency for his country.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Jan. 3 --Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire took part today in the dedication of a gymnasium for convalescent soldiers at the new cantonment hospital here. Equipment was donated by David Silberman of Manhattan, a friend of the Senator.

James V. King, president of the New York district of the State, County and Municipal Workers, affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, issued a statement yesterday declaring that Mayor La Guardia had failed in his budget message to advance a solution for the difficulties of city employes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)--The screws on racing got another tightening today.

The Mozart recital by Rudolf Serkin, pianist, and Adolf Busch; violinist, scheduled by the New Friends of Music for Sunday afternoon at 5:30 o'clock at Town Hall, has been canceled because of the illness of Mr. Serkin.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--The President had appointments with the Brazilian Ambassador, Marvin Jones and Malcolm Ross.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)-- William J. Gallagher, pensioned Minneapolis street worker (he won't say "sweeper") looked on Congress as a member for the first time today and found it "so-so."

The status of an employe who has been inducted into military service does not change and his rights as a legatee are not impaired, Surrogate James A. Foley ruled yesterday, in an accounting proceeding in the estate of William Hall Walker, who died on Nov. 29, 1917.
Leonard Warren sang the title role in the season's second performance of Verdi's "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night before a large audience.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3--After the elections of 1944 a great deal of speculation was uttered and published on what the President's trend of policy would be--whether more or less to the Left than previously.
Frederick K. McKinney, former vice president of George Comfort Company, Inc., has joined A.J. Goldstein Co., 130 Cedar Street, and will specialize in the leasing and sale of commercial properties.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 3 (AP)-- Without a field goal for the first ten minutes, the Ohio State basketball team came from behind to defeat Wyoming, 44 to 36, tonight in a game that sometimes seemed to be a cross between football and hockey. It was Ohio State's fifth victory in seven starts and the eighth straight setback for the Cowboys.
With all preliminaries ironed out and the necessary forms distributed, New York lending agencies now are starting to advance funds for home purchases by veterans under the GI Bill of Rights.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (U.P.)--The Halstead Traffic Communications Corporation, New York, received today authority from the Federal Communications Commission to construct fixed portable radio stations to experiment in the design of signaling equipment for railroads.

Edgar Cayce, whose friends have credited him with the possession of unusual psychic powers, died yesterday at his home in Virginia Beach, Va., where he was known as a "psychic diagnostician." He was born near Hopkinsville, Ky., 68 years ago.
The Brooklyn Trust Company, as trustee, has sold the two-story factory building at 370-80 Jefferson Street, Brookyln, to the Clarileen Fabrics Corporation.

THE operations of professional history are a little like developments in real estate. About forty years ago Prof. Roger Bigelow Merriman began to improve a section, which lay in the first half of the sixteenth century. Having resigned his membership in the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, effective Jan. 5, Archbishop Anthony Bashir of the Syrian Antiochian Eastern Orthodox Church announced yesterday that while his resignation would take effect on that date, it was being reconsidered after a conference with Federal Council officials.
The National Council of American-Soviet Friendship announces the publication of an eight-page brochure titled "Henry J. Kaiser on American-Soviet Post-War Relations."

The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was featured yesterday by a fairly sharp rise in new crop months. Old crop months closed 1 to 3 points higher on the day, while new crop months rose 14 to 30 points.

Go out to cut firewood on a January day full of frost and you often find that the saw bites with remarkable ease even into a green oak log. The reason, of course, is that the log is frozen. Its tough fibers have become brittle. Set a section of such a log on end and it will split with a relatively light axblow. Again, frost gets the credit.

NOW, and the next month or two, will see the dry skin season at its height. It's not just the cold weather, according to dermatologists, it's also the lack of moisture in the air of dry, overheated rooms that makes oily skins comfortably normal and dry skins uncomfortably dry in the winter. The excessively dry air causes skin moisture to evaporate and thereby leaves normal and dry skins parched, rough and chapped.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 14 (AP)-- Byron Nelson stood off last-round sub-par rallies by Denny Shute, Akron, Ohio, veteran, and Sam Byrd, Detroit, to win the $6,666 War Bond Phoenix open golf tournament by two strokes today.

ROME, Jan. 14 (AP)--The German forces blocking the Allies' drive in northern Italy have been strongly reinforced and today they are using the heaviest artillery encountered since the Allies cracked the Hitler Line last May.

LONDON, Monday, Jan. 15-- Russian troops advanced up to seventeen miles through shattered German lines in south-central Poland yesterday, smashing to within sixty-four miles of the rich coal fields of southeastern Germany, while Berlin reported two new mighty Red Army offensives north and south of Warsaw.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14--The new attitude toward religion in the Soviet Union during the last three years has had important repercussions in the Middle East.

To corner the Japanese on Luzon we had to drive them back 3,000 miles from the threatened coast of Australia. Memories of humiliating defeats and many splendid victories over 10,000 miles of the Pacific mingle as we turn our eyes toward the great battle shaping up before Manila.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, that he would disclose "at the proper time, perhaps during the week that petitions may be filed," whether he would be a candidate for a fourth term.

LONDON, Jan. 14--Although one excuse for the inactive condition of the stock markets here at the beginning of the year was the disturbing military situation on the western front in Europe following the German break-through, the markets have not yet shown any...

Financial markets went to a higher level. On Thursday, stocks had risen 2 points last week, to the highest, by THE TIMES' average, since Jan. 8, 1940. Since that month, the average has been down as low as 64.13, in April, 1942.

WITH THE LUBLIN POLISH ARMY, at the Vistula River opposite Warsaw, Jan. 4 (Delayed)-- Across the river lies Warsaw, a city of death and destruction--yet a symbol both of Poland's unrelenting resistance and of Nazi Germany's ruthless and senseless devastation of human life and property.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, on Leyte, Jan. 14--Admiral Sir Bruce Fraser, Commander in Chief of the British fleet in the Pacific, revealed on his arrival here today that he had had a narrow escape from death on the way to the American invasion of Luzon.
WITH AMERICAN SEVENTH ARMY in France, Jan. 12 (delayed)--A group of four soldiers of a signal company found out a few nights ago what it is like to get involved in an enemy infiltration raid.

PARIS, Jan. 14--Black Bourse brokers here, balancing on this day of rest the last week's transactions, confided that bids for the "gold Louis" (a twenty-franc gold coin), reached the unprecedented figure of 4,800 paper francs.

The "mystery team" has departed, and the old Rangers are back. The New York representatives in the National Hockey League skated against the world champion Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night, and looked exactly like the Blueshirts of a month back.

Basil Harris, president of the United States Lines Company, announced yesterday that consolidated net earnings of the company and subsidiaries for 1944 are estimated at $1,235,000, or 85 cents a common share, comparing with $1,567,000, or $1.11 a share, earned in 1943.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 14--Affected by snow-bound freight cars, shortages of fuel because of cold weather and general production problems induced by weather conditions, the raw steel output rate last week continued unchanged from the previous week's revised rate of 93 per cent of capacity.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 14 --Billy Watson, singer and Dutch comedian, who made a fortune in burlesque as owner and star of "Billy Watson's Beef Trust," died in a hospital here today of a heart attack at the age of 78. His home was in Belmar.

The delivery of certified milk in the metropolitan area from the plant of the Walker-Gordon Laboratories, Inc., at Plainsboro, N.J., was halted yesterday when the boycott ordered against the company by Locals 680 and 584 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters went into effect, cutting off the daily supply of 23,000 quarts used almost entirely for invalids and infants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--An increase of 2 per cent in the ceiling price that importers and subsequent sellers of green coffee may charge for sales in lots of twentysix bags or more was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 14--Meeting a trainload of refugees, arriving in Palestine from concentration camps of eastern Europe is an experience that explains why it is difficult to be objective or even rational on the subject of immigration into this contentious country.

The city's "barflies" and "nightclub hounds" were taken to task yesterday by Mayor La Guardia for their failure to volunteer for service in such civilian defense units as the fire auxiliary forces, the City Patrol Corps and the air warden service.

Conceding that the Navy's need for registered nurses was not as great as that of the Army, Vice Admiral Ross T. McIntire, surgeon general of the Navy, declined last week to reply to a direct question as to whether he considered the drafting of nurses for the Navy...
PISA, Italy, Jan. 10 (Delayed)-- At least 50 per cent of Pisa, this city of ancient glories and once lovely monuments of medieval art, is uninhabitable.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 14-- A blinding snowstorm and a blustery north wind that threatened to blow the contestants off the mountaintop provided exacting conditions for the second annual intercollege ski slalom held for men and women today at Big Bromley.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 9 (Delayed)--One of the great medical advances of the war and, in fact, one of the very few original discoveries since the conflict began has now reached so solid a stage that it may be announced.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP)--A rejuvenated Chicago Black Hawk team made its first real bid to escape from the National League hockey cellar tonight as it skated rough-shod over the fourth-place Boston Bruins at the Stadium for a 4--1 victory to snap a long losing streak.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14--Tewfik Doss Pasha, distinguished Egyptian lawyer who pleaded for the defense before British military courts during the Egyptian revolution, when several distinguished Englishmen were killed by mobs, appealed today to a Cairo military tribunal to grant clemency in the case of the two young Palestinians who killed Lord Moyne.

WITH AMERICAN SEVENTH ARMY in France, Jan. 14--Fighting in the eastern sector of the American Seventh Army region of Rittershoffen and Hatten north of the Haguenau forest reached new heights of fury today as strong American and German forces continued to slug it out at close quarters, battling for possession of the two towns, which now have been battered into piles of rubble.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided at the military vesper service in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon at which the service flag that hangs outside the central entrance to the cathedral and the gold star flag that hangs within were rededicated.

A twenty-four-hour "pleasant" snowfall--pleasant for everyone but the undermanned and underequipped Department of Sanitation --ended at 6:45 P.M. yesterday with rail transportation generally operating smoothly but with some bus and most plane service in a chaotic state.

The founding of the Universalist Church in the eighteenth century to offer "a new, realistic conception of Jesus" was reviewed yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Benjamin B. Hersey, minister of the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park west and...

Paul Reinhardt of 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, former head of the Reinhardt Galleries, 730 Fifth Avenue, dealers in paintings of old and modern masters, died Saturday night in the Doctors Hospital, after a long illness. He was 56 years old.

ATHENS, Jan. 14--This was a day of mass celebration and thanksgiving. [The truce in the strife between Leftists and British and Greek Government troops was to begin officially at 1 A.M. Monday.]
A recital consisting mostly of Russian and Czechoslovak songs was given yesterday afternoon in Times Hall by Lida Brodenova, Czechoslovak soprano, before a large and enthusiastic audience.

Miss Anne Ross, champion diver of the St. George Dragon Club of Brooklyn, yesterday received the Metropolitan A.A.U.'s meritorious medal for 1944 which yearly goes to the oustanding athlete in the New York area. The presentation was made by Mrs. Edna Cole...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14-- Ruth Hussey has been borrowed from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer by RKO-Radio to play the lead opposite Pat O'Brien in "Man Alive," a comedy satirizing mediumistic spirit manifestations.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 11 (Delayed)--No other country in the Balkans is as ready and ripe for a democratic regime as Bulgaria. The average Bulgar is fundamentally democratic and therefore most eager to live under the rule of a true democracy.

Is the Southerner's "you-all" good English? The question is discussed again in The Virginia Pilot by R.K. Hughes Jr. He thinks that the language is richer for the expression because of the poverty of pronouns.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 14 (AP)-- Thomas Gresham, well-known Richmond business man and industrialist, died this morning at the Capitol Hotel here. He was 77 years old.
ALBANY, Jan. 14 (AP)--There will be fewer sneezes over a greater area of New York when the ragweed pollen flies again next August.

ROME, Jan. 14--The second anniversary of the Casablanca announcement of "unconditional surrender" led Italians today to draw up the sad balance of what it meant to them and what they believe it has meant to the rest of Europe.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14--All deliveries of corn sold last week at new seasonal high prices on the Chicago Board of Trade, buying being influenced by an announcement that the Government would purchase 50,000,000 bushels of cash corn from farmers prior to March...

WITH AMERICAN THIRD ARMY in Belgium, Jan. 14--Aided by clear blue skies that permitted the Nineteenth Tactical Air Command to have one of its best days since D-day, the American Third Army attacked along an elevenmile front in an are around Bastogne and gained up to four and a half miles.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14--Plans to hold wholesale market shows late in January and running into early February are going forward, it was revealed today, with the scheduled openings planned for Jan. 28.

Over the past week-end three more racing organizations held their annual meetings, elected officers and took steps to maintain racing interest until war conditions permit resumption of the sport.

SOMEWHERE IN THE PACIFIC (By Air Mail)--Staff Sgt. Wayne L. McCarter, who has fought and cooked on Guadalcanal, Tarawa, Saipan and Tinian--to name a few places--cooks for 350 marines three times a day, seven days a week, and now he is tired of cooking.
This is the third in a series of articles on foreign food shops in New York City. The fourth will appear on Thursday.

This has been a peculiar basketball season, indeed. Not the least singular have been the numerous revisions in the ratings of the local college quintets, among whom the experts have been tossing titles around and back and forth like the Staten Island ferryboat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--The War Labor Board closed in three years about 362,000 voluntary and dispute cases affecting 24,000,000 employes and "hundreds of thousands" of employers, its executive director, Theodore W. Kheel, said today in a report covering the period from its establishment, Jan. 12, 1942.
ON THE NORTHERN FLANK of the Belgian Bulge, Jan. 14--The Battle of the Belgian Bulge has now entered its last, bloody stages.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14--The Women's Bureau, which made studies of how women's peacetime skills could be turned to war production, has now completed a study of how the skills women have developed in war can be turned back into the industries likely to be flourishing after the war.

The mysteries of pasta faggioli --a dish disowned by many prosperous Italians, according to Mayor La Guardia, but loved by the poor and by Jimmy Durance, who calls it "pastafazule"--were made public yesterday by the Mayor in an effort to win converts.

SUPERIOR, Wis., Jan. 14 (AP)-- A crowd of admirers assembled at the railroad station here this afternoon to greet Maj. Richard Bong, a former farm boy who has won his country's highest award for his courage in the air in the second World War.

Lotte Lehmann gave the first recital in a series of three yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The popular soprano, who was in her best vocal form, presented a program devoted to songs by Schubert and Schumann, which was fervently received by a capacity audience, with the overflow seated on stage.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Jan. 14--The German Armies in the Belgian salient were in full retreat today, reeling back toward the Siegfried Line, their lines broken and battered by a storm of fire from thousands of Allied warplanes and by powerful ground blows.

PATUXENT, Md., Jan. 14--How millions of dollars, many lives and much time may be saved in the training of crews for Navy flying boats was demonstrated here today when a party of newspaper correspondents saw in operation the first production model of a highly specialized electronic device called "an operational flight trainer."

WITH AMERICAN FIRST ARMY in Belgium, Jan. 15 (AP)-- German officers in several instances recently have ordered American prisoners shot because of food shortages, German captives reported today.

Families of migrant workers on farms in New York State live under "shocking conditions of overcrowding, filth, lack of privacy and sanitation," according to a report issued yesterday by the Consumers League of New York.

Charles R. Ward, who was Commissioner of Public Works for the Borough of Brooklyn from December, 1933, until his retirement on Dec. 31, 1937, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 46 Remsen Street, Brooklyn. He was 69 years old.

The additional demand for Mexican-made articles for the home that followed curtailed manufacture of civilian goods in the United States has proved a strain rather than a boon to Mexican marts, according to one large importer.

The taxpayers' annual March 15 headache of former years, advanced for many by two months this year, found an army of New Yorkers staging a last-minute rush yesterday to get in under the midnight deadline for making final quarterly payments on their 1944 income tax and filing amended declarations on original forecasts if in error by 20 per cent or more.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15--A cigaretterationing system under which every smoker will carry a card issued by his local tobacco dealer was announced tonight by the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, the first industrial group to attempt wartime rationing of a scarce commodity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--Six murders and two forced suicides have occurred in German prisonerof-war camps in the United States, and investigation by the War Department has indicated that in all but one of these eight cases the victims were anti-Nazis who had been accused of treason by fellowprisoners. IN many respects the Akron University basketball team which faces St. John's in Madi son Square Garden tonight is one of the most unusual squads ever to perform there. For one thing, the trip to New York is costing each of the players money and when an athlete is parted from his money even an amateur one--that is definitely news.

The fourteen-week training course in consumer education recently completed by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office was such a success that two additional courses have been planned, it was disclosed yesterday by Mrs. Nathaniel Singer, head of the consumer services division.

Mandalay, or what is left of it, has just been battered anew by the heaviest air-strike yet delivered in Burma. A strong British column, marching down the rail line from Myitkyina, is less than thirty miles from the city.

A banking group headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will offer today a new issue of 20,000 shares of $5 cumulative dividend preferred stock, of no par value, of the Weatherhead Company. The stock will be priced at $97.50 a share, plus accrued dividends.
Don't be surprised to see the names of Jimmy Collins and Roger Bresnahan in Baseball's Hall of Fame after the votes in the current balloting are counted Jan. 20.

The black market in meat and other foods can be wiped out entirely in sixty days if city magistrates and Federal judges impose five-day jail terms on all ceiling price violators who come before them, Acting Chief Deputy Sheriff Israel H. Mandel declared yesterday.

Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston and Assemblyman Lee B. Mailler of Cornwall have introduced a bill in the State Legislature to assist home owners to procure funds for the improvement of their property on a basis much less expensive than any now in existence, Clifford F. Post, president ...

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 15--A budget submitted today by Gov. Walter E. Edge to the Legislature approved expenditure of $80,500,000 for operation of the State government during the fiscal year starting July 1. A total of $51,000,000 was appropriated from the general fund and the rest from the highway fund.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15--Builders and community planners of the country intend to concentrate their efforts after the war on the creation of complete, integrated residential communities which will assure buyers of homes of sound investments, leaders of the industry told the National Association of Home Builders here today at their annual convention.

LONDON, Jan. 15--Recent dispatches from Washington have led Londoners to expect an early announcement that Harry Hopkins, President Roosevelt's closest political confidant, has arrived in Britain to discuss Allied problems with Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden prior to the Roosevelt-Churchill-Stalin meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--Representative James Francis O'Connor of Montana, who was beginning his fifth consecutive term in Congress, died this morning at his apartment in the Roosevelt Hotel here at the age of 66. He had been in excellent health and spirits. His death apparently was due to a heart ailment.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15-- International Pictures has bought the screen rights to W. Somerset Maugham's series of secret service stories, which have been published under the general title of "Ashenden, or the British Agent."

ROME, Jan. 15 (AP)--Snow in the northern Apennines and rain and thaws in the lower areas again put a damper on both ground and air action on the Italian front today, and only artillery and patrol clashes were reported from most sectors.
Stepped-up demands for rayon tire yarn and tire cord will cut sharply into production of rayon staple fiber in the current quarter, it was learned yesterday.

WITH THE UNITED STATES TROOPS, on Luzon, Jan, 15-- While there is no telling where Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita will make his first challenge to the Americans on Luzon, Tarlac, some seventy miles from Manila, is a potential gathering point for a determined stand.
Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. announced yesterday he plans a visit to Mexico City next month to look into a proposition to conduct an important ring battle there.

ON THE NORTHERN FLANK of the Belgian bulge, Jan. 15-- Down here, where our First and Third Armies have so nearly met to seal off most of the German salient, the battle has become a plain grim job of killing.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 12 (Delayed)--The Russians are not interfering directly or openly in Bulgaria's internal affairs. However, the mere fact that there is a Russian army of occupation in the country is enough to give the local Communist politicians the impetus to do what they like unchallenged.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP)--Maj. George E. Preddy, the only American pilot in the European theatre to shoot down six German fighters in one day, crashed to his death Christmas Day when American gunfire struck his plane during a spectacular dogfight over Belgium in which he had bagged two Messerchmitts.

Dispelling rumors of a critical shortage of canned milk for infants' formulas, officials of the Regional War Food Administration said yesterday that while evaporated milk was not plentiful enough to meet the over-all civilian demand, enough was provided to retailers under the current system of allocation to supply essential needs for mothers with very young children.

Record numbers of millinery and corset buyers, anxious to rebuild sharply depleted retail stocks, jammed manufacturers' showrooms here yesterday. Meanwhile, many ready-to-wear, piece goods and notion buyers, who were in the market here last week, continued to check on deliveries on spring orders and to seek strenuously for additional merchandise.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--American casualties for the entire Western Front between Dec. 15 and Jan. 7 totaled 52,594, of which "slightly less" than 40,000 occurred in the Ardennes sector, scene of the bloodiest fighting in the German counter-offensive, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson announced today.
German jet lanes in the skies over Europe have given the enemy a tactical and technical advantage that he did not possess a year or eight months ago.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 16-- Russian troops captured the Polish industrial city of Kielce yesterday, smashed to within fifty-one miles of southeastern Germany and hammered through collapsing German resistance to points twenty-one miles from Cracow on the fourth day of their offensive in southern Poland.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP)--Three major league players who arrived here today after a 35,000-mile trip to Army camps in India, Burma and China found the troops eager for information about the game, including details of plays in the last world series.

Mrs. Jean Barnum Temple, author and English teacher at Far Rockaway High School, died on Saturday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Far Rockaway, Queens, after a long illness. Her age was 50. She resided at 460 Beach Twentysecond Street, Far Rockaway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15--While the French Embassy here denied today that any formal request had been delivered to the State Department for an invitation to Gen. Charles de Gaulle to sit in the coming "Big Three" Conference, it is learned that the French Government considers his presence essential.

ATHENS, Jan. 15--The ceasefire order in the Greek civil war went into effect at 12:01 A.M. today. According to preliminary reports, there was virtually no fighting during the first day of the truce, which followed six weeks of strife, and the insurgent forces seemed to be withdrawing in orderly fashion behind the stipulated boundaries.

PARIS, Jan. 15--Gen. Charles de Gaulle will address the nation by radio within a few days to appeal for unity in the war effort and a speedy transition from a revolutionary situation to a state of legality.

Domei admitted yesterday that Japanese Governmental and political circles had been split wide open under the pressure of a "demand by the nation for a stronger internal structure to meet the growing seriousness of the war."
WHITTINGEHAME, Scotland, Jan. 15 (AP)--Gerald William Balfour, second Earl of Balfour, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 91.

Legal machinery alone is not sufficient to insure a lasting peace, Robert H. Jackson, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, told the seventeenth annual midwinter dinner meeting of the New York State Bankers Association last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (U.P.)--A communique today reported "enemy air activity" against southern England in the twenty-four-hour period ending at dawn, an announcement made on fifty-seven of the last seventy-six days.

Undefeated Akron, boasting a twelve-man basketball squad, every member of which devotes much time to war work each week, brings its unblemished record into Madison Square Garden tonight and places it in jeopardy in a contest with St. John's University. SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Paris, Jan. 15--The American First Army drove into Houffalize in the heart of the Belgian bulge today and opened an all-out attack that carried within six miles of St. Vith as a new Third Army assault in Germany overran three towns.

A plan for bringing university students from the Netherlands to the United States for graduate study in medicine, public health, engineering and other subjects useful in the reconstruction of their war-torn country was announced yesterday after its annual meeting by the Netherland-America Foundation of 10 Rockefeller Plaza.

Charges that the budget estimate submitted by the committee on finance and budget of the Board of Education is shortsighted, timid, misleading and inadequate were made by spokesmen for forty-five civic and educational organizations yesterday at a hearing by the committee at board headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 15-- One of rthe most progressive States in the nation's snow belt in the promotion of outdoor activity dur ing the wintry months when one is apt to do less exercise than normally, Vermont today abounds with major ski developments operating at full gear in almost every instance.

Property owners, investors and taxpayer groups in New York City will be well represented at the joint hearing on the Commercial Rent Control Bill at 1 P.M. today in the Assembly Chamber at Albany. Large groups of delegates left here for Albany yesterday afternoon and last night.

Mussolini was impatient of the tradition of Italy as a country to which one went to see ruins. Yet he has managed to confer more ruins on his native land than any ruler who preceded him. Herbert L. Matthews has described for this newspaper this week what happened to Pisa.

Mayor La Guardia has ordered two meatless days a week as one means of solving New York City's meat problem. It does not seem likely that this program will result in any substantial improvement in the meat situation.

PARIS, Jan. 22--The police announced tonight the arrest of Charles Spinasse, former Socialist Minister of National Economy in the Leon Blum Popular Front Government in 1936, who in July, 1940, accepted the Petain regime and strove to organize a neo-Socialist party favorable to Vichy.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Jan. 22--American fighter-bombers, nemesis of Germany on the western front, caught Field Marshal Gen. Karl von Rundstedt's forces in a mad last-minute dash to escape from the Ardennes salient today and set mile after mile of motor trucks, tanks and armored cars aflame from Central Luxembourg back through the Siegfried Line fifty miles inside Germany.

At Capas General MacArthur's Sixth Army stands within ten miles of Clark Field and fifty-odd miles of Manila. All the way up from Port Moresby Mac Arthur's mind has been several moves ahead of the best enemy brains. His blows have never fallen where they were expected.
The trading in Laclede Gas Light Company's securities was moved yesterday to Post 5 on the New York Stock Exchange and prices began to move nearer the ratio set by the approved reorganization plan.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 22-- Furious carrier strikes at enemy airfields and harbors in Formosa, the Pescadores and Sakishima Islands Saturday destroyed 140 Japanese planes, damaged about 100 more and took a heavy toll of shipping plus extensive damage to docks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--Disabled veterans under current law must pay in effect for their hospitalization, through decerase in disability allowances, while veterans who survive without disabilities receive hospitalization entirely without cost, the House Committee on World War Veterans Legislation disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--Export premiums on five groups of products which have been added to domestic ceiling prices on shipments to foreign countries will be dropped on exports to Canada after Jan. 27, the Office of Price Administration ruled today.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Robinson Hickok, pastor emeritus of the Forest Hill Presbyterian Church of Newark, N.J., died of a heart attack Sunday afternoon in Deposit, N.Y., where he had been temporarily filling a vacancy in the Deposit Presbyterian Church. He was 67 years old.

Col. Edward P. F. Eagan, recently named chairman of the State Athletic Commission, underwent his first pre-fight baptism yesterday at the board's headquarters, and, strangely enough, came through the experience unscathed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 22--Despite the ineffective opposition of a disgruntled minority, the Republican National Committee approved today the program proposed by Herbert Brownell Jr., its chairman, and authorized him to establish a full-time functioning national headquarters in preparation for the elections of 1946 and 1948.

RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 22--This huge open-slope ski area, located about the 2,000-foot high altitude line and just nine miles east of this tradition-proud New England hamlet, has long been known as a paradise for the enthusiast who wishes to "swing" or even "stem" with plenty of speed between him and the tree-line.

William T. Davis, well-known entomologist and a founder, trustee and president emeritus of the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, died yesterday in the Staten Island Hospital after a long illness at the age of 82. Mr. Davis was an authority on cicadas, often called locusts.
LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP)--Two hundred Britain-based Flying Fortresses and 100 Mustang fighters poured 600 tons of bombs on the Sterkrade Synthetic Oil Refinery in the Ruhr today in a concentrated attack.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 22--William Alexander Charles, retired president of Charles Co., one of New York's oldest grocery concerns until its liquidation in 1938, and a former president of the Westchester County Grand Jurors Association, died here today at his home, 30 Hudson Avenue. He was 74 years old.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 22 (U.P.) --Negro major leagues will play baseball this summer if any organized baseball makes the tough manpower grade ahead of it, J. L. Wilkinson, co-owner of the Kansas City Monarchs, one of the best known of the Negro nines, said today.

The Triborough Bridge Authority plans to borrow $1,000,000 to meet interest and amortization which are due on Feb. 1, the first time it has needed to use the borrowing power permitted by the war emergency program, according to a report made yesterday to members of the Authority by George E. Spargo, general manager and secretary.

LONDON, Jan. 22--The need for an international children's charter to mend the bruised minds and bodies of millions of European children caught in the turmoil of war will be discussed by the Governing Body of the International Labor Office, which opens its quarterly meeting here on Thursday.

Motor vehicle equipment of the Department of Correction is in such a run-down state that it is sometimes necessary to transport prisoners between courts and institutions by subway, Commissioner Peter F. Amoroso told Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday in asking for $57,935 for new motor equipment.
Despite the pushing back of the Belgian bulge and Russia's swift advances, Germany is "far from licked" and will make new attacks with "hoarded men and armor,"

PARIS, Jan. 22--In a six-hour conference, Gen. Charles de Gaulle persauded Pierre Mendes-France, Minister of National Economy, to withdraw his resignation for the present, official circles said today.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Jan. 22-- Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Ikeler of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ensign Donna Marie Ikeler of the Waves, to Robert C. McQueen, son of Mr, and Mrs. Robert C. McQueen of Arlington, Va.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., Jan. 22-- Mrs. Adaline H. Judd, who will celebrate her 100th birthday in her Union Street home here tomorrow, talked today of whaling days, of the five wars she has lived through and pooh-poohed the notion that one generation of children is any worse than any other.

MEMPHIS, Jan. 22 (AP)--Oscar Johnston, president of the National Cotton Council, appealed today for broad revisions in Government programs affecting cotton so that the American industry may meet foreign competition after the war.
The Japanese Diet went into secret session yesterday to hear a detailed report by Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu on the "international situations" the Domei agency reported. Earlier the Tokyo ...
Despite inclement weather, more than 4,500 buyers, a new high record, crowded into the New York Furniture Exchange yesterday as the annual winter furniture market opened here for five days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--H. Struve Hensel, attorney, of New York City, who has been assigned to the Navy's legal division since January, 1942, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to become an Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

The executive director of The Associated Press, Kent Cooper, used a good new phrase for an old freedom in his address at Temple Emanu-El in this city Sunday morning. He spoke of "the right to know." The citizen is entitled to have access to news, fully and accurately presented. There cannot be political freedom in one country, or in the world, without respect for "the right to know."
LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP)--The Indian politician, Rash Behari Bose, adviser to the Japanese-sponsored "provisional government of free India," has died in Tokyo, the Tokyo radio announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22--Robert F. Carr, chairman of the board of the Dearborn Chemical Company, a director of many other companies, and former president of the University of Illinois Board of Trustees, died tonight in Passavant Hospital after an illness of three weeks. He was 73 years old.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22--Grain markets were easy early today on favorable war news, with September corn and oats and December wheat selling at new seasonal low prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--Investigation of Attorney General Francis Biddle and the Department of Justice in connection with charges recently made by former Assistant Attorney General Norman M. Littell is sought in resolutions prepared by Representatives Lawrence H. Smith, Republican, of Wisconsin, and Jerry Voorhis, Democrat, of California.
Pete Gray, one-armed outfielder recently acquired by the Browns, has been hailed as the first player with such a physical handicap to make the major leagues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--Important changes in the Twentieth Air Force's field commands of B-29 operations, with Maj. Gen. Curtis E. LeMay moving from the Twentieth Bomber Command in India and China to head the...

In a dispatch to THE TIMES from North Burma, Tillman Durdin says the Japanese have abandoned any hope of holding that area and blocking the reopening of a land supply route to China. Their only aim there now appears to be to slow up the Allied advance as much as possible with suicide rear-guard actions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--Robert E. Hannegan stated today that he would remain as chairman of the Democratic National Committee and would begin organizing at once for the 1946 Congressional campaign.

TRENTON, Jan. 22--Gov. Walter E. Edge today nominated former State Senator Frank E. Abell of Morristown and Donald V. Lowe of Tenafly to suceed the late Frank Dorsey of Perth Amboy and John Borg of Hackensack on the Port of New York Authority.
WITH AMERICAN FORCES, South of Tarlac, Luzon, Jan. 22-- We boiled southward in a jeep driven by Pfc. Clifford Johnson of Birmingham, Ala., looking for the front lines and the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--Senator James E. Murray of Montana submitted a bill today to provide full employment under a national policy and program. Co-sponsors are Senators Robert F. Wagner, Elbert Thomas of Utah and Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming. All are Democrats.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 22--News has been received here that Marshal Tito has signed an agreement with the Allies' military authorities governing the administration and distribution of relief supplies and transport services by the American and British Governments in the liberated portions of Yugoslavia.

ATHENS, Jan. 22--The interpretation of the Greek crisis in the Athens press and the general way in which it is presented to the outside world by foreign correspondents indicate points of view that one local editor described today as "poles apart," reflecting the attitude of Athenians who are beginning to despair of any reconciliation.

EINDHOVEN, the Netherlands, Jan. 21 (Delayed)--There is no black market in the Netherlands. This is because little remains to be bought at any price, rather than because the Netherlanders are more virtuous than the Belgians. However, their character has a lot to do with it.

Shields Co. and associates will formally offer today $1,500,000 city of Corpus Christi, Tex., 2 per cent State aid, seawall and breakwater bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1944, and maturing on each June 1, from 1945 to 1956. The bonds due from 1945 ...

CINCINNATI, Jan. 22--Alfred Bettman, chairman of the Cincinnati Planning Commission and nationally known attorney and authority on regional and city planning, died yesterday on a Cincinnati-bound Pennsylvania train at the age of 71.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 22-- Glenn Tryon, who has been devoting his time recently to directing and writing for the screen, has returned to acting to portray George White in RKO-Radio's current "George White Scandals." Patricia Morison has been signed by Universal to play the romantic rival of Deanna Durbin in "Lady on a Train."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 (AP)-- Carriers and General Corporation, a New York investment company, registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission $1,872,000 of fifteen-year 3 per cent debentures.

LONDON, Jan. 22--Compulsory integration of the British coal mining, industry under a central coal board representing its present private owners was recommended today by Robert Foot, chairman of the Mining Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--If every Senator who believes that Henry A. Wallace is unsuited to take charge of Federal loaning policies votes against his confirmation, Mr. Wallace will not be confirmed as a Secretary of Commerce who also controls Federal loans.
The war returned yesterday to its beginnings.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Hunter Berg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hunter Van B. Berg of 227 Park Avenue and Mill Hill, Southpost, Conn., to Lieut. William Robert Kueffner, Medical Corps, AUS, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Kueffner of St. Paul, Minn., and Rockville, Md., took place yesterday afternoon in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Senator Mead told the Senate yesterday that he and others of his War Investigating Committee, in a visit to the Norfolk Navy Yard, found excess manpower, hoarded labor and enforced loafing. He argued against national service legislation.

The formation of a New York Advisory Board for the National Jewish Hospital at Denver, the first tuberculosis institution in America to provide free medical and surgical care to needy men, women and children on a national, ...

Federal and State enforcement agencies intensified their combined drive yesterday against high-pressure "tie-in" sales of inferior brands of rum and gin to retailers who order scotches and bourbons. Complaints of "tie-ins" being passed along to the consumer by the package store also are being investigated.

The stock market returned yesterday to the average range of December under the fourth successive pounding by sellers. Following the pattern set in the preceding sessions, the liquidation was confined to the early hours, after which moderate recoveries appeared, so that extreme losses of about 2 points were cut to half.
With inexorable justice, a semblance of the terror which the Nazi armies spread through Europe in the days of their conquests is now beginning to spread through Germany itself.
Metro's "Meet Me In St. Louis" today starts its ninth week at the Astor. The Technicolor musical featuring Judy Garland and Mar garet O'Brien will conclude its run there on Sunday, Feb. 4.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--Citing their "very profitable" operations during the war, Chester Bowles, Price Administrator, warned retailers and wholesalers of consumer goods today they would have to absorb rising costs, instead of passing on the increases to consumers "wherever possible."
PARIS, Jan. 23--Fernand Maroni, dean of French writers on economics and financial subjects, is dead in Aix-en-Provence at the age of 85.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (U.P.)-- Chairman Basil O'Connor of the American Red Cross reported today that American and other Allied prisoners of war at German camps in the path of the Soviet advance had been moved toward the center of Germany several weeks ago.

Marshall Buckland Downing, who retired on Jan. 1, 1939, as vice president and general manager of the New York Telephone Company, died yesterday in his home, 1 Grace Court, Brooklyn. His age was 68.

ROME, Jan. 23--The widespread agitation of Italian students, which is taking primarily the form of protesting against presenting themselves for the army, is causing much anxiety to the authorities and leading Italians and resulted today in two typical expressions of opinion.
The Metropolitan Opera House was filled last night with members and guests of the Metropolitan Opera Guild at its tenth birthday party.

The theory that moderate drinking does not harm the drinker is "all bunk," Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin, national president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, yesterday told a cheering audience of 150 in a speech demanding that work with alcoholics be supplemented by legislation "abolishing the liquor traffic."

The American Legion, augmented by veterans of this war and wielding its influence through "a block of 40,000,000 to 50,000,000 votes, counting friends and relatives," will be a powerful factor in the 1948 election, its national commander, Edward N. Scheiberling, told the closing session of the twenty-fourth annual meeting of the New York State Publishers Association at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

Contributions totaling $426,400 were presented to twenty philanthropic and relief organizations by the Refugee Relief Fund of the Coat and Suit Industry of New York at a dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP)--By issuing emergency orders for embargoes on shipments of civilian freight and bulk grains, the Office of Defense Transportation sought today to alleviate a railroad traffic jam in northeastern States, the Association of American Railroads said.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 23--John T. Rowland, for the last forty-four years architect for the city of Jersey City and the Board of Education, died last night after a brief illness at his apartment in the Duncan Arms, 2600 Hudson Boulevard. His age was 73.

LONDON, Jan. 23--Hordes of German refugees streamed out of Poland and eastern Germany today as Berlin admitted the Russian tide still was largely unchecked and Adolf Hitler sped Heinrich Himmler and other "iron-willed" leaders to the critical Eastern Front with orders to "make and execute drastic decisions."

Robes Meade Parker, retired president of the Sugar Export Corporation, who was a vice president of the American Sugar Refining Company from 1916 to 1924, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 80.

The stock market attracted modest bidding yesterday morning on the premise that it had reached an oversold condition, but the effect of favorable war news was made evident in the final hour when selling depressed prices further.

OTTAWA, Jan. 23--Prime Minister William L. Mackenzie King today, in a second open letter to the electors of Grey North, where the Minister of Defense, General MacNaughton, is seeking election to the House of Commons, told the country that he had done his best to avoid holding a general election during a critical stage of the war, but that his hand was being forced and that those who had done so must bear the responsibility.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23--General liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade after an early advance had carried the deferred deliveries of wheat up 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's close.
Mink in new mutations took the spotlight yesterday in showings by Lampson, Fraser Huth and the New York Auction Company at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ROME, Jan. 23 (AP)--Fifth and Eighth Army patrols, operating today along the entire Italian front, probed the positions of the reinforced German Army, now reported to total twenty-eight divisions, its greatest strength since last spring.

HEADQUARTERS OF PACIFIC ARMY AIR FORCES, Hawaii, Jan. 23--Japan will be "on her feet and fighting in 1946," Lieut. Gen. Millard F. Harmon, commander of Army Air Forces in the Pacific, declared today in a radio address.

This is the night when boxing's ambassadors of good-will are to be honored. The occasion will be the seventh annual dinner of the Boxing Writers Association of New York in Ruppert's Brewery, commencing at 7 o'clock.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY FORCES, on Luzon, Jan. 22 (Delayed)--A comparatively small group of men whose exploits occasionally border on the amazing have achieved a reputation as a major cog in Pacific amphibious warfare. They are known as Jasco, an abbrevation for Joint Assault Signal Company.

After three years a land route for supplies from India to Burma again is open.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Jan. 23--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's forces came within five miles of recapturing the whole of the former Ardennes bulge today, but at the same time, under threat of five or six German divisions, the United States Seventh Army suddenly abandoned a sizable strip of territory along the Maginot Line north of Strasbourg.

A new electrical "brain" that gives quick answers to problems considered "unsolvable" by mathematical analysis was described yesterday at the annual winter meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers in the Engineering Societies Building, 33 West Thirty-ninth Street.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 (AP)--Big Si Seibert scored twice in 36 seconds late in the third period, enabling the Detroit Red Wings to beat the Boston Bruins, 5 to 4, for the thirteenth consecutive time in a National Hockey League game before 12,000 fans at the Boston Garden tonight. Both tallies were made while the home forces played shorthanded.

Sales of the Caterpillar Tractor Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Caterpillar Military Engine Company, increased last year to $245,949,525 from the $173,945,023 volume transacted in 1943, according to the annual report for 1944, given yesterday by L.B. Neumiller, president.

Roberts B. Thomas, secretary and general counsel of the American Institute of Steel Construction, 101 Park Avenue, who had long been prominent in the steel industry as an expert on legal and labor matters, died yesterday in the Polyclinic Hospital, 345 West Fiftieth Street, where he underwent an operation on Jan. 16. He was 53 years old.

Henry Hoyns, who had been chairman of the board of directors of Harper and Brothers since 1931, and on last Dec. 31 celebrated his sixty-first year with the publishing firm, died last night at his home, 1314 Carroll Street, Brooklyn. He was 76 years old.

Although Warner Brothers announced the purchase of the screen rights to "The Voice of the Turtle" last summer, final contracts were signed on Monday, according to Alfred de Liagre Jr., producer of the John van Druten three-character play.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 23-- Kenneth S. Clark, who wrote four of the songs that Princeton undergraduates and alumni have sung at athletic contests and reunions for many years, died at his home here last night after an illness of several months. His age was 62.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Office of Price Administration, in a step generally understood to loosen somewhat its price regulation for aluminum, made three changes today in its ceiling-price order for aluminum scrap and secondary aluminum ingots.

Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein agreed yesterday to let an alleged swindler plead guilty to petit larceny when he returned $8,150 he had obtained from a 78year-old Brooklyn widow.

The camera has brought the war in the Pacific to the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, where an exhibition of photographs of action on the sea, in the sky, and on land will be opened to the public today under the title, "Power in the Pacific."

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 23 (AP)--An extension of Japanese holdings in Chekiang Province, obviously intended to counter any American landing on the east coast of China south of Shanghai, was reported tonight by the Chinese High Command.
The Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland reported yesterday that its net income in 1944 was $1,555,738, equal to $12.96 a share, against $1,515,550, or $12.62 a share the year before.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 23--If Argentina sincerely wishes to uphold Pan-Americanism she should start by backing up the Rio de Janeiro conference, Gen. Fulgencio Batista, former President of Cuba, declared here yesterday as he was leaving for Venezuela.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 23--Okinawa Island, major Japanese air and naval base in the Ryukyu Archipelago within 320 miles of Japan proper, was attacked on Sunday by Pacific Fleet carrier planes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23-- Samuel Goldwyn has announced that his next picture for Danny Kaye will be a musical fantasy based on the life of Hans Christian Andersen, in which the comedian will portray the fairy-story writer. Virginia Mayo will have the feminine lead.

Byrd describes it, "a fourth branch of the Government" and therefore the most important factor in the struggle between Congress and the President over the appointment of Henry A. Wallace to control this Federal authority.

Uncertainty regarding legislation affecting cotton and continued favorable war news were unsettling influences yesterday on the cotton futures market, especially new crops, and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange lost 8 to 23 points net. Edward J. Bourke, who retired from the Police Department in 1920 with the rank of captain after a long and colorful career during which he had won the personal commendation of the late President Theodore Roosevelt, died Monday at his home, 41 58 Judge Street, Elmhurst, Queens. He was 77 years old.
