A syndicate of 150 banks and investment houses headed by the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank won yesterday the award of a new issue of $75,000,000 of New York City serial bonds. In fact, given sufficient understanding, kind treatment and encouragement, Germany, he thinks, will reform on her own initiative, moved by shame and humiliation because of recent crimes and the stigma of defeat.

The Detroit Symphony Orchestra, Karl Krueger conductor, with Marjorie Lawrence as soloist, appeared last night for the first time under its present organization in Carnegie Hall. It was heard by an audience that packed the house and gave unstinted applause to a rather poorly made program.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--Bills for the establishment of a five-man commission to eliminate racial and religious discrimination in employment were introduced in the Assembly and Senate today with bipartisan backing.

The Massachusetts Bonding and Insurance Company had a net gain in surplus during 1944 of $1,820,185, bringing the total at the yearend to a record, $9,868,114, T.J. Falvey, president, reported yesterday.

An exhibition called "William Sidney Mount and His Circle" was opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum. Installed in the Balcony Galleries of the Great Hall, it will be opened to the public today and will continue through April 1.

Nine thousand next-of-kin of war prisoners from this area will receive the newest map of German prison camps when they attend the meeting arranged for them by the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, to be held at 7 P.M. Thursday...

By unanimous action the City Council adopted yesterday a resolution urging the Board of Education to fill all openings in the teaching system by appointment of regular teachers from current lists of eligibles, to terminate the...

SCANDAL has reared its ugly head in basketball. The sports world was stunned yesterday by the revelation that five Brooklyn College players had been bribed to "throw" one game in Boston and another in New York. It's a rather terrifying prospect. If it happened now, has it happened in the past or will it happen again in the future?

In an effort to reduce annual interest charges by taking advantage of the current favorable money market, the Alleghany Corporation is understood to be negotiating with a group of bankers for the purpose of replacing its outstanding 3 per cent...

New York's celebration of President Roosevelt's sixty-third birthday--the city's tribute to his twelfth annual dedication of the anniversary of his birth to the nation-wide fight against infantile paralysis--was held last night with many fetes here, principal of...

Edward Choate and Marie Louise Elkins, who a few seasons back united forces to present "Yankee Point," are the joint sponsors of "Alice in Arms," the comedy by L. Bush-Fekete, Sidney Sheldon and Mary Helen Faye, opening this evening at the National Theatre.

Katharine Wyman Drummond Herbert, founder and for more than fifty years president of the Working Girls Vacation Society, who in 1933 made an outstanding gift to the American Museum of Natural History, died here after a long illness at her home in West Twentysecond Street on Monday. Her death occurred on the eighty-seventh anniversary of her birth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The May-Bailey bill for "limited nationa service" was asserted by key legislators tonight to have made gains on both sides of the House, but Administration forces were working for withdrawal or defeat of two highly controversial amendments which appeared to stand in the way of certain passage of the measure.

The factional conflict in Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes Union, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, was before the membership of 28,000 for decision yesterday in an election for officers conducted on order of Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

A candid warning that the American public would have to reconcile itself to a high level of taxes after the war, however unpalatable that might be, was given last night by Dr. Roy Blough, assistant to Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. and his adviser on tax policy matters.

Mr. and Mrs. Harvey E. Fisk Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., have announced here the marriage of their daughter, Miss Dorothea Harper Fisk, to Lieut. Lynn Lyle Fulkerson Jr., Army Medical Corps, which took place last Thursday in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

PARIS, Jan. 30 (AP)--The first American officer tried in the series of railway battalion black market cases here--Lieut. John W. Springer--was convicted today by a general court-martial of conspiracy to defraud the United States Government and was sentenced to thirtyfive years' imprisonment at hard labor.

LONDON, Jan. 30--The Governing Body of the International Labor Office today decided to set up seven tripartite international industries committees that will form the basis of cooperation in their respective spheres of workers, employers and governments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-- Charges were made before the Senate War Investigating Committee today that Jacob Goldberg, president of Surplus Liquidators, Inc., of 1775 Broadway, New York City, tried to "tempt and lure" officials of the Defense Plant Corporation by offering them salaries two to three times as large as their Government pay.
The speed and sweep of the Russian offensive, which still rolled unchecked toward Berlin yesterday, has surprised most observers, military as well as civilian.
Ferenc Molnar, the Hungarian writer best known for his play "Liliom," has a new book, "The Captain of St. Margaret's," due on Feb. 14 from Duell, Sloan Pearce.

Every commanding general has one recurring nightmare. It is that the forces under his command will be split by the enemy into groups for attack and defeat in detail. For the Japanese general on Luzon, whether the legendary Yamashita or some lesser commander, that bad dream now would appear to be a reality.

Although war conditions had forced the abandonment of the annual Honors Night Dinner of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, several hundred members attended a meeting in the Engineering Societies Building last night at which many awards were conferred.

As the seasonal increase in egg production forced down retail prices 1 and 2 cents a dozen yesterday, the War Food Administration said there was no truth in Mayor La Guardia's assertion that the Government was holding "millions of cases" of cold storage eggs that should be released to the public before they rotted.

Failure to share taxicab service in this city during the wartime emergency period was termed yesterday by Senator Fred G. Moritt (Democrat) of Brooklyn, an "asinine situation" for which "Mayor La Guardia is responsible," according to an Associated Press dispatch from Albany.

At noon today the new north tube of the Lincoln Tunnel, linking New York City and Weehawken, till open, to help speed traffic and the movement of war goods, and incidentally relieve the mind of Michael Catan of 679 Waring Avenue, the Bronx, who has been waiting anxiously for days at the Thirty-ninth Street entrance in order to be the first to make the trip to New Jersey.

Reflecting recent large-scale refinancing and debt reduction by the railroads, prepayment of bonds in January aggregated $608,788,000, the largest monthly figure since July, 1936, when $661,230,000 was redeemed, and the biggest January total in over eighteen years.

LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP)--Members of the House of Commons--conscious that the absence of their leaders and a meeting of the "big three" might be synonymous--received a guarded hint today that the question of early Soviet aid against Japan had been removed from the agenda of that conference.

The contraction of excess reserves of member banks in the Federal Reserve System which follows war loan drives, as Treasury deposits built up during the campaigns are transferred to private accounts, has been much smaller than usual since the close of the ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The Office of Price Administration, having concluded a series of conferences with the leather industry, announced today a number of changes in its regulation establishing ceiling prices for leather with the intent of making the ruling "more workable" for both producers and jobbers.

LONDON, Thursday Feb. 1-- Massed Red Army tanks and infantry, slashing through Berlin's outer defenses, drove to within sixtythree miles northeast of the German capital yesterday while Berlin said other Soviet armored spearheads had stormed into the Oder River valley forty to fortyfive miles east of the panic-stricken city.

LONDON, Jan. 31--The United Nations War Crimes Commission elected a new chairman today, stated that it would not cease to discharge the task of bringing war criminals to Justice despite recent reports to the contrary, and sent a letter of thanks to Herbert Claiborne Pell, who was withdrawn from his post as United States representative on the commission.

Funeral services for Carr V. Van Anda, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES from 1904 to 1932, and his daughter, Miss ...

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 31-- After a thrilling first-half battle in which the score was tied on five occasions, the high-scoring United States Military Academy basketball team suddenly found itself and ...
Admission by five Brooklyn College basketball players two days ago that they had accepted a $1,000 bribe to "fix" an intercollegiate game had further concrete results yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 31 (AP)--The slaying of the Rosselli brothers in France eight years ago was probably planned by the Italian Foreign Office with the direct approval of Benito Mussolini, a witness testified today at the trial of fifteen persons accused of crimes under the Fascist regime.

Since 1926 the New York Heart Association has been a part of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association. The two are now to be separated, because diseases of the heart are at least statistically so important that they should be combated by a special organization. Various forms of heart
CHICAGO, Jan. 31--Heavy short covering developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and prices advanced swiftly after an early dip.
LONDON, Jan. 31 (U.P)--The rumble of Russian guns was reported audible in Berlin tonight as indications increased that Adolf Hitler had determined to defend the city along Stalingrad lines.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 31-- Denis F. O'Brien, who patented the water hydrant in standard use in New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and other large cities, died here today of a heart attack in his home, 179 Prospect Street. His age was 80.
UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 31--Albert O. Foster, treasurer of Foster Bros., a furniture manufacturing company in Utica, died here yesterday at the age of 69.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31--A dozen home-makers stepped into the buyers market for help today with the passage of a set of standards for household workers as the guiding chart of the new Y.W.C.A. Household Employers League.

Reversing the trend of recent years, New York City's tentative assessed valuations for the fiscal year 1945-46 have risen to $15,934,065,239, up $36,442,233 from the comparable figures for last year and $88,073,225 above the final figures for 1944-45, William Wirt Mills, president of the Tax Commission, announced yesterday.

Every valid effort should be exerted to preserve the sovereignty and independence of the States in the field of insurance regulation, Robert E. Dineen, Superintendent of Insurance, declared yesterday in his annual report to the New York Legislature.
CHICAGO, Jan. 31--The first all-round style show held under the auspices of the Chicago Fashion Industries took place here today in the Stevens Hotel, with two showings, afternoon and evening.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31--Herbert L. Clarke, famous cornetist with John Philip Sousa's band, died in the Harriman Jones Clinic here today after a brief illness. He was 77 years old.

Robert Casadesus gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall which marked the tenth anniversay of his American debut. During his notable career in this country he never was more fully a great master of the keyboard than in his superb presentation of the twelve pieces
The text of the address by John D. Rockefeller Jr. at the dinner of the Protestant Council of the City of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night follows:

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 31--The shortage of fuel oil in Nassau County is the most critical since the war and has resulted in clos ing "many" homes, J.L. Barron, sanitary engineer of the Nassau County Health Department, declared today. Mr. Barron also said

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (U.P.)-- Heavy American bombers from Philippine bases, escorted by fighter planes, have blasted the important Japanese air base at Heito on Formosa, while patrol planes, scouring the China Sea, have hit enemy shipping in the Sakishima Islands, 150 miles to the east, sinking four freighters and setting two afire, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, Jan. 31--The Governing Body of the International Labor Office at a lively private session today declined to take immediate action on Italy's request for readmission to membership and decided to place the question on the agenda of its next session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The jet-propelled fighter plane, now constituting a rapidly growing segment of the aircraft production in this country, will displace "to a great degree" the standard type of fighter-escort craft in the war against Japan, according to war production officials.

ROME, Jan. 31 (AP)-German patrols stabbed again at British Eighth Army positions in the Adriatic sector today in an obvious effort to learn as much as possible about Allied dispositions and plans. Increased artillery and air activity on both sides was noted along the entire Italian front.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 31 (AP)-- Lieut. Col Charles T. Gwynne, former executive vice president of the New York State Chamber of Commerce, died here today at the age of 70.

LONDON, Jan. 31--Economic surveys of Latin America, liberaced European areas and the Middle East markets are in progress in preparation for an expansion in Britain's export sales after the war, Harcourt Johnstone, secretary of the Overseas Trade Department of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons today.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, Pacific Ocean Areas, Jan. 31--The story of the Seabees and their ability to achieve the impossible in less than record time has been told many times in this war, and out here on the island in the western Pacific to be used as headquarters ...

Simplification of the method among judges and referees of scoring bouts under the jurisdiction of the State Athletic Commission was the one concrete recommendation that developed yesterday out of the meeting of boxing writers and Chairman Eddie Eagan at the Yale Club.

As the Russians continue to drive ahead in the east with unabated strength and American Armies in the west move toward a full-scale offensive over a forty-mile front, what must be the situation within Germany itself?

The report of the Johns-Manville Corporation, to be issued today to stockholders by Lewis H. Brown, president, discloses consolidated net earnings of $5,476,213 for 1944, equal to 5.4 cents in the sales dollar and to $6.39 a share of common stock. Consolidated net earnings for 1943 were $4,655,280 or $5.27 a common share.

An appeal for a reborn "Church of the Living God," which would pronounce ordinance, ritual and creed nonessential for admission into the Kingdom of God, and would make its test a life, not a creed, was sounded last night by John D. Rockefeller Jr. at a dinner of the Protestant Council at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The directors of the Pere Marquette Railway at a meeting held in Cleveland yesterday authorized an issue of $50,000,000 of thirtyfive-year bonds to be offered competitively on Feb. 19, R.J. Bowman, president, announced.

Miss Lucy Lea Hurd and Lieut. John Spangler Farrington, Naval Air Arm, whose engagement was announced a few days ago, were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square.

The fire-story building containing two stores and thirtyfive apartments at 1365-67 York Avenue, southwest corner of Seventh-third Street, has been sold by the Continental Realty and Investment Corporation to David S. Meister, operator.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 31-- Elizabeth Taylor, the young riding star of "National Velvet," has been lent to RKO-Radio by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for a featured part in the Leo McCarey production "The Bells of St. Mary's."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- American troops shifted from Europe to the Pacific after Germany's defeat will leave the bulk of their equipment behind, under present plans, and will be armed anew for Japan.
The shortage of nurses in Army hospitals and rehabilitation centers is "a terrible thing," Helen Keller said yesterday at the American Foundation for the Blind, Inc., 15 West Sixteenth Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Progress by the Government in settling terminated war contracts has speeded up but "further improvement" is necessary before settlement is on a current basis.
PARIS, Jan. 31--The French are spectators of the meeting of Big Three, but they feel that they are far less completely on the outside looking in than they have previously been.

PARIS, Jan. 27 (Delayed) (AP)-- Maj. Gen. Paul Hawley, surgeon general of the European theatre, said today that eleven general Army hospitals were arriving in this war zone without a single nurse because nurses in the United States were not volunteering in sufficient numbers.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 31-- Dr. Logan Clendening, lecturer and writer on "diet and health," was found dead in his bed at his home today with a puncture in his throat that was believed to have pierced the jugular vein.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The way was cleared tonight for a showdown on the Senate floor tomorrow on the confirmation of Henry A. Wallace as Secretary of Commerce. This resulted from a day of many conferences in which leader set their final strategy.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Jan. 31 (AP)--Communique 298: Allied forces attacking in the vicinity of Simmerath, northeast of Monschau, made gains of one to three miles to reach Kesternich and capture Konzen. We have taken Rohren, two miles east of Monschau, in an advance of 3,000 yards against increasing resistance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31-Jean Monnet, the French special envoy on lend-lease and shipping negotiations, said today that his discussions here were proceeding satisfactorily. He made the statement in denying a published report that serious difficulties were being encountered.
PARIS, Jan. 31--Yellow stickers adorned with black swastikas and inscriptions in blood-red lettering are appearing on store windows in Paris and provincial cities.

SOME time ago a tale was recounted here of Tiny Maxwell, the gargantuan and slightly fabulous football official. William W. Craig, Lafayette '08, stayed on top of the ball by rushing through with a Maxwell story of his own. Unfortunately, though, we fumbled by misplacing the letter. But the fumble has been recovered and this is Mr. Craig who is carrying the ball:
About as large an assortment of nuts as any fancier of that food could dream up greets the customer who stops in at the new Planters Peanut Shop at 1560 Broadway, near Forty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Pictures of some pin-up girls for servicemen overseas provide "an indecent picture before their dying gaze," William C. Smith, assistant executive secretary of the National Council of Catholic Men, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- The War Department announced today an agreement with Canada for the disposition of defense facilities established in the Dominion by the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31--New lighting fixtures and new store fronts lead the list of post-war improvements to be made in the nation's grocery stores, a survey conducted by the National Association of Retail Grocers revealed today.

Month-end covering for the trade and some let-up in volume of liquidation and hedge selling gave cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange a steady tone yesterday, and final prices were 10 to 20 points net higher, with new crops relatively strong.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Luzon, Thursday, Feb. 1 --Pushing rapidly southward from their beachheads in Zambales Province, troops of Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Eleventh Corps captured Olongapo, former American naval base on the eastern shore of Subic Bay at the base of the historic Bataan Peninsula on Tuesday, according to an announcement issued here today.

Twelve Purple Heart holders, all American prisoners of war who escaped or were repatriated from Axis prison camps, will begin a tour of the United States tonight at the Seventeenth Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street, with talks before 9,000 next-of-kin of prisoners still in Axis hands.

Open hearings before the Senate Commerce Committee on the McCarran bill to establish a "chosen instrument" for the United States in international air commerce have been assured, it was announced yesterday by Alexander B. Royce, representing the seventeen airlines seeking regulated competition.
LONDON, Jan. 31 (U.P.)--Louis Goodrich, actor, playwright and novelist, died yesterday at his home in Hampshire. His age was 80.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--The May-Bailey bill for "limited national service" took its first and probably highest hurdles in the House today and, after nine attempts to change it had failed, appeared to Congressional leaders to be headed safely for passage tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31--The very high degree of prosperity reached by Argentina despite her shipping shortage and other difficulties resulting from war is made manifest by foreign trade returns for 1944, released today.
Directors of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, it was disclosed yesterday, have referred to the company's executive committee the recent request for a special meeting of stockholders.

LONDON, Jan. 31--Documents on which Prime Minister Churchill based his charge that Elas had been guilty of committing atrocities in Greece were published today by the British Government in a white Paper.

ALBANY, Jan. 31--Liberalization of the corporate franchise tax law as it affects renegotiated war contracts is provided in a bill introduced today by Senator William Bewley, chairman of the Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment.

Net premium income of the United States Fidelity and Guararty Company of Baltimore last year increased $998,143 to the record total of $45,025,449, E. Asbury Davis, the president, reported yesterday in the forty-ninth annual statement to stockholders.

PARIS, Jan. 31--Another severe criticism of Gen. Charles de Gaulle and his Cabinet appeared in the newspaper Combat today. It accused General de Gaulle of not explaining his policies and his Ministers of Inertia--matters that, the resistance paper said, "widen constantly the gulf that separates us from the Provisional Government."

THE presumption is always against any established man who ventures into an entirely new field. Paderewski was handicapped by his music when he became Premier, just as Winston Churchill started from behind scratch when he took to painting.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 31-- The Dartmouth basketball team avenged an early season setback at the hands of Columbia by defeating the Lions tonight, 45--38.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Harold G. Olsen of Ohio State University, chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournament committee, took issue today with statements by Dr. Forrest (Phog) Allen that ...

There is as much meat in the city this week as at any time in the last two years, Daniel P. Woolley, regional head of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday, announcing the expansion of the Federal agency's enforcement division to put black market dealers "out of the meat business and into the jails" until the housewife gets her, fair share.

Three first-run films today enter second weeks at midtown theatres. They are: "A Song to Remember," at the Radio City Music Hall; "The Woman in the Window," at the Palace and "The Thin Man Goes Home," at the Capitol.

Reports from Washington agree that the outlook is improving for favorable action in the House of Representatives on the May-Bailey bill, which provides for civilian war service in the 18-45 age group. Various factors are contributing to this result.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Recommendation that the War Labor Board require twelve large corporations to set up procedures whereby foremen and other supervisory employes could be represented by a committee in the presentation to management of grievances was made today to the board by a "blue ribbon" panel.

Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox began at 19 the career from which he never deviated. As "new teacher" in a country school from which the older boys enjoyed throwing instructors who failed to master them, the young pedagogue firmly demonstrated his ability to stay on the job. As president of Union College he was still on the job and at the height of his activity when his career ended.

The means by which Russia is supposedly attempting to gain political influence in Spain, France and Italy are described in a letter written to Spanish Republican leaders in the United States by Luis Araquistain, formerly Spanish Ambassador to Berlin and Paris and now the London representative of the Spanish Republican Committee of Liberation with headquarters in Mexico.
WITH THE AMERICAN NINTH ARMY, Jan. 28 (Delayed) (AP)-- The company commander was sending a midnight patrol across the Roer.

Members of the diplomatic corps paid tribute yesterday to Dr. Wladyslaw Neuman, Polish Minister to Mexico who died here last Wednesday, at a funeral service in the Campbell Chapel, Madison Avenue and Eighty-first Street.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS. Allied Expeditionary Force, Jan. 31--The possibility that the western Allied armies and the Soviet forces may establish a common front somewhere in northern Europe before German military resistance is stamped out was envisaged today by some non-official observers here.

To the National Theatre last evening the firm of Choate Elkins brought "Alice in Arms"-- and a plague on that house. The new comedy by L. M. BushFekete and Sidney Sheldon is another one about the returning soldier, and to it nothing new has been added save that the soldier is a Wac.

LONDON, Jan. 31(AP)--The Czechoslovak Government in exile formally recognized the Polish Provisional Government formerly of Lublin today but did not break off diplomatic relations with the exiled Polish Government in London.

AUBURN, Me., Jan. 31--Sixteen children, most of them infants, and a woman were burned to death or suffocated early today in a fire which swept a wooden house operated as a nursery for war workers' children.

So successful has the Millrose A.A. meet become that Fred Schmertz, its director, is now able to flaunt superstition, which he has done this year by arranging thirteen relays for Saturday night when the event will celebrate its thirty-eighth birthday at Madison Square Garden.

James Caesar Petrillo not only dictates terms to the big broadcasting companies; he not only ignores the orders of the War Labor Board and the written pleas of the President; but he is able in effect to set aside also the decisions of the National Labor Relations Board.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 31 (U.P.)--Guarding against Allied landings. Japanese troops have completely sealed off the China coast east of the Canton-Hankow railway by capturing Kukong, 120 miles above Canton and last Chinese strong point on the vital rail artery.
An acute shortage of registered nurses exists at many of the ninety-three veterans hospitals in the United States, Col. Robert C. Cook, manager of the Bronx Veterans Hospital, said yesterday.

The volume of new securities offered here to the public in January was the largest for any month since October, totaling $459,891,000 for twenty-two bond flotations and $30,897,000 for ten stock issues, compared with $75,036,000 for ten bond offerings and $3,725,000 for three stock emissions in the preceding month.
Next time you catch a fish that is exactly one ounce heavier than any of that species ever caught before, don't throw it back. Keep it and go down in history as a world record holder.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--Among 3,319 Army and 576 Navy casualties announced today by the War and Navy Departments, all based upon prior notification to next of kin, were the following (the name following the casualty is that of the next of kin):

In a show resembling a dressrehearsal of the Easter parade, Russeks presented a varied suit picture yesterday during luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Colors bloomed like a flower garden and the silhouette story ranged from boleros to riding habit effects.

ALBANY, Jan. 31--Moving to ease the critical coal and livestock feed shortages caused by storm conditions, Governor Dewey mobilized today an unspecified number of units of the State Guard in upstate cities to help dig out rail yards and to assist in fuel deliveries.

A lessee of various theatres for the last dozen years, Allan Robbins now plans to try his hand at Broadway play producing. He has acquired as his first offering "This Was a Woman," a psychological drama by Joan Morgan, which received a hearty endorsement in London where it closed recently after 400 performances.
PALERMO, Sicily, Jan. 30 (Delayed)--There is more crime in Sicily and the situation is graver than the Italian Government admits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31--President Roosevelt's promise, delivered early this month, that the United States "cannot and will not shrink from the political responsibilities which follow in the wake of the battle" is beginning to be translated into action in the liberated areas of Europe.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing company, in its preliminary annual statement for 1944, reported yesterday a net income of $26,018,096 after taxes and all charges and provision for renegotiation.

After an ownership of two years, the twelve-story apartment for sixty-eight families at 340 West Eighty-sixth Street, near Riverside Drive, has been resold by a client of the Globes Realty Corporation to B. Feldman Bros. for cash over a first mortgage of $264,600.

A brownout, ordered by the War Production Board as a fuel conservation measure, became effective at 12:01 A.M. today throughout the nation and promised to save a minimum of 100,000 tons of coal in New York City alone, but worsening weather conditions again stalled freight movements in western New York and kept alive the threat of severe civilian fuel and food shortages.
John Gomar Harwood, actor and stage director, died in London on Dec. 28, according to word received ere yesterday.
CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 31 (AP) --The stage is being set for the battle for Mandalay for the Japanese obviously are preparing for a last ditch defense of Burma's second largest city.
The Appellate Division has reduced the assessed valuation of the seventeen-story building at 84 William Street by 36 per cent to $630,000 for the tax year 1942-43.
George S. Ryan, manager of the Feeder Divison of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, has been named assistant to T.I. Phillips, vice president. C.B. Dick Succeeds Mr. Ryan.

SUPREME HEADQUARTERS, Allied Expeditionary Force, Jan. 31--Infantry of two American armies, moving up to challenge guns of the Siegfried Line, pierced the German frontier in three places today, in addition to the penetration yesterday, on the front south of Aachen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)-- Congress was urged today to appropriate $25,000,000 to help colleges and universities maintain their teaching facilities.
ROME, Jan. 31--Secretary of State Edward R. Stettinius Jr., as well as Harry Hopkins, was in Italy until this afternoon, it was revealed today, but he did not come to Rome.
If "political credit" is to be avoided, Government-guaranteed loans must stop as soon as the war production bill is paid, Hugh H. McGee, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, said yesterday.

An exhibition of paintings, drawings and pastels by eight merchant seamen opens today in the National Maritime Union's recreation hall, 346 West Seventeenth Street.

Three hundred and fifty veterans now studying in private trade and professional schools in New York City under provisions of the GI Bill of Rights may have to curtail their courses under a recent interpretation of the law made by the Veterans Administration, it was revealed yesterday by A.B. Kelly, chief of education and training.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 31--Belgium will oppose French control of the Rhineland on the principle that the Netherlands, Luxembourg and this country have interests that must be protected by a strictly international agreement. When Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak visits Paris in the near future he is expected to say as much to the French Government.

R.H. Macy Co. will put its own cigarette rationing plan into effect this morning, when it will reopen its tobacco department, closed since Jan. 19 because of the difficulty of satisfying customers in view of the existing shortages. Sales will be made only to persons holding ration cards issued by the store.
The stock market closed yesterday the month of January on a selective recovery note but only after selling had raked the list in the early hours.

Whether it be Old Man Winter or just plain Nemesis that has been trying to quiet "The Voice of the Turtle," John van Druten's play at the Morocco Theatre, Producer Alfred de Liagre Jr. isn't prepared to say. As of yesterday, however,

Kelly, chief of education and training.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 31--Belgium will oppose French control of the Rhineland on the principle that the Netherlands, Luxembourg and this country have interests that must be protected by a strictly international agreement. When Foreign Minister Paul-Henri Spaak visits Paris in the near future he is expected to say as much to the French Government.

R.H. Macy Co. will put its own cigarette rationing plan into effect this morning, when it will reopen its tobacco department, closed since Jan. 19 because of the difficulty of satisfying customers in view of the existing shortages. Sales will be made only to persons holding ration cards issued by the store.

ALBANY, Jan. 31--Governor Dewey proposed in his budget message today that New York State go on a pay-as-you-go basis for all its future capital improvements, except for loans to municipalities. His budget, submitted to the Leg-- islature, recommended appropriations of $580,000,000 for the fiscal year starting April 1.

Mrs. Gibson Lamb Caldwell of Kenwood Place, Wheeling, W. Va., has announced here the engagement of her second daughter, Margaret Bird, to the Hon. Miles Godfrey Walter Phillimore, fourth son of the Right Hon. Lord Phillimore, Deputy Lord-Lieutenant of Oxfordshire, England, and the late Hon. Mrs. Godfrey Phillimore of Coppid Hall, Henley-on-Thames.

Twenty-year-old Grace Lichenstein, 5 feet 6 inches tall and weighing 125 pounds, bookkeeper for the Norman Sportwear Company, 239 West Thirty-ninth Street, foiled a hold-up yesterday by sheer determination and lung power.

Laboratories of Brooklyn unless a labor dispute is settled on terms ordered by the War Labor Board, informed sources said today. The company is understood to have a week in which to comply.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3-- Regions in California tackled a storm-repair job today as heavy rains, accompanied in some regions by high winds, subsided after many highways had been closed, power lines broken and hundreds of persons evacuated from their flooded homes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3--The Senate Military Affairs Committee, which seemed well on the way yesterday to reporting out its version of the House-approved "limited national service" bill, became snarled today over the critical question of which agency or official should have control of the powers to be delegated.

The coal situation in New York "could hardly be worse," Mayor La Guardia said yesterday. The city will order closing of all amusement places heated by coal, it is reported, and will cut off steam service to others. [1:1.]

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 3-- Prof. Samuel J. Record, dean of the School of Forestry of Yale University and a member of the faculty since 1910, died today in the New Haven Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 63 years old.

ALBANY, Feb. 4--Governor Dewey, reported today in a speech broadcast over a Statewide radio network, that the worst of the transportation crisis growing out of storm conditions up-State appeared to be over but that the need for conservation of fuel, food and feed for livestock continued unabated. In New York City, he said, it was particularly urgent that meat supplies be used sparingly.

Kaplan, dean of the Teachers Institute of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, as the means of meeting the need of American Jews for trained leaders. He spoke at a special convocation...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (U.P.)-- Statistics issued by the War Labor Board tonight, purported to show that the ban by Fred M. Vinson, director of economic stabilization, on wage increases that cause ultimate price rises would affect slightly more than 10 per cent of the dispute cases and less than 1 per cent of the voluntary wage applications decided by the WLB during October.

Salvage rather than reconstruction will be the main preoccupation in Europe for the next year or so, Sir Frederic Eggleston, Australian Minister to the United States, said yesterday in a talk in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. Sir Frederic, who is also a member of the council of the Institute of Pacific Relations, spoke on the general character of the peace.

LONDON, Feb. 4--Premier Hubert Pierlot of Belgium is spending the week-end composing the defense of his Government that he will make on Tuesday. It is going to be a trial of strength of absorbing interest to Belgians, most of whom cannot make up their minds what to think.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--All Senators and Members of Congress seem to be unanimous on one thing--the need to build an apartment house near the Capitol for the country's "homeless" legislators, Representative Luther Patrick, Democrat of Alabama, said tonight.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4--Fruit and vegetable growers and shippers were warned today to order containers as far ahead as possible to assure adequate supplies to move crops to market. They also were urged to salvage and make use of used types.

Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday that a new course for teachers, entitled "The Newspaper--Its Making and Its Meaning," would begin on Wednesday, Feb. 21. Sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, under auspices of the Board of Education, the course will include fifteen weekly sessions from 4:15 to 5:55 P.M. at the Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

PARIS, Feb. 4--It was announced yesterday in the Journal Officiel that France's public debt as of Oct. 31 last, was 1,500,000,000,000 francs, or theoretically $30,000,000,000 at the official rate of exchange, which admittedly does not represent the true purchasing value of the French currency. In this total, Government bonds, whether in the form of rentes or of treasury notes, figure for 1,000,000,000,000 francs.

CHUNGKING, China, Feb. 4 (AP) --Reinforced Japanese troops, driving against air bases east of their China corridor, have advanced thirty-two miles from fallen Suichwan to positions eighteen miles from Kanhsien [Kanchow], the Chinese High Command said tonight.

ROME, Feb. 4 (AP)--Twentythree Army personnel, including three nurses, were killed Friday when a transport plane carrying twenty-six American Army personnel crashed against a mountainside sixty miles north of Rome.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 4--When the raw steel rate dropped 3 points last week to 89 per cent of rated capacity, the industry received the greatest setback in production since the war started. Nor were there indications last night that the rate would show this week much of an increase from last week's subnormal level.

Royal E.T. Riggs, well-known lawyer and partner in the law firm of Riggs Seibert, 30 Broad Street, died yesterday morning at his home, 236 East Sixty-first Street, after an illness of several months. His age was 63. He had a summer home at Old Lyme, Conn.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Feb. 4-- Action of anthracite miners in reporting for duty Saturday although they were paid only straight time drew commendation from the Government today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (U.P.)--A fleet of the largest and fastest ore carriers in the world is being constructed for use in the South American trade, the War Shipping Administration disclosed tonight.

Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Methodist area, speaking yesterday in Temple Emanu-El, listed "six ethical ideals from the teaching of Jesus of Nazareth" as moral foundations upon which the post-war social structure must be built lest it fall as "a house built on sand."

LONDON, Feb. 4--The amazing rapidity of the Russian Armies' march on Berlin has played an important part in bringing renewed unsettlement and a moderate depression in the stock markets here, while business has dwindled to very small proportions.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 (AP)--Scoring once in each period, Montreal's Canadiens stretched their National Hockey League lead to 11 points tonight by defeating Detroit, 3 to 1, for the seventh time this season before 13,535 fans.

WITH THE AMERICAN THIRD ARMY, in Germany, Feb. 4--Just before Fifth Infantry Division battalions took Lipperscheid in Luxembourg, a German battalion commander told his superior officer in a telephone conversation that the situation was critical but that his units would fight to the last man. He made certain, however, he was not going to be the last man.

Baseball forgot its cares and woes for an evening yesterday when more than 1,200 gathered in the grand ball room of the Hotel Astor to attend the twenty-second annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Feb. 4 (AP)--Byron Nelson celebrated his thirty-third birthday by winning the Corpus Christi open golf tournament today, finishing with a 16 under-par 264 that left him four strokes better than Harold (Jug) McSpaden.

PARIS. Feb. 4--If a soldier who has been released from a hospital is thrust too abruptly back into the front line, the United States Army has learned, he may find himself unequal to his problem physically and mentally and may break down.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (U.P.)--A growing tendency among States to enact laws for the policing of labor unions and their activities may draw a comprehensive ruling from the United States Supreme Court within the next few months.

ROME, Feb. 4--A protest against keeping Italian soldiers prisoners while other Italians fought by the side of the Allies against Germany was made today by Count Sforza in an article in the Giornale del Mattino. Count Sforza said that it was the "most urgent, most painful" problem facing Italy, that about a half million families had relatives who were prisoners of the Allies.

LONDON, Feb. 4--The use of German labor to repair regions devastated by the Germans will be pressed by the Russian delegation to the world trade union conference which will open here next Tuesday and continue until Feb. 16.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP)--The Boston Bruins protected their twogame grip on the National Hockey League's fourth-place play-off berth by sharing a 3-3 deadlock with the New York Rangers tonight at the Boston Garden in a game marked by fifteen penalties and police interference between a player and a fan.

The smoldering conflict between State regulatory commissions, primarily those engaged in the regulation of public utilities, and the Federal Power Commission, one of the main regulatory agencies of the United States Government, has reached the point where all State utility commissions have been asked to take concerted action against the "encroachments" of the FPC on States' rights.

From the national road down which we are moving through the northern section of the city we can see great clouds of smoke billowing from the city's center, and they seem to be coming from the waterfront area.

ROME, Feb. 4 (U.P.)--Adolf Hitler's present Fuehrer headquarters is really a hiding place in a little monastery on the outskirts of Salzburg, Austria, where he is still suffering the result of the July 20 bomb plot against him, usually reliable Vatican informants said today.

Following a sharp downward trend for two weeks, domestic cotton prices turned firmer last week and closed the period with moderate net gains. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes of 15 to 27 points for the week.

PARIS, Feb. 4 (AP)--The present Russian offensive has raised the number of German war refugees inside the Reich to 23,000,000, more than one-third of the Reich's prewar population, information available at Supreme Headquarters showed today.

LONDON, Feb. 4--The meeting of the Big Three seems to be causing considerable anxiety among German leaders. They have been making contradictory guesses about where the meeting is being held and obviously are fishing for information.

PARIS, Feb. 4--While reproducing reports from the London press professing to reveal in detail the proposals that President Roosevelt will make in the Big Three conference, the French press expressed some misgivings today.

The executive committee of the American Jewish Committee adopted yesterday a post-war program in which it accepted the recommendations of a special committee on peace problems composed of forty-seven leaders from every section of the United States.

PALERMO, Sicily, Jan. 31 (delayed)--when one of the regional separatist organizations was formed in Sicily last year it adapted as its emblem the American flag, and one feature of its program was a demand for annexation by the United States.

A vacant tract of 300 lots on Park Drive East, between Seventy-second and Seventy-seventh Avenues, in Kew Gardens, Queens, has been purchased by the Park Drive Corporation, Harry Lefrak, president, from the Queens Valley Development Company, represented by T. Keogh.
CAIRO, Egypt, Feb. 4--The Foreign Ministers of seven Arab States will meet in Cairo on Feb. 14 to draft a constitution for a league of Arab nations, it was confirmed today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)--An undisclosed number of American merchant ships will be turned over to the French Government for operation in the United Nations' shipping pool.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (U.P.)-- Disabled veterans are beeing absorbed into war jobs so rapidly that comparatively few are applying to the Veterans Administration for specialized training, Edward M. Lewis, Public Relations director, said tonight.

ROME, Feb. 4--There were two strong indications today that the response to the Army draft, on which many Italian backers of a strong new army had pinned their hopes of impressing the Allies, was disappointing, possibly seriously disappointing.

ADVANCED HEADQUARTERS, on Luzon, Monday, Feb. 5--American troops of the First Cavalry Division entered Manila, Saturday night from the east, pushed to the north bank of the Pasig River, and captured the civil internment camp at Santo Tomas and the Malacanan Palace in the heart of the city,

ALBANY, Feb. 4--In the State's fiscal year starting April 1, New York City will get $133,375,000 of the $272,500,000 to be distributed to municipalities as their share of certain State-collected taxes and as appropriations from the general fund for aid to education, social welfare and relief, it was disclosed today.

Retailers are concerned over the tight merchandise situation and various changes announced and in work on the part of war agencies covering apparel lines in the expectation that the confusion is going to last for some time, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4--Prices of wheat were on the upgrade last week despite the continued favorable character of the European war news, and many traders have experienced a change of heart as the result of reports indicating demand for foodstuffs from liberated countries will probably far surpass previously anticipated needs.

The twelfth week of the Metropolitan Opera Association's season will be featured by the unabridged performance of Wagner's "Siegfried," the third part of the "Ring" cycle, on Tuesday night, Feb. 13. Lauritz Melchior will sing the title role and Helen Traubel that of Bruennhilde. Norman Cordon will be heard as The Wanderer for the first time here.

ALBANY, Feb. 4--Woman war workers in New York State stand only a "fifty-fifty chance" of employment in the post-war period, Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi said today in making public a report covering 304 employers.

ROME, Feb. 4 (AP)--Public relations officers at Allied headquarters said today that prolonged negotiations had failed to gain access for American and British correspondents as a group to any of the Balkan countries except Greece.

A preliminary report of the National Steel Corporation and subsidiaries for 1944 shows a net profit of $10,751,369, equal to $4.87 a share on 2,206,392 shares of capital stock, comparing with $11,698,362, or $5.30 a share, in 1943.

ABOARD ADMIRAL KINKAID'S FLAGSHIP, in the Philippines (U.P)--The U.S.S. Cooper went down fighting. Her five-inch batteries were blazing at the enemy when a torpedo broke her in two. She sank in thirty-six seconds.

After careful studies by several committees, the American Bankers Association has published a report in which it contends that Congress should not approve the proposed International Monetary Fund, but that it should approve, with modifications, the proposed International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

ATHENS, Feb. 4--Conversations between the Greek Government and Eam-Elas representatives seeking a peace agreement ended abruptly last night. At a late hour tonight the discussions had not been resumed. Officials said they probably would not be reopened before both sides had had time for thorough consultations.

WITH THE FIRST CAVALRY DIVISION, in Manlia, Feb. 4 (AP)-- By midafternoon today approximately 3,000 persons--mostly American women and children-- had been liberated from the Santo Tomas internment camp. They had been held there since May 1, 1942.

Mishel Piastro gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. The violinist presented a program, the first half of which was devoted to the infrequently played sonata in A minor, by the eighteenth century Italian composer, Nicolo Pasquali, and the Glazunoff concerto.

In a market where trading in stocks exceeded one million shares for every day of the week, prices alternately rose and fell for stocks and for grain. All the war news was favorable; but, more perhaps than on previous occasions, speculative sentiment was divided between favorable conclusions from a victorious campaign and uncertainties of an early peace.

MOSCOW, Feb. 4 (AP)--Alexei, former Metropolitan of Novgorod and Leningrad, was crowned Patriarch of Moscow tend All the Russians today in a traditional ceremony of the Russian Orthodox Church at Bogoyavlensk Cathedral.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has signed Booth Tarkington and Katherine Anne Porter to write for the films. Mr. Tarkington will prepare the story for the next picture in the Hardy family series. Miss Porter will do a screen play for production by Sidney Franklin.

Charley Beetham, former Ohio State runner, now a lieutenant in the Navy, who, among other achievements, has annexed the National A.A.U. 800-meter crown four times, was voted the outstanding performer in this year's Millrose games that were held in Madison Square Garden last Saturday night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 (U.P.) --"Going My Way," Paramount's heart-warming story of two Catholic priests, and its stars, Bing Crosby and Barry Fitzgerald, were nominated tonight for gilt Oscars by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

LONDON, Monday, Feb. 5--Russian armored columns, in a new nineteen-mile advance on Berlin's Oder River front, yesterday outflanked the key fortress of Kuestrin, drove a wedge between that city and the Baltic port of Stettin and thrust to within thirty-nine miles of the German capital, Moscow announced last night.

Eleven one-man shows and several group exhibitions are on this week's art calendar. The Knoedler Galleries will open today its most important exhibition of the season, "Dutch Masters of the Seventeenth Century." Many of these pictures have never been shown before in this country and have been lent from important collections.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 4--Middlebury's Panthers returned to their snow lair in Vermont tonight with the most singular triumph of their ski history.

Through snapping fire--crackers, waving banners and cheering throngs, the dusty first convoy over the Stilwell Road rolled the other day under the arching west gate of ancient Kunming. The Chinese people had heard about this incredible road built by the Americans; it was necessary to convince them that it would deliver the goods.

MALOLOS, Luzon, Feb. 3 (Delayed) (AP)--The Filipino political pot is still boiling in this town, birthplace of the first Philippine Republic and incubator of the 1899-1901 insurrection against the United States.

ROME, Feb. 4--About 30,000 cheering Romans witnessed today the unusual sight of the Pope standing silhouetted in the window of his private library, his arms opened wide in a gesture of blessing which closed the triduum of penitence called by the Vatican.

American women have given "a promise of prayer and a pledge of action for our comrades in arms in European countries." Margaret A. Hickey, president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs of the United States, declared yesterday afternoon. She spoke at a meeting honoring officers of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs in the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--The nation's capital rejoiced today over the entry into Manila. The rejoicing was led by a statement written by President Roosevelt, who said "our hearts have quickened" at the great events developing in the Eastern theatre of war.

Aherence of leaders of important unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations to the Liberal party instead of to the American Labor party was announced yesterday when officers of the Liberal party told of the organization of a trade union division on which CIO leaders are strongly represented.

"There is a growing consciousness among the citizens of Australia that the problems confronting the people bordering on the Pacific Ocean are so tremendous and so perplexing that they cannot be solved in isolation," Canon William J. Edwards of Australia declared in a sermon yesterday morning in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 (AP)--The last mission of the "Missouri Sue," Liberator, which glided back to England from German territory with all four engines silenced, was described today by First Lieut, Nathaniel Glickman of the Bronx, N.Y., its bombardier.

HEADQUARTERS OF 21ST BOMBER COMMAND, Guam, Monday, Feb. 5--Superfortresses struck at Kobe yesterday for the first time in daylight, and details made public today disclosed that thirty-four fires had been started in industrial areas of Japan's sixth city.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4--Open-market trading in lard and rendered pork fat is at a standstill, and brokers say the situation is the worst, so far as supplies are concerned, since the start of the war. The large Government set-aside requirements and a drastic reduction in receipts of hogs last week further complicates the situation.

This gives a smooth, iceslippery surface for sliding.

IWO, Volcano Islands, Feb. 21-- There is no front line on bloody Iwo. The whole island is a battle zone. The front line may be the northern edge of the southern airfield captured by the marines yesterday. It may be at the foot of Mount Suribachi.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today that prices for items in its cost of living rose 2.3 per cent in January above those of a year ago, and 27.1 per cent over the 1935-39 average.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 21-- Louis Hayward will be starred with his wife, Ida Lupino, in the Hunt Stromberg production, "Young Widow." "Young Widow," a United Artists release, is based on the novel by Clarissa Fairchild Cushman. It has been in production one week.
